questions.text: Which of the following local anaesthetics is an amide?
questions.solution:
Prilocaine is a local anesthetic that is classified as an Amide.

All the other drugs are classified as esters.

questions.text: What is the preferred treatment of uterine prolapse in a nulliparous woman who desires future pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Sling surgery or cervicopexy is usually performed in a young female with uterine prolapse who is nulliparous and desires future pregnancy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presented with back pain radiating to the leg after lifting a heavy suitcase. There is sensory loss over the anterolateral aspect of the ​leg, dorsum of the foot, and great toe. The medial hamstring reflex is diminished. The knee and ankle jerks are normal. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in this case scenario is L4-L5 disc prolapse.

The points given in the question in favor of this diagnosis are back pain radiating to the leg, sensory loss over the anterolateral aspect of the ​leg, dorsum of the foot, great toe, diminished medial hamstring reflex, and normal ankle jerk. 

The prolapsed intervertebral disc (PIVD) usually presents in adults between 20 to 40 years. The most common symptom is low back pain. It can be associated with or without pain radiating down the back of the leg (sciatica). 

Neurological features of L4-L5 PIVD are: 

  • Weakness of extensor hallucis longus and dorsiflexor muscles of the foot
  • Sensory loss over the anterolateral aspect of knee and leg, dorsum of the foot, and the great toe. One or more adjacent toes may also be involved (i.e., 1st web space) but never the little toe
  • Diminished medial hamstring reflex
  • Knee jerk and ankle jerk are normal.

Tests for diagnosis:

1. Straight Leg Raising Test (SLRT): 

This test is done to assess nerve root irritation in the lumbosacral area. The patient is made to lie on the back with the head extended, with hips and legs in a neutral position. Affected leg passively and slowly raised by the ankle with the knee fully extended. SLRT test negative if the leg can be raised 80–90 degrees without pain. SLRT test positive if pain elicited between 30-60 or 70 degrees from horizontal. Lasègue's test is a modified SLRT where the knee is bent to 90 degrees. 

2. Crossed straight-leg test: 

SLRT on the unaffected side. Pain felt on the affected side and is termed as contralateral positive SLRT or crossed SLRT positive. It is often highly specific for a large central prolapse. 

3. Bowstring sign or popliteal compression test: 

This test is more specific for disc prolapse than SLRT. It is performed by eliciting SLRT until the patient experiences sciatic pain. Now without reducing the amount of lift, the knee is bent to relax the sciatic nerve. The pain in the buttocks is immediately relieved. Following this, the popliteal fossa is pressed to stretch the lateral popliteal nerve behind the lateral tibial condyle. Tightening of the nerve like a bowstring re-induces the pain. 

MRI is the investigation of choice.

Treatment:

  • Bed rest, heat, ice, NSAIDs, muscle relaxants and/or spinal traction are commonly advised
  • Operative removal of the prolapsed disc: 
    • Absolute indication - cauda equina compression syndrome 
    • Relative indications - neurological deterioration, persistent pain and/or failed conservative treatment

questions.text: Which pattern of inheritance does the pedigree chart denote?
questions.solution:
The above pattern of pedigree chart denotes a pattern of X- linked dominant inheritance.

Points in favour of X linked dominant inheritance in the given chart:

  • Females affected twice as often as males.
  • Affected female shows 50% probability of transmitting the disease to her son or daughter.
  • Affected male transmits the disease to all his daughters and none of his sons.

Related Pearl: Pedigree chart for different inheritance patterns

questions.text: In children, renal failure in terms of urine output is defined as_________________
questions.solution: Acute Kidney Injury/ Acute Renal failure in children is defined as eCCl( estimated creatinine clearance) decrease by 75% or eCCl < 35ml/min/1.73m2 or Urine output < 0.3ml/kg/hr for 24 hours or anuria for 12 hours.

questions.text: When the level of hardness in water is around 50-150mg/litre it is classified as_____________
questions.solution:
When the level of hardness in water is around 50-150mg/litre it is classified as moderately hard water.

Related Pearl: Hardness of Water

  • Hardness is the soap destroying power of water or the amount of dissolved calcium and magnesium in water.
  • It is most commonly caused by bicarbonates and sulphates of calcium and magnesium, but their nitrates and chlorides can also cause hardness.
  • Temporary (carbonate) hardness is due to bicarbonates of calcium and magnesium. 
  • Permanent (non-carbonate) hardness is due to sulphates, chlorides and nitrates.
  • 1 mEq/L of an ion that produces hardness is equal to 50 mg CaCO3 (50 ppm) in 1 litre of water.
Classification Level of hardness (mEq/l) Amount of ion producing hardness (mg/l)
Soft water Less than 1 Less than 50
Moderately hard 1 – 3 50 – 150
Hard water 3 – 6 150 – 300
Very hard water Over 6 More than 300
  • Drinking water must be moderately hard
  • Softening of water is recommended when the hardness exceeds 3 mEq/L (150 mg/litre)
  • Removal of hardness:
    • Boiling: 
      • This removes temporary hardness by expelling carbon dioxide and precipitating insoluble calcium carbonate. It would be expensive to do this on a large scale.
    • Addition of lime: 
      • This removes temporary hardness and also reduces magnesium. Lime absorbs carbon dioxide and precipitates insoluble calcium carbonate. In Clark’s method of softening water, lime is used.
    • Addition of sodium carbonate (soda ash): removes both temporary and permanent hardness.
    • Base exchange process:
      • This removes permanent and temporary hardness and can be used on a large scale. In this method, permutit is used. Sodium permutit is a complex compound of sodium, aluminium and silica. When hard water is passed through this permutit, the calcium and magnesium ions are removed by base exchange and is converted into calcium and magnesium permutit. This process reduces water to zero hardness, which is corrosive and thus it is then mixed with a part of raw water.

questions.text: Megaloblastic anemia is caused by all except
questions.solution:
Rifampicin is not known to cause megaloblastic anemia.

Tetracycline, Nitrofurantoin and Sulfasalazine are considered Anti-folate drugs and hence cause megaloblastic anemia.

questions.text:
Real time polymerase chain reaction is done for ___________
1.	DNA detection
2.	RNA detection
3.	Monitoring amplification of target nucleic acid
questions.solution: The PCR (Polymerase chain reaction) is a method of amplifying a target sequence of DNA. PCR provides a sensitive, selective, and extremely rapid means of amplifying any desired sequence of DNA. Real time PCR is a method by which the amount of the PCR product can be determined, and is very useful for investigating gene expression. It uses fluorescent dyes or specific DNA probes. It is also known as qPCR (Quantitative PCR).

questions.text: A pelvic bone found during a police investigation was suspected to be of a 35-year-old woman who went missing. The pelvic bone might not be hers if:

choices.text: The greater sciatic notch is L shaped

questions.solution:
The pelvic bone might not be of the lady if the preauricular sulcus is absent. The preauricular sulcus is always present in a female pelvis and it is absent in a male pelvis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old sexually active man presents with a rash over his palms and soles. On further probing, he admits that his partner was recently diagnosed with syphilis and he himself had an ulcer on his penis a few months back. Which is not a likely feature of this rash?
questions.solution:
In this patient, a new-onset rash in the setting of syphilis in his partner and a history of a penile ulcer are suggestive of secondary syphilis. A non-infectious maculopapular rash is usually the earliest manifestation.

It usually develops around 8 weeks after initial infection due to generalized treponemal dissemination. Rashes in secondary syphilis have three common features:

  • Non-pruritic
  • Coppery red color
  • Symmetrically distributed

Cutaneous lesions of secondary syphilis are not infectious as they do not have enough treponemes. Exceptions are condyloma lata and mucous patches, which are highly infectious.

questions.text: The germ theory of disease stated that most diseases were caused by microorganisms. Who advanced this theory?
questions.solution:
Louis Pasteur advanced the germ theory of disease, which stated that most diseases were caused by microorganisms.

He is also known for the following contributions:

  • Disproved the theory of spontaneous generation.
  • Developed vaccines for rabies and fowl cholera.
  • Pioneer of techniques of pasteurization and sterilization.

questions.text: Isocapnic buffering is?
questions.solution:
Normal pCO2 with increased CO2 is called Isocapnic buffering.

During exercise, initially CO2 production and increase in ventilation are proportionate. So, pCO2 remains the same despite increased CO2 production.

But in later stages, ventilation increases more than the rate of CO2 production. As a result, pCO2 decreases.

questions.text: The patient presents with sudden onset of fever and painful burning lesions on his right knee. Which of the following is not indicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
A systemic response(fever), along with prodromal symptoms like pain and presence of grouped herpetiform vesicles developing on the erythematous base is classical of Herpes zoster infection. In this case fluconazole is not indicated.

Tricyclic antidepressants are given for the management of pain.

Glucocorticoids are given for reduction of inflammation. However, it should not be used without concomitant antiviral therapy.

questions.text: Benedict’s test is positive with all of the following except __________
questions.solution:
Sucrose does not give a positive benedict’s test since it’s a non reducing substance. Benedict’s test is positive for reducing substances.

Benedict’s test: In alkaline pH, glucose is converted to a reducing agent called enediol. This converts cupric ions to cuprous oxide, yellow to red in colour.

It is positive with

  • Monosachharides such as glucose, fructose, galactose
  • Reducing disaccharides such as lactose, maltose, isomaltose
  • Acids: Homogentisic acid, ascorbic acid, glucuronic acid
  • Creatinine, uric acid in high concentration
  • Glutathione

Non reducing disachharides like sucrose, trehalose do not give the test positive.

questions.text: Most common site involved in genital TB is ____________
questions.solution:
Fallopian tubes are the most common site of genital tuberculosis.

Genital Tuberculosis:

  • Almost always a secondary infection.
  • Most common route of spread is hematogenous.
  • Most common site is bilateral fallopian tubes (most common part affected  is ampulla and most common pathology encountered is endosalpingitis).
  • Most common in 20-30 years age group.
  • Infertility is the most common symptom.
Site of genital TB % involved
Fallopian tubes 90-100
Uterus 50-60
Ovaries 20-30
Vagina/vulva 1-2

questions.text: Antenatal USG in a primigravida revealed fetal hydrocephalus. Postnatal MRI of the infant is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given T2 MRI image shows the racing car appearance, which is seen in agenesis of the corpus callosum. This sign refers to the widely spaced lateral ventricles with intervening Probst bundles(white matter tracts that are no longer able to cross the midline in the corpus callosum).

Appearances on axial MRI or CT resemble a Formula One car seen from above. The front tyres are represented by the widely spaced frontal horns anteriorly. The back tyres are represented by the dilated trigones seen posteriorly, which is also known as colpocephaly.

The image given below shows the racing car sign in corpus callosal agensis.

Other options:

Option B: Marchiafava - Bignami disease is a rare condition characterized by demyelination of the corpus callosum most often in patients with chronic alcoholism. The MRI image in this condition shows the sandwich sign.

 

Option C: Metachromatic leukodystrophy is an autosomal-recessive disease that results from a deficiency of the lysosomal enzyme arylsulfatase A. Symmetric confluent areas of T2 hyperintensity are seen in the periventricular white matter. Radiating T2 hypointense lines through the demyelinated deep white matter represent the sparing of the perivascular white matter. This results in the tigroid and leopard skin patterns when imaged in the long axis or cross-section, respectively. Subcortical U-fibers are spared.

Option D: The most common site of lipoma in the brain is the peri-callosal region. The CT below shows bracket calcification of lipoma and is called bracket sign.

questions.text: Identify the condenser _____
questions.solution:
Condensor lens of microscope is marked as B in the image. The purpose of the condenser lens is to focus the light onto the specimen.

A is coarse focusing knob.

C is objective lens. There are usually 3 or 4 objective lenses on a microscope. They almost always consist of 4X, 10X, 40X and 100X powers.

D is Illuminator. It is a steady light source used in place of a mirror.

questions.text: Which of the following can be used as a yardstick for the assessment of standards of therapy?
questions.solution:
Survival rate is used as yardstick for the assessment of standards of therapy.

Survival rate: It is defined as the proportion of survivors in a group (of patients), studied and followed over a period of time (5 years).

  • It is used to describe prognosis in certain disease conditions.
  • Survival period is usually counted from the date of diagnosis or start of treatment.
  • Useful in cancer studies.
  • Survival rate (SR)= Total no. of patients alive after 5 years / Total no. of patients treated X 100.

questions.text: A study is being conducted on anaemia in pregnancy. A normal distribution curve with a mean haemoglobin level of 10.6 gm/dL with a standard deviation of 2 gm/dL is obtained. Below what level would 5% of the women in the group have their haemoglobin values?
questions.solution:
5% of the pregnant women in this group will have their haemoglobin levels below 7.31 g/dL.

Solution:
Given Data :

  • Mean: 10.6 g/dL
  • Standard deviation : 2 g/dL

Step 1:

According to the empirical rule of a normal distribution, 95% of the population fall within 2 standard deviations of the mean, i.e., mean ± 2SD. 
This implies that the remaining 5% lie outside 2 SD, i.e. 2.5% below 2 SD and 2.5% above 2 SD. 
Therefore , Mean - 2SD = 10.6 − 2 (2) 
                                    = 10.6 − 4 
                                    = 6.6 g/dL 
Thus, 2.5% of pregnant women have Hb levels below 6.6 g/dL.

However, the question asks about 5% and not 2.5%. So options C and D have been ruled out.

Now Let's move to the next step.

Step 2:

According to the empirical rule of a normal distribution, 68% of the population fall within 1 standard deviation of the mean, i.e., mean±1SD. 
This implies that the remaining 32% lie outside 1 SD, i.e., 16% below 1 SD and 16% above 1 SD. 
The value of mean−1 SD is 8.6 g/dL (i.e. 10.6 − 2) 
Thus, 16% of pregnant women have Hb levels below 8.6 g/dL.

so now option A is ruled out 

Step 3:

The value for 5% must lie between the values where 2.5% and 16% of the population lie, i.e., between 6.6g/dL and 8g/dL. Only option B, 7.31 g/dL, satisfies this condition.

Hence, 5% of pregnant women have their Hb levels below 7.31 g/dL.

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

The normal distribution curve is the most common shape taken by continuous data distributions. It is also called bell curve (bell-shaped) or Gaussian distribution after mathematician Karl Friedrich Gauss.

The following is an image of three different normal distribution curves.

Salient features of the standard normal distribution:

  • Defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation
  • Has mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1
  • Mean = median = mode
  • Symmetric and have bell-shaped curves with a single peak
  • Total area under the curve is 1
  • Frequency of values is more around the center and less around the tails
  • No skew in the curve
  • Data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution
  • The empirical rule of a normal distribution:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean (mean ± 1 SD)
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD)
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD)

questions.text: A patient with recent-onset primary generalized epilepsy develops a skin reaction due to phenytoin sodium. What is the most appropriate course of action?

choices.text: Stop and restart phenytoin sodium after two weeks

questions.solution:
Hypersensitivity reaction to phenytoin warrants discontinuation of the drug. Switching to sodium valproate is the most appropriate course of action for this patient. 

Sodium valproate is one of the first-line agents indicated for GTCS. Clonazepam and ethosuximide are primarily used in absence seizures and are not indicated for GTCS. 

Clonazepam is indicated as adjunctive therapy in the absence seizures when first-line agents (ethosuximide, sodium valproate, lamotrigine) fail to control the seizures adequately.

questions.text: In Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome (MRKH), which of the following is absent?
questions.solution:
In MURCS (Mullerian agenesis, Renal aplasia and Cervicothoracic Somite dysplasia) testes is absent. It is also known as MRKH (Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser) syndrome.

It has Karyotype of 46,XX. So, the gonads present are ovaries (in contrast to Androgen Insensitivity syndrome where the testes are present).

Vagina in its upper 2/3rd are absent but lower one-third is present as it develops from urogenital sinus.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes in urea cycle is a hydrolase?
questions.solution:
Arginase in urea cycle is a hydrolase type of enzyme. Hydrolytic cleavage of arginine is catalysed by liver arginase. It releases urea and ornithine. Ornithine then reenters liver mitochondria and participates in additional rounds of urea synthesis.

Urea cycle:

Related Pearl: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about Insulin-like growth factor-1(IGF-1)?

choices.text: It is synthesized in the liver
It has a major role in fetal development
It is also synthesized by bone
It’s secretion is regulated by growth hormone levels

questions.solution:
IGF -2 has a major role in growth during fetal development, while IGF-1 plays a major role in skeletal and cartilage growth.

Insulin-like growth factors (IGF) are the polypeptide growth factors that are similar to insulin in their structures. They are also called somatomedins. IGFs that are found in human beings are IGF-1 and IGF-2.

IGF -1 is also called somatomedin C. It is synthesized by the liver and other peripheral tissues like bone. Secretion is independent of growth hormone before birth, however, after birth, the growth hormone stimulates the secretion of IGF-1. The major physiological role of IGF-1 is to stimulate skeletal and cartilage growth. Its plasma concentration rises during childhood, peaks during puberty, and declines during old age.

IGF-2 secretion is independent of the growth hormone levels. It has a major role in the growth of fetus before birth.

questions.text: A young woman complains of pain in lower abdomen with no history of fever. WBC count is 9000 per microlitre. Her LMP was 2 weeks back. Most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Young female having mid-cycle lower abdominal pain without fever and leucocytosis points towards a diagnosis of Mittleschmerz.

It is a mid-cycle pain, not lasting more than 12-24 hours, around ovulation. Pain is located in one of the iliac fossa and may be accompanied by vaginal bleeding.

questions.text: Suspicious deaths were occurring after receiving parcels via mail in the USA. The microscopy of the specimen collected showed the following appearance. The bioterrorism agent involved can also show ___________
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a bioterrorism agent with the gram stain showing a box car appearance/bamboo stick appearance is suggestive of Bacillus anthracis (Category A bioterrorism agent). Bacillus anthracis can also show a medusa head appearance on microscopy.

Bacillus anthracis is a non-motile gram-positive bacillus that has a characteristic box car or a bamboo stick appearance on gram staining. On the agar plate, they form irregular round colonies that are raised, dull, greyish-white colonies giving a frosted glass appearance as given in the image below.

Long interlacing chains of bacilli, resembling matted hair, are present on the edge of the colonies giving it a medusa-head appearance when seen on low-power microscopy.

M’Fadyean’s reaction is used to demonstrate the polypeptide capsule which is stained with polychrome methylene blue. It also shows an inverted fir tree appearance on gelatin slab culture. On a solid media containing penicillin, the colonies give a string of pearls appearance as given in the image below. 

Other options:

Option A: A fried egg appearance of colonies is seen in the case of Mycoplasma.

Option C: Draughtsman or carrom coin appearance of colonies on blood agar is seen in the case of Streptococcus pneumonia, as given in the image below.

Option D: A fluorescent antibody-stained specimen of Yersinia pestis reveals rod-shaped bacteria with characteristic bipolar staining or safety pin or hairpin-like appearance.

questions.text: Choose the correct statement regarding Mitsuda reaction of the lepromin test.

choices.text: It consists of an indurated skin nodule which may ulcerate
It is a measure of humoral immunity against lepra antigens
Histologically, there is an  infiltration of neutrophils

questions.solution:
The true statement among the following is It consists of an indurated skin nodule which may ulcerate.

The lepromin test consists of two reactions:

  1. Early reaction (of Fernandez): Develops within 24-48 hrs and lasts for 3-5 days. It is analogous to the tuberculin reaction & not of much significance.
  2. Late reaction (of Mitsuda): It starts in 1 week & peaks at 4 weeks. It consists of an indurated skin nodule which may ulcerate. It is a measure of cell mediated immunity against lepra antigens. Histologically, there is an infiltration of lymphocytes, epithelioid cells & giant cells. It is the more meaningful reaction to determine whether a person can mount an immune reaction against lepra bacilli or not.

The antigens used in lepromin test are

  • Lepromin A (from armadillo-derived lepra bacilli)
  • Dharmendra antigen

questions.text: In alloimmune thrombocytopenia, antigen is found against antibody ______________
questions.solution:
Antigen against antibody HPA1a (platelet alloantigen) is found in Neonatal Alloimmune Thrombocytopenic purpura (NATP).

It is caused by development of maternal antibodies against antigens present on fetal platelets that are shared with the father and recognized as foreign by maternal immune system.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is not caused by pseudomonas aeroginosa?
questions.solution:
Glanders disease is not caused by pseudomonas. Causative organism for Glander’s disease is Burkholderia Mallei.

Diseases caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa:

  • Shanghai fever: self-limited febrile illness
  • Jacuzzi syndrome (Hot tub folliculitis/Pseudomonas aeruginosa folliculitis) is a common type of folliculitis, which causes inflammation of hair follicles.
  • Scromboid poisoning: It is one of the most common causes of morbidity associated with fish intake which have not been refrigerated properly from the time they were caught until the time they were served. Bacteria act on compounds in the fish, releasing histamine. Process is induced by enzymes produced by primarily enteric gram-negative bacteria (e.g., Morganella morganii, Escherichia coli, Klebsiella species and Pseudomonas aeruginosa) found in the fish's cutis and intestines.

questions.text: Which of the following programs aims to globally strengthen poison centers?
questions.solution:
The International Program on Chemical Safety (IPCS) INTOX program is a global endeavor established by WHO to promote chemical safety through the establishment and strengthening of poison centers. The INTOX Data Management System (INTOX DMS) is a software system specially designed for poison centres.

Option B: WHOPES - World Health Organization (WHO) Pesticide Evaluation Scheme was set up in 1960, to promote and coordinate the testing and evaluation of pesticides for public health.

Option C: INCHEM - Joint project by collaboration between IPCS and Canadian Centre for Occupational Health and Safety (CCOHS), for the chemical safety and the sound management of chemicals.

Option D: SAICM (Strategic Approach to International Chemicals Management) is a global policy framework to foster the sound management of chemicals.

questions.text: Which of the following is used for permanent interstitial implant brachytherapy?
questions.solution:
In interstitial implant brachytherapy cesium 131 is one of the permanent source of implant. In this type of brachytherapy sources are inserted directly into tumour cells.

It can be permenant or temporary sources.

   Temporary sources    Permanent sources
    Iridium-192    Cesium-131
    Radium-226    Gold-198
    Cesium-137    Iodine 125
   Cobalt-60    Radon 222
  Californium    Pallidum-103
   Tantalum    Yttrium

Note: cobalt -60 and cesium-137 are used for both teletherapy and brachytherapy.

questions.text: Plasticity is seen in which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Plasticity is seen in all the structures given above, including sensory cortex.

Auditory plasticity in humans include the observation that in individuals who become deaf before language skills are fully developed, sign language activates auditory association areas.

If a solitary smooth muscle is stretched, at first it will contract with greater tension. However, if the stretch is maintained, the tension gradually decreases. This is also called plasticity.

Neuroplasticity, is the ability of the brain to change and adapt. The activity of a certain area of the brain with a given function can be transferred to a different area, and synapses may be strengthened or weakened with time.

questions.text: Which of the following is a selenium containing antioxidant?
questions.solution:
Glutathione peroxidase is a selenium containing antioxidant. Hence adequate selenium intake is required for antioxidant action.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used to assess the severity of acute pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
The level of amylase does not correlate with the severity of acute pancreatitis.

The diagnosis of acute pancreatitis can be made by a serum amylase level that is three-times higher than normal. However, the half-life of amylase is short, which means that the levels might be normal in patients who present to the hospital late. Serum lipase is a more sensitive and specific test than amylase.

It is extremely important to identify patients who have severe acute pancreatitis because they require more aggressive management. Many prognostic scores have been used for this purpose. The Ranson score is the one most commonly used and is given below. Severe pancreatitis is diagnosed if three or more factors in the Ranson score are present. The main advantage of the Ranson score is that the patient's condition is assessed at the time of admission and again at 48 hours following admission.

Related Pearl: Ranson Prognostic Criteria for Acute Pancreatitis

Ranson's prognostic criteria at presentation
Parameter Non-gallstone pancreatitis Gallstone pancreatitis
Age >55 years >70 years
Blood glucose level >200 mg/dL >220 mg/dL
White blood cell count >16,000 cells/mm3 >18,000 cells/mm3
Serum LDH level >350 IU/L  >400 IU/L
Serum Aspartate aminotransferase level  >250 IU/L  >250 IU/L

 

Ranson's prognostic criteria after 48 hours of admission
Parameter Non-gallstone pancreatitis Gallstone pancreatitis 
Hematocrit fall
 >10% >10%
Serum calcium level <8 mg/dL <8 mg/dL
Base deficit >4 mEq/L >5 mEq/L
Blood urea nitrogen level increase 

≥5 mg/dL despite IV fluid hydration

 ≥2 mg/dL despite IV fluid hydration
Fluid sequestration
  >6 L  >4 L
PaO2  <60 mm Hg  Not available

Ranson score ≥3 defines severe pancreatitis.

Score Interpretation

  • 0 to 2 points: 0% to 3% mortality
  • 3 to 4 points: 15% mortality
  • 5 to 6 points: 40% mortality
  • 7 to 11: nearly 100% mortality

questions.text: Which of the following is the best indicator for long-term nutritional status?
questions.solution:
Height for age is the best indicator of long-term nutritional status (chronic malnutrition).

The influence of malnutrition is seen earlier in a child's weight. This means that changes in weight are more indicative of acute status, and weight-based indices are used to assess acute malnutrition. Weight for age is the most commonly used index. Changes in height occur as a result of long-term nutritional deprivation and is hence, an indicator of chronic malnutrition. A low weight for height, or wasting, also indicates acute malnutrition.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about the condition shown in the image below?

choices.text: Hypernatremia is a major cause of delayed neurologic deficits in this condition
Sensitivity of a CT scan is best within 96 hours
The Hunt-Hess scale can be used for the grading of this condition
Giant aneurysms are those greater than 3.5 cm

questions.solution:
The non-contrast CT image above shows a subarachnoid hemorrhage (marked with an arrow) with blood filling the subarachnoid cisterns bilaterally and into the Sylvian fissure.

Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (SAH):

  • Scales used for SAH grading are the Hunt-Hess scale and the World Federation of Neurosurgical Societies classification.
  • Most common causes of SAH are head trauma and rupture of a saccular aneurysm.
  • Giant aneurysms are those which are >2.5cm.
  • Characteristic clinical feature is the presence of a sudden onset, severe headache which the patient often describes as ‘the worst headache of their life’.
  • The four major causes of delayed neurologic deficits in SAH are rerupture of an aneurysm, hydrocephalus, vasospasm, and hyponatremia.
  • The gold standard of diagnosing SAH is a non-contrast CT scan which has a high sensitivity up to 72 hours. If a CT scan is negative, yet there is high suspicion of an SAH, then a lumbar puncture (LP) is to be done to check for xanthochromia, which is detectable from 2 hours after hemorrhage and lasts several weeks. If both CT and LP are negative, then a CT angiography can be done to search for the cause.

Note: The Modified Fisher scale is a method for grading SAH seen on non-contrast CT. The Hunt and Hess scale describes the severity of SAH and is used as a predictor of survival.

questions.text: What is the maximum time period within which a recurrent episode of UTI is regarded as a relapse and not a reinfection?
questions.solution: Recurrence of a UTI within 2 weeks is usually regarded as relapse rather than reinfection. It may also indicate the need to evaluate the patient for a sequestered focus.

questions.text: For burn resuscitation, amount of Ringer's lactate to be used in a 10 year old child is_____________
questions.solution:
Resuscitation of a less than 14 year old burn patient should begin at 3 mL/kg/% TBSA; this balances a higher resuscitation volume requirement due to larger surface area per unit body mass with the smaller paediatric intravascular volume, increasing risk for volume overload.

Very small children (i.e., < 30 kg), should receive maintenance fluids of D5LR (5% dextrose in Lactated Ringers), in addition to the burn resuscitation fluid.

Burn resuscitation fluid rates and target urine output by burn type and age:

Category of burn Age and weight Adjusted fluid rates Urine output
Flame or scald Adults and older children (>/= 14 years old 2ml RL/kg/%TSBA 0.5ml/kg/hr 30-50ml/hr
Children (< 14 years olds) 3ml RL/kg/%TSBA 1ml/kg/hr
Infants and young children (</=30 kg) 3ml RL/Kg/%TSBA Plus a sugar containing solution at maintenance rate 1ml/kg/hr
Electrical injury All ages 4ml/kg/%TSBA until urine clears 1-1.5ml/kg/hr until urine clears

questions.text: A 35 year old male presents with seizure and loss of consciousness. He also complains of headache for the past few days. He has no prior history of convulsions or any medication. His CT scan is given below. CSF examination reveals antibodies to cysticercal antigen. Which of the following is false about the clinical condition?

choices.text: This is a probable diagnosis of Neurocysticercosis
The given CT scan findings confirm Neurocysticercosis in this patient
Visualization of the parasite in the eye would have confirmed the diagnosis
Intestinal disease is treated by single dose Praziquantel

questions.solution:
This is a CT showing a typical lesion of neurocysticercosis (colloidal vesicular stage). According to the criteria for diagnosis of cysticercosis, the CT scan should show a characteristic scolex in the cyst for confirming the diagnosis.

Criteria for diagnosis of Neurocysticercosis:

1. Absolute criteria

  • Demonstration of cysticerci by histologic or microscopic examination of biopsy material
  • Visualization of the parasite in the eye by funduscopy
  • Neuroradiologic demonstration of cystic lesions containing a character- istic scolex

2. Major criteria

  • Neuroradiologic lesions suggestive of neurocysticercosis
  • Demonstration of antibodies to cysticerci in serum by enzyme-linked immunoelectrotransfer blot
  • Resolution of intracranial cystic lesions spontaneously or after therapy with albendazole or praziquantel alone

3. Minor criteria

  • Lesions compatible with neurocysticercosis detected by neuroimaging studies
  • Clinical manifestations suggestive of neurocysticercosis
  • Demonstration of antibodies to cysticerci or cysticercal antigen in cerebrospinal fluid by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay
  • Evidence of cysticercosis outside the central nervous system (e.g., cigar-shaped soft-tissue calcifications)

4. Epidemiologic criteria

  • Residence in a cysticercosis-endemic area
  • Frequent travel to a cysticercosis-endemic area
  • Household contact with an individual infected with Taenia solium

Diagnosis is confirmed by:

  • Either one absolute criterion
  • Or a combination of two major criteria, one minor criterion, and one epidemiologic criterion.

A probable diagnosis is supported by the fulfillment of:

  • One major criterion plus two minor criteria; or
  • One major criterion plus one minor criterion and one epidemiologic criterion; or
  • Three minor criteria plus one epidemiologic criterion.

Other options:

The above case suggests a probable diagnosis of Neurocysticercosis --> 1 Major + 2 Minor criteria are satisfied.

Visualization of parasite in the eye by fundoscopy is an absolute criteria and that alone would be sufficient to confirm the disease.

Intestinal disease is treated by single dose Praziquantel.

questions.text: All of the following patients presenting with abdominal pain and shock need immediate laparotomy except:
questions.solution:
All of the following patients presenting with abdominal pain and shock need immediate laparotomy except hemorrhagic  pancreatitis.

Treatment of hemorrhagic pancreatitis:

  • Adequate initial resuscitation and intensive follow-up are probably the most important elements in the management of patients with hemorrhagic pancreatitis.
  • Careful monitoring of fluid and electrolytes and blood gases is required to avoid shock and renal and pulmonary failure. 
  • Antibiotics are indicated in patients with biliary tract disease and penetrating ulcer in whom the risk of secondary infection is considerable.
  • Associated diseases that initiated pancreatitis and that in themselves may be life-threatening, such as acute cholecystitis or cholangitis, should be promptly treated by operation.
  • Diagnostic and therapeutic lavage are justified in the treatment of hemorrhagic pancreatitis.
  • Resection of the necrotic pancreas should be considered when the patient fails to improve after lavage and nonoperative resuscitation.

questions.text: All are true regarding measles vaccine except_________
questions.solution: Measles vaccine has a sub-cutaneous (and not intramuscular) dose of 0.5ml. The first dose is given at 9 months and second dose at 16- 24 months.

questions.text: A child has a small head, minor anomalies of the face including a thin upper lip, growth delay and developmental disability. This can be due to all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Structural abnormalities like small head, thin upper lip in a child cannot  be due to polygenic syndrome. Polygenic disease is a genetic disease where multiple genes contribute disease like hypertension and diabetes (and not structural abnormalities).

Microcephaly, thin upper lip and growth and developmental delay can be seen in:

  • Chromosomal syndrome tetrasomy 21p (Pallister-Killian syndrome).
  • Teratogenic syndrome like fetal alcohol syndrome.
  • Mendelian syndrome like Rubinstein-Taybi syndrome.

questions.text: Leber Hereditary Optic Neuropathy is associated with all except ___________
questions.solution:
Leber Hereditary Optic Neuropathy is not associated with genomic imprinting.

Leber hereditary optic neuropathy is a prototype of mitochondrial inheritance. It manifests as progressive bilateral loss of central vision.

Mitochondrial inheritance: The feature unique to mtDNA is maternal inheritance. Mothers transmit mtDNA to all their offspring, male and female; however, daughters but not sons transmit the DNA further to their progeny.

LHON is due to one of three homoplasmic point mutations of mtDNA that affect genes encoding different subunits of complex I of the mitochondrial Electron transport chain.

Examples for mitochondrial inherited diseases:

  • LHON
  • Leigh’s disease
  • MELAS
  • NARP syndrome
  • Kearns-Sayre syndrome
  • Chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia
  • Pearson syndrome.

A cell can have some mitochondria that have a mutation in the mtDNA and some that do not. Thus tissues may harbor both wild- type and mutant mtDNA, a situation called Heteroplasmy.

Homoplasmy refers to a cell that has a uniform collection of mtDNA: either completely normal mtDNA or completely mutant mtDNA.

questions.text: A patient presents with itching around the periorbital region. Identify the given skin lesion?
questions.solution:
This given image is of Lichen Planus dermatitis of the face.

Typically the lesion shows firm, shiny, polygonal, papules with a red to violet color. On closer observation, tracers of thin white lines can be seen on the surface of the lesions (Wickham’s striae).

Related Pearl: Nail changes in lichen planus

Nail involvement in lichen planus occurs in up to 10% of the cases but is usually a minor feature of the disease.

Dorsal Nail Pterygium is the most specific nail change in Lichen planus. The fusion of dorsal nail fold and nail bed leads to pterygium.

The most frequent nail change is the exaggeration of longitudinal lines and linear depressions due to a slight thinning of the nail plate.

Pup-tent sign - elevation of nail in shape of tent

Trachyonychia - 20 nail dystrophy

Subungual Hyperkeratosis and Onycholysis

Longitudinal Melanonychia in Lichen Planus of the nail bed

Permanent destruction of several toenails with ulceration of soles (rare variant)

Image shows  Nails in Lichen planus presented with irregular longitudinal grooves and ridges .

Image : Dorsal Nail Pterygium

Image : Pup-tent sign 

Image: Trachyonychia

questions.text: What are the net number of ATP’s generated in rapaport leubering cycle ?
questions.solution:
The net number of ATPs generated in the Rapaport Luebering cycle(2,3 BPG shunt pathway) is zero. 2 ATPs are generated at the pyruvate kinase step, but that is used up by hexokinase and fructokinase.

Rapaport luebering cycle:

In the erythrocytes. Bisphosphoglycerate mutase converts 1,3-bisphosphoglycerate (BPG) to 2,3-BPG. Then BPG-phosphatase removes the phosphate group to form 3-phosphoglycerate

Significance of BPG

  • 2,3-BPG binds to hemoglobin and reduces the affinity towards oxygen. So, in the presence of 2,3- BPG, oxyhemoglobin will unload oxygen more easily in tissues.
  • Under hypoxic conditions the 2,3-BPG concentration in the RBC increases, thus favoring the release of oxygen to the tissues even when pO2 is low.
  • The compensatory increase in 2,3-BPG in high altitudes favors oxygen dissociation. BPG affinity is decreased in fetal circulation.

questions.text: What is false about Eales disease amongst the following?
questions.solution:
Optic neuritis is not seen in Eales disease.

Eales disease:

  • It is an idiopathic, inflammatory, peripheral retinal vasculopathy which presents with recurrent vitreous hemorrhage in young males.
  • The vasculitis is clinically seen as a sheathing of the vessels, which leak copiously on fluorescein angiography.
  • Obliteration of the vessels occurs, seen as solid white lines and these are surrounded by arteriovenous shunt vessels and neovascularization on the retina or extending into the vitreous.
  • After a few recurrences, the hemorrhage organizes and is associated with a tractional retinal detachment and secondary glaucoma.
  • Treatment usually involves systemic steroids. Abnormal vessels under traction should be treated with photocoagulation.
  • ATTs are also usually given since it is believed that a hypersensitivity reaction of the retinal vessels to tuberculous-proteins may be the cause of vasculitis.

questions.text:
Peripheral smear in a patient shows the following finding. Which of the following will not be present in the given condition?
a. Ringed sideroblasts
b.Pawn ball megakaryocytes
c. Tingible bodies
questions.solution:
The peripheral smear shows pseudo pelger huet cells (neutrophils with only two nuclear lobes and occasionally neutrophils that completely lack nuclear segmentation) which are seen in Myelodysplastic syndrome. All the above options can be seen in MDS except Tingible bodies.

Options explained:

  • Ringed sideroblasts are erythroblasts with iron laden mitochondria visible as perinuclear granules in Prussian blue stained aspirates or biopsy.
  • Pawn ball megakaryocytes are megakaryocytes with single nuclear lobes or multiple separate nuclei.
  • Tingible bodies (macrophages containing phagocytosed apoptotic cells) are seen in non neoplastic reactive hyperplasia of the lymph node.

Related Pearl: Bone Marrow Changes in Myelodysplastic Syndrome (MDS)

The myelodysplastic syndrome can lead to dysplasia of the erythroid series, myeloid series, and megakaryocytes.

Dysplasia of erythroid series:

  • Megaloblastoid maturation - Abnormally large erythroid cells
  • Nuclear budding abnormalities - Nucleus with abnormal shape
  • Ring sideroblasts - Erythroblasts with stainable iron in the cytoplasm 

 

Dysplasia of myeloid series:

  • Neutrophils with a decreased number of secondary granules
  • Pseudo-Pelger-Hüet cells- neutrophils with only two nuclear lobes

 

Dysplasia of the megakaryocytes:

  • Megakaryocyte with single nuclear lobe
  • Pawn ball megakaryocytes- cells with multiple separate nuclei

If only one lineage is affected, then it is called single lineage dysplasia. If multiple lineages are affected, then it is called multilineage dysplasia. If the percentage of ring sideroblasts is more than 15% it is called MDS with ring sideroblasts (MDS-RS).

questions.text: All of the following are true about infectious crystalline keratopathy except?

choices.text: It is a variety of stromal keratitis
Prolonged treatment with corticosteroid is necessary

questions.solution:
Infectious crystalline keratopathy (IKC) requires prolonged treatment with topical vancomycin, moxifloxacin or gatifloxacin eye drops with discontinuation of topical steroids.

Infectious crystalline keratopathy (IKC):

  • It is a special variety of stromal keratitis distinguishable by appearance of crystalline arboriform white deposits in the corneal stroma.
  • Associated with minimal or no inflammatory reaction.
  • Usually seen in immunocompromised corneas such as following corneal grafts and prolonged corticosteroid use or contact lens wear.
  • Alpha haemolytic streptococcus, Pepto-streptococcus, Pseudomonas, and Candida are most commonly implicated organisms.
  • Recurrence of infection and stromal scarring are common which may then require keratoplasty.

Differential diagnosis of crystalline deposits in the cornea includes:

  • Schnyder’s crystalline corneal dystrophy
  • Hypergammaglobulinaemia
  • Cystinosis
  • Lipid keratopathy
  • Bietti’s dystrophy
  • Lymphoproliferative disorders

questions.text: Treatment of choice of placental site trophoblastic disease is________
questions.solution:
Surgery (hysterectomy) is the recommended mode of treatment for placental site trophoblastic disease.

Placental site trophoblastic disease:

  • Arises from the placental bed trophoblasts and invades the myometrium.
  • Follows a full-term normal delivery.
  • Tumour contains mainly cytotrophoblasts with few or no syncytiotrophoblasts.
  • Most of these tumours run a benign course. Malignancy is rare.
  • Beta-hCG level is low. Serum human placental lactogen level is high.
  • Tumour is resistant to chemotherapy. Hysterectomy is the recommended treatment.

questions.text: The most common cause of death in a lower-middle income country like India is ____________
questions.solution:
Ischemic Heart Disease followed by stroke are the leading causes of death worldwide (overall) as well as in the lower-middle (India), upper-middle and High income group countries.

On the other hand, lower respiratory tract infections followed by diarrhoeal diseases are the leading causes of death in low-income group of countries.

questions.text: Primary amenorrhoea refers to failure of menstruation beyond the age of _______
questions.solution:
Primary amenorrhoea refers to failure if menstruation beyond the age of 15 years regardless of development of secondary sexual characters.

Secondary amenorrhoea absence of menses for more than three months in girls or women who previously had regular menstrual cycles or six months in girls or women who had irregular menses

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about Diabetes?

choices.text: Alzheimer's disease is nicknamed as Type 3 Diabetes
Myotonic dystrophy can be associated with Diabetes mellitus
Fulminant Diabetes is a form of Type 2 DM
Honeymoon phase is seen in Type 1 DM

questions.solution:
Fulminant diabetes is a form of acute onset Type 1 DM seen mainly among Japanese.

Alzheimer's disease(AD) is sometimes referred to as Type 3 or Brain Diabetes. It is because AD is associated with insulin resistance in the brain. 

Honeymoon phase is seen in Type 1 DM. After the initial clinical presentation of DM, follows a phase in which glycemic control is achieved with modest doses of insulin or, rarely, without insulin. This is referred to as the honeymoon phase. This phase soon disappears and the individual becomes insulin deficient.

Myotonic dystrophy is one of the genetic syndromes associated with Diabetes mellitus. The other syndromes include Wolfram's syndrome, Down's syndrome, Klinefelter's syndrome, Turner's syndrome, Huntungton's chorea etc.

questions.text: Nucleolar pattern of staining is seen in antinuclear antibodies to ______________
questions.solution:
Nucleolar pattern of staining is seen in antinuclear antibodies to RNA.

Related Pearl: Pattern of nuclear body suggests the type of antibody present in patient’s serum.

Five basic patterns of nuclear fluorescence is recognized for anti-nuclear antibodies:

Staining pattern Antigen
Homogenous or diffuse nuclear staining Antibodies to chromatin, histones, and occasionally double-stranded DNA
Rim or peripheral staining Antibodies to double-stranded DNA, and sometimes to nuclear envelope proteins
Speckled pattern

One of the most commonly observed patterns of fluorescence, the least specific. 

Antibodies to non-DNA nuclear constituents such as Sm antigen, ribonucleoprotein, and SS-A and SS-B reactive antigens.
Nucleolar pattern

Few discrete spots of fluorescence within the nucleus and represent antibodies to RNA.

Seen in systemic sclerosis.
Centromeric pattern

Seen in systemic sclerosis

Often contain antibodies specific for centromeres, which give rise to this pattern.

questions.text: All the following are true regarding Van Nuys Prognostic index except:

choices.text: ER/PR status is one of the prognostic factor
Used to classify ductal carcinoma in situ
Useful aid in deciding which patients  benefit from adjuvant radiotherapy (RT)
Useful aid in deciding which patients are at increased risk of local recurrence

questions.solution:
ER/PR status is not a prognostic factor for VNPI( Van Nuys Prognostic index).

 The Van Nuys Prognostic Index (VNPI) is thought to be a useful aid in deciding which patients are at increased risk of local recurrence and who may benefit from adjuvant radiotherapy (RT).

Prognostic factors are:

  • Patient's age
  • Tumour size
  • Margin width
  • Nuclear grade
  • Presence of microcalcification

Patients with a high score benefit from radiotherapy after excision,whereas those of low grade ,whose tumour is completely excised need no further treatment.

Scores range from a low of 4 (least likely to recur) to a high of 12 (most likely to recur).

Silverstein Van Nuy’s prognostic index for DCIS
Parameters Score 1 Score 2 Score 3
Size(mm) ≤15 16-40 ≥41
Margin(mm) ≥10 1 - 9 <1
Class Grade 1 or 2 without necrosis Grade 1 or 2 with necrosis Grade 3 with or without necrosis
Age(years) >60 40-60 <40
  • Scores 4-7 with >3mm margin : Excision alone 
  • Score 7 with < 3 mm margin, 8 with > 3mm margin, 9 with >5mm margin: Excision with RT
  • Score 9 with < 5mm margin & score 10,11,12: Mastectomy

questions.text: Identify the correct match :
questions.solution:
Incision marked as 1 is Kocher incision - a subcostal incision used to gain access for gall bladder and/or biliary tree pathology.

Incision marked 5 is Lanz incision, a transverse or skin crease incision for appendicitis, 2 cm below the umbilicus, centred on the midclavicular–midinguinal line. Due to its continuation with Langer’s lines, the Lanz incision produces much more aesthetically pleasing results with reduced scarring.

 

2 is midline incision - the most common incision for laparotomy, a vertical incision which follows the linea alba which are particularly favoured in diagnostic laparotomy, as they allow wide access to most of the abdominal cavity.

3 is McBurney's incision(also called gridiron incision) is an oblique incision(superolateral to inferomedial) passing along the McBurney's point. It is popularly used for open appendicectomy.

4 is battle incision a lower right paramedian incision but placed more laterally than the standard paramedian incision. It is suitable for dealing with acute appendicitis and pathologies in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen.

6 is paramedian incision - this incision runs 2-5 cm away from the midline used to access much of the lateral viscera, such as the kidneys, the spleen, and the adrenal glands.

7 is transverse incision - A supraumbilical transverse incision offers excellent exposure of the upper abdomen. A transverse incision may be superior to a midline incision in terms of recovery and complications postoperatively.

8 is Rutherford Morrison incision , an oblique muscle cutting incision used for access to sigmoid colon and pelvis in patients where the midline is scarred due to previous surgery.

9 is Pfannensteil incision - an infraumbilical transverse incision in the lower abdomen, often used for gynaecological and obstetric procedures.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about conditions required for acute radiation syndrome?

choices.text: Radiation dose must be large i.e greater than 70 rads.
The dose must be mostly internal.
Bone marrow suppression occurs earlier than neurovascular effects.
The dose must have been delivered in a short time.

questions.solution:
Acute radiation syndrome after deposition of radioactive materials inside the body is extremely rare. The dose must be external.

Acute radiation syndrome, also called radiation toxicity or radiation sickness, is an acute illness caused by irradiation of the entire body by a high dose of penetrating radiation in a very short period of time. The major cause of this syndrome is the depletion of immature parenchymal stem cells in specific tissues.

Stages of Acute Radiation Syndrome (ARS)

The prodromal phase: This phase is marked by non-specific symptoms like nausea, vomiting, and anorexia. Early and persistent symptoms predict severity.

Latent phase: The patient looks and feels generally healthy for a few hours or even up to a few weeks. In severe cases, this phase may be absent.

Manifest illness phase: Symptoms depend the radiation dose. Tissues with greater rates of cellular division are most radiosensitive, and hence the hematopoietic and gastrointestinal systems are the most affected.

Recovery phase or Death: The recovery phase is seen after the manifest stage when the patient recovers from the acute exposure. The time taken for recovery depends on the severity of the injury and the organ system affected. 

Syndrome    Dose Prodromal Stage  Latent Stage Manifest Illness Stage Recovery/Death
Hematopoietic (Bone marrow)  >0.7 Gy (>70 rads) (mild symptoms may occur at doses as low as 0.3 Gy or 30 rads) 

 

  • Symptoms are anorexia, nausea and vomiting.
  • Onset occurs 1 hour to 2 days after exposure.
  • Stage lasts for minutes to days.  
  • Stem cells in bone marrow are dying, although patient may appear and feel well.
  • Stage lasts 1 to 6 weeks. 

 

  • Symptoms are anorexia, fever, and malaise.
  • Drop in all blood cell counts occurs for several weeks.
  • Primary cause of death is infection and hemorrhage.
  • Survival decreases with increasing dose.
  • Most deaths occur within a few months after exposure.  

 

  • In most cases, bone marrow cells will begin to repopulate the marrow.
  • There should be full recovery for a large percentage of individuals from a few weeks up to two years after exposure.
  • Death may occur in some individuals at 1.2 Gy (120 rads).
  • The LD50/60 is about 2.5 to 5 Gy (250 to 500 rads). 
GIT >10 Gy (>1000 rads) (some symptoms may occur at doses as low as 6 Gy or 600 rads)

 

  • Symptoms are anorexia, severe nausea, vomiting, cramps, and diarrhea.
  • Onset occurs within a few hours after exposure.
  • Stage lasts about 2 days.
  • Stem cells in bone marrow and cells lining GI tract are dying, although patient may appear and feel well.
  • Stage lasts less than 1 week.

 

  • Symptoms are malaise, anorexia, severe diarrhea, fever, dehydration, and electrolyte imbalance.
  • Death is due to infection, dehydration, and electrolyte imbalance.
  • Death occurs within 2 weeks of exposure.
 The LD100 is about 10 Gy (1000 rads).
CVS/CNS >50 Gy (>5000 rads) (some symptoms may occur at doses as low as 20 Gy or 2000 rads)

 

  • Symptoms are extreme nervousness and confusion; severe nausea, vomiting, and watery diarrhea; loss of consciousness; and burning sensations of the skin.
  • Onset occurs within minutes of exposure.
  • Stage lasts for minutes to hours.
  • Patient may return to partial functionality.
  • Stage may last for hours but often is less.

 

  • Symptoms are return of watery diarrhea, convulsions, and coma.
  • Onset occurs 5 to 6 hours after exposure.
  • Death occurs within 3 days of exposure.
 No recovery is expected.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presented with a 7-day history of a generalized pruritic rash, which started around the neck, without a history of cough, fever, or rhinorrhea. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows a large number of minute thin-walled vesicles on the trunk, consistent with a diagnosis of miliaria.

Other options:

Option A: Folliculitis would involve specific inflammation in the pilosebaceous units.

Option B:  Infantile acne would have characteristic comedones, papules, and pustules. Moreover, the question states the boy is 4 years old. 

Option D: Candidal infections usually occur as macerated erythematous lesions in the intertriginous areas.  

Note: Milia, conversely, are tiny keratin‐filled, epithelial‐lined cysts that are not connected to the overlying skin.

Related Pearl: Different types of miliaria

Miliaria is a common acute or subacute skin condition that arises due to the occlusion or disruption of eccrine sweat ducts in hot humid conditions.

Based on the level of blockade it is differentiated into

  • Miliaria Crystallina- Stratum corneum
  • Miliaria Rubra - Malpighian Layer
  • Miliaria profunda - Dermoepidermal junction

Pathophysiology:

  • The first event may be an increase in the skin flora, perhaps with Staphylococcus epidermidis being responsible for producing an extracellular polysaccharide substance or slime that blocks the lumen of the sweat duct.
  • The parakeratotic plugs, a notable feature of the later stages of the disease, are not the primary cause of the obstruction but arise in the repair process, and further aggravate the obstruction.
  • Leakage of sweat into the epidermis is responsible for the final production of the lesions, and for their further aggravation.
  • Miliaria crystallina occurs commonly in infants due to a delay in the development of patency in the sweat ducts.

Clinical features:

  • Miliaria crystallina: Clear, thin‐walled vesicles, 1–2 mm in diameter without an inflammatory areola, are usually symptomless and develop in crops, mainly on the trunk. In persistent febrile illnesses, recurrent crops may occur. The vesicles soon rupture and are followed by superficial, branny desquamation.

 

  • Miliaria rubra: Typical lesions develop on the body, especially in areas of friction with clothing, and in flexures. The lesions are uniformly minute erythematous papules, which may be present in very large numbers. Characteristically, the lesions produce intense discomfort in the form of an unbearable pricking sensation. Relief is often instantaneous when the stimulus to sweating is abolished by a cool shower. In infants, lesions commonly appear on the occluded skin of the neck, groins and axillae, but also occur elsewhere.

 

 

  • Miliaria profunda: This nearly always follows repeated attacks of miliaria rubra, and is common only in the tropics. The lesions are easily missed. The affected skin is covered with pale, firm papules 1–3 mm across, especially on the body, but sometimes also on the limbs. There is no itching or discomfort from the lesions.

 

Treatment:

  • First line
    • Control local environment (remove excess bedding, fans, air
    conditioning)
    • Cool the skin (damp compresses, cool showers)
    • Avoid tight or excessive clothing
  • Second line
    • Menthol (e.g. 0.5% menthol in aqueous cream)
    • Topical antibiotics if there is secondary infection
    • Mild topical steroids
  • Third line
    • Removal to cooler climate
    • Prophylactic oral vitamin C

questions.text: Cyclosporine is produced by the fungus
questions.solution:
Cyclosporine is a cyclic polypeptide, that inhibits calcineurin activity and is produced by the fungus Beauveria nivea.

Tacrolimus is a macrolide antibiotic produced by Streptomyces tsukubaensis.

Sirolimus (rapamycin) is a macrocyclic lactone produced by Streptomyces hygroscopicus.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is currently approved for the treatment of small pox?
questions.solution:
Tecovirimat has been recently approved as a treatment of smallpox.

It was approved under the FDA's animal rule, which allows findings from animal studies to support an FDA approval when it is not feasible or ethical to conduct efficacy trials in humans. Cidofovir has also been approved by the FDA for smallpox under this rule.

Both these drugs are currently stockpiled by CDC’s strategic national stockpile, which has the medical supplies required to protect the public in case of a public health emergency.

Tecovirimat could also be used under an investigational new drug (IND) protocol to treat adverse reactions from vaccinia vaccination.

Option B: Lumacaftor is a drug approved for cystic fibrosis.

Option C: Pegvaliase has been approved for the treatment of phenylketonuria in adults.

Option D: Apalutamide is a nonsteroidal antiandrogen medication which is used in the treatment of prostate cancer. It is specifically indicated for use in conjunction with castration in the treatment of non-metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following represents the frequency of continuous variables?
questions.solution:
A histogram represents  frequency of continuous variables.

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following image shows a histogram.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about biotransformation?

choices.text: Phase I reactions unmask a functional group
Phase II reactions may precede phase I reactions
Biotransformation of drugs occurs primarily in the liver
Flavin containing monooxygenases are a part of phase 2 enzymes

questions.solution:
Flavin containing monooxygenases (FMO) are a part of Phase 1 oxidation reactions. Others are carried out by Cytochrome P450s, , aand Epoxide hydrolases(EH).

 Phase I reactions usually convert the parent drug to a more polar metabolite by introducing or unmasking/ adding a functional group such as –OH, –COOH, –SH, –O–, or NH2. Reactions carried out by phase 1 enzymes usually lead to the inactivation of a drug/activation of the drug.

Majority of the drugs undergo these biotransformation reactions in a sequential manner. However, rarely Phase II reactions may precede phase I reaction.

The biotransformation of drugs occurs primarily in the liver. Other organs with significant drug-metabolizing capacity include the GI tract, kidneys, and lungs.

questions.text: Which of the following is not correctly paired?
questions.solution:
Synapses allow conduction in one direction, so an Antidromic conduction would die out. Antidromic conduction occurs along axon away from axon terminal and towards the soma. It is the opposite of normal direction(orthodromic) of conduction.

Orthograde transport occurs along microtubules that run along the axon and require two molecular motors: dynein and kinesin.

It moves from the cell body toward the axon terminals and has both fast (400 mm/day) and slow (0.5–10 mm/day) components.

Nerve growth factors are transported from axon terminal to soma (Retrograde transport).

questions.text: Which of the following types of morbidly adherent placenta is shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
The given image shows placenta increta. 

Morbidly adherent placenta occurs due to the partial or total absence of the decidua basalis and imperfect development of the fibrinoid or Nitabuch layer. It is of three types:

  • Placenta accreta - villi are attached to the myometrium.
  • Placenta increta - villi invade deep into the myometrium.
  • Placenta percreta - villi penetrate through the entire myometrium and to or through the serosa. 

Based on the adherence of placental lobules, all three types of morbidly adherent placenta can be:

  • Total - involving all lobules of the placenta 
  • Focal - involving a single lobule or part of a lobule of the placenta

Morbidly adherent placenta can lead to torrential post-partum hemorrhage. It is managed via C-section and peripartum hysterectomy.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in trauma and injury severity score:
questions.solution:
Energy that caused the injury is not included in Trauma and injury revised score.

Trauma and injury revised score combines (TRISS):

  • Injury Severity Score (ISS)
  • Revised Trauma Score (RTS)
  • Age
  • Mechanism of Injury (blunt / penetrating)

Trauma scoring : Various scoring systems are used to score the trauma including:

  • AIS – Abbreviated Injury Scale
  • ISS – Injury Severity Score
  • OIS – Organ Injury Scale
  • GCS – Glasgow Coma Scale
  • RTS – Revised Trauma Score
  • MESS – Mangled Extremity Severity Score
  • TRISS – Trauma and Injury Severity Score

Related Pearl: Trauma Scoring Systems

Revised Trauma Score  - Total score 0-12 :

  • Glasgow coma scale
  • Respiratory rate
  • Systolic BP

Glasgow coma scale  - Total score 3-15 :

  • Eye-opening
  • Verbal response
  • Motor response

Abbreviated Injury Scale: AIS severity code – 1(minimal severity) to 6 (presumably fatal)

Injury Severity Score – Total score 1 to 75. Calculated summing the squares of the AIS severity codes for the three most severely injured body regions

Score Severity of injury
3-8 Minor
9-16 Moderate
16-24 Serious
>25 Severe/ Critical

  

Mangled Extremity Severity score: Mnemonic - ELiSA

  • Energy that caused the injury, skeletal and soft tissue injury
  • Limb ischemia
  • Shock
  • Patient’s age

TRISS (Trauma and Injury Severity Score) : Mnemonic - IRMA

  • Injury Severity Score
  • Revised Trauma Score
  • Mechanism of Injury (blunt/penetrating)
  • Age

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of double vision occasionally. On examination, it is noticed that the patient’s right eye is capable of abduction but not adduction. The left eye however is not capable of either abduction or adduction. Where would you expect the brain lesion to be present?
questions.solution:
The given description is that of One and a half syndrome.
The pathologic lesion is in the left dorsal pontine tegmentum which involves both ipsilateral PPRF (or the abducens nucleus) and the ipsilateral Median longitudinal fasciculus. This causes the paralysis of abduction and adduction on the left side, and only paralysis of adduction on the right.

questions.text: Drug used in endometriosis is_______
questions.solution:
Combined oral contraceptives, letrozole, mifepristone are all used in management of endometriosis.

Medical management of endometriosis:

  • Combined oral contraceptives: Administered intermittently or continuously, these pills may alleviate the disease.
  • Oral progesterones: Exert anti-oestrogenic effect and their continuous administration causes decidualization and endometrial atrophy.
  • Danazol: inhibits pituitary gonadotropins.
  • GnRH analogues: Downregulate and suppress pituitary gonadotropins.
  • Aromatase inhibitors (letrozole): Anti-oestrogenic effect.
  • Anti-progestin (mifepristone)

Related Pearl: Endometriosis

Sites of Endometriosis:

  • Pelvic endometriosis: Pelvic peritoneum, the pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligament.
  • Rectovaginal endometriosis.
  • Ovarian endometriosis.
  • Chocolate cyst of the ovary.
  • Other sites—appendix, pelvic lymph nodes.
  • Metastatic— lungs, umbilicus, scar endometriosis.

One pathology review revealed that endometriosis has been identified on all organs except the spleen.

Examination findings in endometriosis:

  • Abdomen: Cystic swelling, fixed and tender.
  • Pelvis: Cystic tender mass.
  • Vaginal examination: Fixed, tender, retroverted uterus. Tenderness in the lateral fornices (indicative of endometriosis even if no mass).
    • Speculum inspection of the Posterior fornix: Bluish/blackish puckered spots on speculum, tender to touch. The presence of puckered spots is pathognomonic of endometriosis.
    • Posterior Fornix Palpation: Uterosacral ligaments & pouch of Douglas feel thickened and shotty with multiple small palpable nodules. This is called the cobblestone feel of uterosacral ligaments.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in munchausen syndrome?
questions.solution:
Antisocial personality is not seen in munchausen syndrome (factitious disorder). However, antisocial personality might simulate munchausen syndrome.

Antisocial personality disorder:

  • Similarities with munchausen syndrome: Pathological lying, lack of close relationships with others, hostile and manipulative manner, and associated substance abuse and criminal history.
  • Differences with munchausen syndrome: Antisocial persons, however, do not usually volunteer for invasive procedures or resort to repeated or long-term hospitalization.

Note: Antisocial personality is seen in malingering(pretend to be ill in order to escape duty or work).

Other options:

  • Munchausen syndrome features peregrination or frequent wide-ranging travel to seek medical care.
  • Patients with Munchausen syndrome often insist on surgery and claim adhesions from previous surgical procedures. They may acquire a gridiron or washboard-like abdomen from multiple procedures.
  • Patients with Munchausen syndrome (Factitious disorder) demonstrate pseudologia fantastica, a specific syndrome of autobiographical lying.

questions.text: Virulence of a disease is indicated by:

choices.text: Amount of GDP spent on control of disease

questions.solution:
Virulence of a disease is indicated by case fatality rate.

Related Pearl: Case Fatality Rate

  • Case fatality rate =  (Total number of deaths due to a particular disease)/(Total number of cases due to the same disease)x 100
  • It is a good indicator of severity or killing power of a disease.
  • It is used mostly in acute and infectious diseases.
  • No time interval is used.
  • Case fatality rate is closely related to virulence.
  • Limitation of CFR is that its usefulness for chronic diseases is limited because the period from onset to death is variable.
  • It is expressed in percentage.
  • CFR is an incidence proportion and not a true rate.
  • CFR may vary for the same disease in different epidemics.

  • Case fatality of a few diseases:

    • Rabies - 100% especially after symptoms manifest
    • Ebola - 25 to 90%, average - 50% 
    • Yellow fever - 15 to 50%
    • Chicken pox - 0.001%
  • Diseases with a high case fatality rate: Tetanus, Rabies, Botulism, Ebola.
  • Diseases with a low case fatality rate: Leprosy, Trachoma, Lymphatic filariasis.

Related Pearl: Mortality and morbidity indicators in epidemiology

Mortality Indicators

Morbidity Indicators

Universal indicators:

  • Crude death rate
  • Life expectancy
  • Age-specific death rates
  • Disease-specific mortality rate
  • Proportional mortality rate
  • Case fatality rate
  • Years of potential life lost
  • Adult mortality rate

Maternal and child-related indicators:

  • Infant mortality rate
  • Child death rate
  • Under-5 proportionate mortality rate
  • Maternal mortality rate
  • Incidence and Prevalence
  • Notification rates
  • Attendance rates at OPD
  • Admission, discharge & re-admission rates
  • Duration of stay in hospital
  • Spells of sickness or absence from work or school

questions.text: A patient told his doctor that he had gone to see an Indo- Pak cricket match in Sharjah last week. While in reality he had seen this match 20 years ago. This phenomenon can be seen in cases of __________
questions.solution:
The phenomenon is confabulation. This can be seen in cases of korsokoff’s psychosis, senile dementia, schizophrenia and syphilis.

Confabulation is a phenomenon in which the patient fills in memory gaps with inaccurate information. Further investigating the statement made by the patients may reflect past experiences or bizarre, fantastic stories.  This fabrication of false information is not done on purpose.

questions.text: Incidence rate of lung cancer among smokers is 10 per 1000 and among non-smokers is 1 per 1000. In this context which of the following is false?

choices.text: Incidence of lung cancer in smokers is 10 times higher than in non-smokers
If smoking is eliminated then there will be  90% reduction in the incidence of lung cancer
90% of lung cancer can be attributed to smoking

questions.solution:
If smoking is eliminated then there will be 91% (and not 90%) reduction in the incidence of lung cancer. This is evident from the population attributable risk which will be 91% approximately.

In the given data:

  • Incidence among exposed (Iexp) = 10/1000
  • Incidence among non-exposed (Inon-exp) = 1/1000

Therefore,

Incidence total (Itot)= 11/1000

Option A:

  • Relative risk (RR): Incidence among exposed / incidence among non-exposed
  • RR = Iexp / Inon-exp = 10

Interpretation: Incidence of lung cancer (disease) in smokers is 10 times higher than in non-smokers (non-exposed).

Option B:

  • Population attributable risk (PAR): Difference between total incidence and incidence among non-exposed /  Total Incidence X 100.
  • PAR = (Itot- Inonexp) / Itot X 100= (11-1) / 11 X 100

  = 10/11 X100

  = 90.90 ≅ 91%

Interpretation: If smoking is eliminated then there will be 91% reduction in the incidence of lung cancer.

Option C:

  • Attributable risk (AR): Difference between incidence among exposed and incidence among non-exposed / incidence among exposed X 100
  • AR= (Iexp- Inonexp)/ Iexp X 100= 10-1/10 X 100 = 90%

Interpretation: 90% of lung cancer can be attributed to smoking.

questions.text: Your sister tells you that your nephew has now started using his crayons. He easily copies circles, but still has trouble with squares. Other than a minor ASD noted incidentally at birth, he is a perfectly healthy child. Which of the following would you expect him to be able to do at this stage?
questions.solution:
Normally, a child is able to copy a circle at 3 years and a square at 4 years. This child is a 3-year-old, and he should be able to know his name and gender.

  • A child is able to tell a story at 4 years.
  • Asks meaning of words at 5 years.
  • A child can skip at 5 years.
