questions.text: A 40-year-old patient complains of palpitations. He is hemodynamically stable. An ECG is obtained and is given below. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows wide complex tachycardia (QRS complexes are >120 ms in duration), with regular QRS complexes with uniform morphology in each lead. This is suggestive of ventricular tachycardia (VT). Since this patient is hemodynamically stable, the best management is IV amiodarone. 

In patients with sustained VT who are hemodynamically stable, medical treatment with intravenous amiodarone is preferred. Alternative drugs that can be given are lignocaine and procainamide. However, if the VT fails to resolve with medical management or if the patient's symptoms worsen, DC cardioversion is the next step. 

Other options:

Option A: Carotid massage has no role in the management of VT. It is used as an initial step in paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia to block the AV node and terminate the arrhythmia.

Option B: Chest compressions are done until the defibrillator is arranged to ensure some amount of cardiac output even during this period.

Option C: If a patient with VT has hemodynamic compromise due to hypotension or impaired consciousness or has pulmonary, electrical cardioversion is performed.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an advantage for employers under ESI act?

choices.text: Rebate under Income Tax Act on contribution deposited in ESI scheme
Exemption from payment of medical allowance to employees and their dependants or arranging for their medical care

questions.solution:
Under the ESI Act, employers do not get exemption from sales tax.

Related Pearl: ESI ACT, 1948

Employees State Insurance Act, 1948 (Revised in 2019)

Scope: It is applicable to all factories in India excluding:

  • Defence 
  • Railway  
  • Mines 

Finance Contribution

  • It covers all employees getting income up to Rs.21,000/- per month.
  • Employee – 0.75% of his daily wage.
  • Employer – 3.25% of the employees' daily wage.
  • Medical benefit – 1/8th by the state government and 7/8th by the ESI Corporation.

Benefits

To the Employees

  • Medical Benefit- full medical care is provided free of cost in case of sickness, employment injury, and maternity.
  • Sickness Benefit- is given at 70% of average daily wages for a duration of 91 days in one year. In order to qualify for sickness benefit, the worker is required to contribute for 78 days in a period of 6 months.
    • Extended sickness benefit – 80% of the daily wages for a duration of 2 years, for 34 specified diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseases, diabetes, Parkinson's, myasthenia gravis, glaucoma, coronary artery disease, etc.
    • Enhanced sickness benefit – at full wages for sterilization procedure; for a duration of 7 days post-vasectomy and 14 days post tubectomy. 
    • The total amount payable is double the standard sickness benefit rate, that is, equal to full wages.
  • Maternity Benefit – benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage, and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy. It also covers the premature birth of a child born to an insured woman.
  • Dependance Benefit– in case of death, as a result of employment injury, the dependents of an insured person are eligible for periodical payments. Pension at the rate of 90% of the wages is payable, shared by dependants in a fixed ratio, on monthly basis in accordance with the prescribed share. An eligible son or daughter is entitled to the dependant's benefit up to the age of 18; the benefit is withdrawn if the daughter marries earlier.
  • Disablement Benefits–
    • Temporary disability- at 90% daily wages as long as the person is disabled.
    • Permanent disability- lifetime pension. It also covers occupational diseases.
  • Funeral Benefit – a maximum of Rs.15,000/-.
  • Rehabilitation Benefit- on payment of Rs.10, the insured person and his/her family continue to get medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement.

To the Employers

  • Exemption from Workman Compensation Act.
  • Exemption from Maternity Benefit Act.
  • Income tax rebate on the amount contributed towards the scheme.
  • Exemption from payment of medical allowance to employees and their dependants, or arranging for their medical care.
  • Healthy-work force.

questions.text: Causes of precocious puberty in girls are all except:
questions.solution:
In Prader Willi syndrome, there is hypogonadism and hence sexual development is delayed.

Other options:

  • Hypothalamic hamartomas that secrete excess gonadotropins-releasing hormone are responsible for a significant proportion of cases of precocious puberty.
  • McCune-Albright syndrome is a cause of peripheral precocious puberty, where cutaneous pigmentation and fibrous dysplasia of the skeletal system are also seen.
  • In hypothyroidism, though puberty is delayed in adolescents, pseudo-precocious puberty may be seen in younger children as a result of abnormally high TSH concentrations binding to FSH receptors with subsequent stimulation.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs does not cause or exacerbate acne?
questions.solution: Adapalene is a 3rd generation retinoid which does not cause acne. Rather, it is used in the treatment of mild to moderate acne, especially when comedones are predominant.

questions.text: Which of the following findings on a fundus examination would suggest severe non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy?

choices.text: Significant venous beading in any of the 4 quadrants

questions.solution:
Severe hemorrhages in all 4 quadrants is a feature of severe NPDR.

Note: Macular star is a feature of malignant hypertensive retinopathy.

Related Pearl: Early treatment diabetic retinopathy study (ETDRS) classification

Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR):

  • Mild NPDR
    • At least one microaneurysm must be present
  • Moderate NPDR
    • Microaneurysms/intraretinal hemorrhage in 2 or 3 quadrants
    • Early mild intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA)
    • Hard exudates and cotton-wool spots may or may not be present
  • Severe NPDR - any one of the following (4-2-1 rule)
    • 4 quadrants of microaneurysms and extensive intraretinal hemorrhages
    • 2 quadrants of venous beading
    • 1 quadrant of IRMA changes
  • Very severe NPDR - any two of the following (4-2-1)
    • 4 quadrants of microaneurysms and extensive intraretinal hemorrhages
    • 2 quadrants of venous beading
    • 1 quadrant of IRMA changes

Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR):

  • PDR without high-risk characteristics (Early PDR)
    • Early neovascularization at the optic disc (NVD) or neovascularization elsewhere (NVE)
  • PDR with high-risk characteristics as follows
    • NVD < 1/4 disc area with vitreous hemorrhage (VH) or preretinal hemorrhage (PRH)
    • NVD 1/4 to 1/3 of disc area with or without VH or PRH
    • NVE > 1/2 disc area with VH or PRH

Clinically significant macular edema: 1 of the following 3 criteria are present on slit-lamp examination with 90D lens

  • Thickening of the retina at or within 500 micron of the center of the fovea.
  • Hard exudates at or within 500 micron of the centre of fovea associated with adjacent retinal thickening.
  • Development of a zone of retinal thickening one disc diameter or larger in size. At least a part of this should be within one disc diameter of the foveal center.

Advanced diabetic eye disease:

  • Persistent vitreous hemorrhage
  • Tractional retinal detachment
  • Neovascular glaucoma

questions.text: A 40 yr old lady presents with large left parietal convexity meningioma with perilesional edema. She is scheduled for surgery the next day .A senior neurosurgeon asks a house surgeon to write the pre operative  notes for the lady. Which of the following pre op note is wrong?
questions.solution:
Perilesional oedema or vasogenic oedema responds to steroids thus lowering intracranial pressure. Therefore steroids are to be continued and morning dose has to be taken.

  8. Anticonvulsants

  10. Steroids (oral and inhaled)
  11. Statins
  12. Levodopa
  13. Mono Amine Oxidase inhibitors are continued when:(1) Anesthesiologist is comfortable with use of MAO-safe procedures (2) Possibility of exacerbation or precipitation of depressive syndrome.

questions.text: Periodic Acid Schiff staining shown in the image given below is seen with _____________
questions.solution:
The image shows block like or dot like PAS positivity which is seen with lymphoblast in ALL. 

Diffuse PAS positivity is shown by erythroblasts in AML-M6.

questions.text: Reed Sternberg cell morphology is pathognomonic of ___________
questions.solution:
Reed Sternberg cell morphology is not pathognomonic of any condition since they are seen in many conditions such as:

  • Hodgkin’s lymphoma
  • Non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma (commonly in immunoblastic type)
  • Infectious mononucleosis
  • Follicular lymphoma

A feature is called pathognomonic when that particular feature is so specific to or distinctly characteristic of a disease that it makes the diagnosis.

Note: The diagnosis of Hodgkin lymphoma depends on the identification of Reed- Sternberg cells in a background of non-neoplastic inflammatory cells.

Reed Sternberg cell: It is a giant cell. It has a classic owl-eyed appearance due to the presence of a symmetric or mirror-image bilobed nucleus with prominent nucleoli surrounded by a clear space.

Related Pearl: Important Features of the Different Types of Hodgkin's Lymphoma (HL)

Classic subtypes

  • Nodular sclerosis 
  • Mixed cellularity 
  • Lymphocyte-rich
  • Lymphocyte depletion

Non-Classical subtype

  • Lymphocyte predominant

Note: Mixed cellularity is most commonly associated with HIV due to its high incidence.

questions.text: Which of the following drug is part of behavioural modification technique for alcohol de addiction?
questions.solution:
Disulfiram is used in behavioural modification technique for alcohol de addiction. Principle of action is aversive conditioning.  After giving the drug, if the patient takes alcohol he will experience untoward side effects such as nausea, vomiting, rashes autonomic manifestations, etc.

Other modalities of treatment:

  • Pharmacotherapy: Typically 5-10 days, treatment for detoxification: Benzodiazepine and chlordiazepoxide are the drugs of choice.
  • Rehabilitation programs: Typically 28-day programs, learn about relapse prevention and identification of triggers.
  • Maintenance phase: Baclofen, Acamprosate, Naltrexone, Topiramate, SSRI, Ondansetron
  • Psychotherapy: Group therapy such as Alcoholics Anonymous

questions.text: MRI rooms are shielded completely by a continuous sheet or wire mesh of copper or aluminium to shield the imager from external electromagnetic radiations. This is called as
questions.solution:
Faraday cage is a conductive box used to shield out stray electromagnetic interference. Virtually any type of metal can be used, including aluminum and galvanized steel. However, it most commonly consists of wood panels wrapped with copper. It serves two functions:

1) to prevent extraneous electromagnetic radiation from contaminating/distorting the MR signal, and

2) to prevent electromagnetic radiation generated by the MR scanner from causing interference in nearby medical devices.

questions.text: The maximum contractile force of any muscle per square cm cross-sectional area is _____
questions.solution:
The strength of a muscle is determined mainly by its size, with a maximal contractile force between 3 and 4 kg/cm2 of muscle cross-sectional area.

  • The female muscle can achieve almost exactly the same maximal force of contraction as that of the male muscle per square centimeter of cross-sectional area.
  • Most of the difference in total muscle performance between males and females lies in the extra percentage of the male body that is muscle, which is caused partly by endocrine differences:
    • Testosterone secreted by the male testes has a powerful anabolic effect in causing greatly increased deposition of protein in the muscles.
    • Estrogen increases the deposition of fat in the female, especially in the breasts, hips, and subcutaneous tissue.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the condition given below?

choices.text: Two forms of the disease are recognized: bullous and non-bullous
This can occur from either streptococcal or staphylococcal infection
Oral antibiotics are more effective than topical antibiotics
Disease is self-limiting and resolves with antibiotics and skin cleansers

questions.solution:
The given image is suggestive of Impetigo.

Oral antibiotics and topical antibiotics are equally effective in mild-moderate disease.

If the infection is widespread or severe, or is accompanied by lymphadenopathy, then an oral antibiotic such as flucloxacillin or erythromycin is indicated. Topical retapamulin, a relatively new topical antibiotic is also effective in treating impetigo.

questions.text: True about the device given below is:

choices.text: Holding period of 160 degree Celsius for 2 hours
Spores of Clostridium tetani act as control

questions.solution:
The above image shows the autoclave machine. It is a method of sterilization by moist heat.

Autoclave machine:

  • High penetrative power
  • Temperature - 1210C for 15 min
  • Spores of Bacillus stearothermophilus acts as a control.

 Hot air oven:

It is a method of sterilization by dry heat.

  • Holding period of 1600C for 2 hours is used to sterilize glassware, swabs, glass syringes, scalpel, forceps, scissors.
  • Cutting instruments in ophthalmic surgery – 2 hours at 1500C.
  • Spores of Clostridium tetani act as a control.

questions.text: A child presented with a swelling in the right groin region. When  the swelling was reduced, a  gurgling sound was heard . Which of the following is an incorrect statement?

choices.text: The hernia lies above and medial to pubic tubercle
This type of hernia is most common in children

questions.solution:
Sac contains omentum only is the incorrect statement.

Contents of hernia:

omentocele :omentum is doughy. The last portion is more difficult to reduce than the first.

Enterocele: gurgles on reduction. First portion is more difficult to reduce than the last.

Most hernias that are present at birth or in childhood are indirect inguinal hernias. Inguinal hernia is a type of ventral hernia that occurs when an intra-abdominal structure, such as bowel or omentum, protrudes through a defect in the abdominal wall. 

The processus vaginalis is an outpouching of peritoneum attached to the testicle that trails behind as it descends retroperitoneally into the scrotum. When obliteration of the processus vaginalis fails to occur, inguinal hernia results.

questions.text: A dead body recovered from a river showed washerwoman’s skin appearance. The body must have been immersed in water for _______
questions.solution:
The body of the person must have been immersed in water for few hours to 3days. The washerman’s skin is seen in after few hours upto 3 days after death.

Washerwoman’s skin: The first signs tend to be on areas with an appreciable keratin layer (such as the fingertips palms, backs of the hands and later the soles) where the surface becomes wrinkled, pale and sodden. This is called washer-woman’s skin. The first site affected are the fingerpads. It affects the hands earlier than the feet.

Estimation of duration of immersion - When a body falls into water in average temperate climates, the following is an approximate guide to timing:

Finding Time since immersion
No wrinkling of finger pads Less than a few hours
Wrinkled fingers, palms and feet Few hours to 3 days
Early decomposition (Head and abdomen) 4-10 days
Marbling of veins, peeling of epidermis 2-4 weeks
Muscle loss with bone exposure 1-2 months

Note: Signs of immersion just indicate that the body was immersed in water, they are not evidence of death from drowning.

questions.text: CD 62 was found to be the CD marker of a molecule. Function of this molecule must be _________
questions.solution:
CD 62 is a marker of selectins. Selectins are involved in initial rolling interaction of leucocytes and endothelium.

questions.text: Risk of tubal pregnancy is increased by all except?
questions.solution:
Oral combined pill use does not increase the risk of ectopic pregnancy. In fact, combined pills reduce the risk of ectopic pregnancy.

Risk factors of ectopic pregnancy:

  • Previous ectopic pregnancy
  • Tubal corrective surgery, tubectomy
  • IUCD
  • Assisted reproductive technology
  • Documented tubal pathology
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease (Chlamydia infection and salpingitis isthmica nodosa)
  • Genital tuberculosis
  • Endometriosis
  • Pelvic adhesions
  • Congenital elongation, accessory ostia, diverticula
  • Transmigration
  • Smoking
  • Prior abortion
  • Multiple sexual partners
  • Prior Caesarean delivery
  • Progesterone-only pills (POPs)

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient has to undergo incisional hernia surgery under general anesthesia. She complains of awareness in her past caesarean section. Which of the following monitoring techniques can be used to prevent such awareness?
questions.solution:
The monitoring technique used to prevent such an awareness intraoperatively is the bispectral index. 

The bispectral index is a monitoring technique to check the depth of anesthesia using an algorithm by a device. Individual intraoperative awareness is evaluated. It utilizes parameters like EEG signals, eye blinking, etc. 

BIS examines four components within the EEG that are associated with the anesthetic state.

  1. Low-frequency waves (as found during deep anesthesia)
  2. High-frequency beta activation (as found during light anesthesia)
  3. Suppressed EEG waves
  4. Burst suppression

It has numerical values from 0 to 100. with 0 representing isoelectric EEG and 100 being awake CNS. Recommended range of Bispectral index (BIS) for anesthesia: 40-60.

 BIS 
value		    Interpretation
     80-100    Awake
     60-80   Moderate sedation
     40-60 General anesthesia
      <40  Deep hypnosis
0  Coma (Flatline coma)

questions.text: What is the Nernst potential for K+ in milivolt (mV)?
questions.solution:
The Nernst potential for K+ is −90mV.

Note:

  • For K+ ions, the concentration gradient is directed outward and the electrical gradient is directed inward.
  • In general, all excitable cell membranes at rest are maximally permeable to K+ and thus their RMP is close to equilibrium potential of K+ ion.

questions.text: Obsessive compulsive personality is included in personality disorder cluster ____________
questions.solution:
Obsessive compulsive personality is included in personality disorder cluster C.

Obsessive compulsive personality disorder is characterized by a pervasive pattern of preoccupation with orderliness, perfectionism, and mental and interpersonal control, at the expense of flexibility, openness, and efficiency.

Note: Obsessive compulsive personality disorder and obsessive compulsive disorder are 2 separate entities.

Schizotypal
Eccentric & odd thoughts, perceptions & behavior, magical thinking and beliefs

Cluster B (Dramatic, Emotional and Erratic)
Antisocial
Disregard for and violation of rights of others, illegal activities
Borderline
Chaotic relationships, sensitivity to abandonment, labile mood, impulsivity, inner emptiness, self-harm
Histrionic
Dramatic, superficial, attention-seeking
Narcissistic
Grandiosity, lack of empathy

Cluster C (Anxious, Fearful, Introvert)
Avoidant
Avoidance due to fears of criticism and rejection
Dependent
Submissive, clingy, needs to be taken care of
Obsessive-compulsive/
Anankastic
 
Rigid, controlling, perfectionist

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can be safely used in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Glatiramer acetate has the best safety profile for pregnant women with mild Multiple Sclerosis.

Terifluomide has a risk of teratogenicity.

Both the above drugs are approved therapies for multiple sclerosis.

Miltefosine is highly curative against visceral, cutaneous and mucocutaneous forms of the disease. A major drawback is its teratogencity.

Bosetan is an endothelin receptor antagonist which is used as a first line therapy for moderate PAH. It is also a teratogenic drug.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child was brought with complaints of bedwetting at night. There is no history of bedwetting during day time. His urine examination was normal. Specific gravity was 1.020. What would be your advice?
questions.solution:
According to the given history, the child had nocturnal enuresis with normal findings on urine examination and hence consulting a child psychologist is the most appropriate option.

Nocturnal enuresis:

  • It refers to the occurrence of involuntary voiding at night after 5 years of age.
  • If no daytime symptoms and physical and urine examination are normal, then further evaluation for urinary tract pathology is not warranted.
  • An USG is done in an older child (usually >7 years) with enuresis or in those who do not respond to therapy.
  • Active treatment should be avoided in children younger than 6 years of age.
  • Psychological therapy includes motivational therapy (star charts), Conditioning therapy (auditory or vibratory alarms) and self-hypnosis. It helps the child to deal with enuresis psychologically and motivate the child to void at night if he wakes up with a full bladder.
  • Pharmacological therapy ( imipramine and desmopressin) is intended to treat the symptoms of enuresis and thus is regarded as second line and is not curative. Desmopressin tablet with a dosage of 0.2-0.6 mg at bed time can be given.

questions.text: Most common Hodgkin’s lymphoma in India is ____________
questions.solution:
Mixed cellularity is the most common Hodgkin’s lymphoma in India whereas nodular sclerosis is the most common Hodgkin’s lymphoma in the world.

Most common hodgkin’s lymphoma in:

  • Females: Nodular Sclerosis (However, overall Hodgkin's lymphoma is more common in males)
  • EBV associated: Lymphocyte depleted (EBV association 90%)
  • In HIV patients: Mixed cellularity (EBV association 70%)

Note:

  • In WHO classification of hematolymphoid tumors, it is given as follows - Mixed cellularity subtype is more frequent in patients with HIV infection but lymphocyte depleted, a rare subtype is often associated with HIV infection.
  • In Robbins and cotrans pathology of diseases 9th edition page 609, It is mentioned as lymphocyte depletion subtype is associated with HIV individuals of any age.
  • In Harrisons text book of medicine 19th ed, it is mentioned that patients infected with HIV more commonly have mixed-cellularity Hodgkin’s lymphoma or lymphocyte-depleted Hodgkin’s lymphoma.
  • Mixed Cellularity is the most common associated with HIV due to its high incidence. But, Hodgkin Lymphoma with strongest association is Lymphocyte Depleted. Williams Hematology clearly mentions, "Cases of cHL* developing in the setting of HIV typically exhibit the lymphocyte-depleted morphology" *(Classical Hodgkin Lymphoma).

questions.text: All of the following muscles are innervated by the nerve marked "? "in the image except _______
questions.solution:
The nerve marked “?” in the image is posterior interosseous nerve. Deep branch of radial nerve after penetrating supinator is called posterior interosseous nerve. It innervates all extrinsic wrist extensors except ECRL.

ECRL is supplied by the radial nerve (C6, C7) before its division into superficial and deep branches in the lateral wall of cubital fossa.

 

Radial nerve before division (C5,C6)
  • Brachioradialis
  • Extensor carpi radialis longus (ECRL)

Radial nerve deep branch before penetrating supinator (C7,C8)
  • Extensor carpi radialis brevis (ECRB)

Posterior interosseous nerve (C7,C8)
  • Superficial
    • Extensor digitorum
    • Extensor digiti minimi(EDM)
    • Extensor carpi ulnaris (ECU)
  • Deep
    • Supinator
    • Abductor pollicis longus (APL)
    • Extensor pollicis brevis (EPB)
    • Extensor pollicis longus (EPL)
    • Extensor indicis

Radial nerve

(C6,C7,C8)
  • Anconeus

questions.text: Match the following DNA repair defect with disease condition.
questions.solution:
Correct match is:

  • Mismatch repair - HNPCC syndrome
  • Nucleotide excision repair – Xeroderma pigmentosum
  • Recombinant DNA repair – Bloom syndrome

Defects in three types of DNA-repair systems:

  • Mismatch repair: Patients with HNPCC syndrome have defects in the mismatch repair system, leading to the development of carcinomas of the colon. These patients’ genomes show microsatellite instability.
  • Nucleotide excision repair: Patients with Xeroderma pigmentosum have a defect in the nucleotide excision repair pathway and are at increased risk for the development of cancers of the skin exposed to UV light, because of an inability to repair pyrimidine dimers.
  • Recombination repair: Syndromes involving defects in the homologous recombination DNA repair system constitute a group of disorders which includes Bloom syndrome, ataxia-telangiectasia, and Fanconi anemia. They are characterized by hypersensitivity to DNA-damaging agents, such as ionizing radiation.

Note: Fanconi syndrome is unrelated to and should not be confused with Fanconi anemia. Fanconi syndrome is a rare disorder of kidney tubule function.

questions.text: Which of the following is involved in windlass mechanism?
questions.solution:
Plantar aponeurosis is involved in windlass mechanism.

Windlass mechanism:

When there is a dorsiflexion of the great toe, the plantar aponeurosis shortens and it draws the two pillars together. This leads to a heightening of the medial longitudinal arch. This is called the ‘windlass’ mechanism. 

Posterior part of the inferior calcaneal surface and the three metatarsal heads respectively form the posterior and anterior pillars of the medial longitudinal arch.

 

Median longitudinal arch:

Arch between the heel proximally and the medial three metatarsophalangeal joints.

Bones involved: Calcaneus, talar head, navicular, the three cuneiforms and the medial three metatarsals.

Stability of arch:

  • Plantar aponeurosis (most important)
  • Spring ligament
  • Talocalcaneal ligaments
  • Deltoid ligament
  • Muscles: Flexor hallucis longus, Flexor digitorum longus, abductor hallucis flexor digitorum brevis, Tibialis posterior and anterior
  • Bones

questions.text: Which of the following receptors is not found in hairy skin?
questions.solution:
Merkel cells (Merkel-Ranvier cells) are found on glabrous (free from hair) skin and are highly specialized to respond to sustained pressure and touch.

They are slowly adapting receptors.

The remaining receptors are found in hairy skin.

Clinical significance: Merkel cells may become malignant and form a Merkel cell carcinoma, which is an aggressive and hard to treat cancer.

Related Pearl: Sensory Receptors

questions.text: Identify the test shown below.
questions.solution:
The image shows a tear strip placed in the lower lid of the eye. This is the Schirmer test which is used to check for dry eye.

Dry eye is a multifactorial disease of the eye characterised by loss of homeostasis of the tear film. Patients present with irritation, foreign body sensation and dryness. Treatment of dry eye includes medical treatment (lubricating eyedrops, most commonly methylcellulose derivatives) or surgical treatment (lacrimal punctum occlusion using silicone plugs).

Other tests for dry eye include: 

  1. Tear film break-up test is used to determine the interval between a complete blink and appearance of first randomly distributed dry spot on the cornea. A drop of fluorescein is instilled in the eye, following by examination in the cobalt-blue light of a slit-lamp.
  2. Rose Bengal staining is used for the detection of dry, dead epithelium in dry eye.
  3. Tear osmolarity test is performed with an osmometer. 

Other options:

Option B: Ishihara plates are used to test colour vision. They help detect red-green colour blindness. 

Option C: Jones test is used in watering eye. It uses fluorescein dye. 

Option D: Goldmann's tonometry is used to measure intra-ocular pressure. It consists of a double prism mounted on a slit-lamp.  

Related Pearl: Tear film tests used for the diagnosis of dry eye

Schirmer test

Inference 

  • 15 mm: Normal
  • 5-10 mm: Moderate keratoconjunctivitis sicca (KCS)
  • < 5 mm: Severe KCS

Tear film break up test (TBUT)

Inference 

  • 15-35 seconds: Normal
  • < 10 seconds: Unstable tear film

Rose Bengal staining

Inference

  • A pattern: Confluent staining → Severe KCS
  • B pattern: Extensive staining → Moderate KCS
  • C pattern: Fine punctate stains → Mild KCS

Tear osmolarity test

Abnormal osmolarity is defined by 

  • An elevated reading, >300 mOsm/L, indicating loss of homeostasis, or
  • When the inter-eye difference is >8 mOsm/L, indicating instability of the tear film.

questions.text: Ibrutinib is a _______
questions.solution:
Ibrutinib is a Bruton Tyrosine kinase inhibitor. It inhibits malignant B cell proliferation - used in CLL, SLL, Waldenstrom's Macroglobulinemia.

Imatininib is a BCR- ABL kinase inhibitor.

Palbociclib is a CDK inhibitor approved for use in metastatic breast carcinoma.

Ruxolitinib is Jak1/2 inhibitor indicated for the treatment of patients with polycythemia vera who have had an inadequate response to hydroxyurea and for the treatment of myelofibrosis.

questions.text: Swarming is exhibited by which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
Swarming is exhibited by all the above organisms.

Swarming effect is produced on blood agar which is characterized by expanding rings (waves) of organisms over the surface of the agar. Organism exhibiting swarming include:

  • Proteus
  • Serratia
  • Vibrio parahemolyticus
  • Clostridium tetani

questions.text: A 35-year-old asymptomatic woman on USG shows a unilocular cyst in the ovary of 6 cm with negative serology. Treatment involves:
questions.solution:
Follow up after 1-2 cycles of oral combined pills (conservative management) is the best treatment modality in the given scenario as it is most likely to be a functional cyst.

For conservative management of ovarian cysts, the following criteria should usually be met:

  • Asymptomatic
  • Unilocular
  • Unilateral
  • No solid areas
  • Normal CA 125
  • Less than 7cm
  • Ultrasound re-examination after 3-6 months (no signs of increase in size or malignancy)

Features of a functional cyst:

  • Related to temporary hormonal disorders
  • Benign and rarely become complicated
  • Usually 6-8cm in diameter
  • Usually asymptomatic
  • Unilocular
  • Contains clear fluid, unless haemorrhage occurs
  • Lining epithelium corresponds to the functional epithelium of the unit from which they arise
  • Spontaneous regression occurs within 4-6 months

Treatment of functional cysts:

  • Usually conservative; spontaneous regression occurs after 4-6months.
  • Oral combined pills to hasten the regression of cyst.
  • Laparotomy for tumours more than 7 cm to prevent complications or malignant transformation.

questions.text: A patient underwent a surgical resection of a part of his brain to treat seizures. Following the surgery, he suffered from anterograde amnesia and was unable to form new long-term memories but could learn new puzzles. He has normal procedural memory. Which portion of his brain was surgically removed?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient had anterograde amnesia and was unable to form new long-term memories post-surgery. The hippocampus is most likely removed in this patient as it converts short-term memories to long-term memories.

Other options

The neocortex, the amygdala, and the striatum are associated with implicit (procedural) memory, which is intact in this patient.

Related Pearl: Forms of Memory

From physiologic point of view memory is divided into explicit and implicit forms.

questions.text: A child presents with painful swelling of the parotid glands as shown in the image below. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: Salivary gland involvement is limited to the parotids
The patient is not infectious prior to clinical parotid enlargement
Mumps orchitis frequently leads to infertility

questions.solution:
In the given scenario the image of a child presenting with painful swelling of the parotid glands suggests the diagnosis of mumps. Meningoencephalitis can precede parotitis is true regarding mumps. 

Meningoencephalitis classically manifests 5 days after parotitis, however, it can occur before, or along with parotitis.

Other options:

Option A: Mumps virus may involve salivary glands (parotid, submandibular), CNS, pancreas, and testes.

Option B: The virus appears in saliva 7 days before to 7 days after the appearance of parotid swelling. The maximum period of infectivity is 1-2 days before 5 days after the onset of parotid swelling.  

Option D: Mumps orchitis may lead to atrophy of the testes but sterility is rare even with bilateral involvement.

questions.text: According to the expanded new Ballard score, which of the following criteria for neuromuscular maturity shows a popliteal angle?
questions.solution:
According to the expanded new ballard score, criteria for neuromascular maturity given in row "D" depicts popliteal angle.

Expanded New Ballard score:

  • 5 points (maximum score) can be assigned to only 2 of the criteria:
    • Popliteal angle (criteria for neuromuscular maturity)
    • Skin (criteria for physical maturity)
  • For all other criteria, 4 is the maximum score.
  • -1 is the minimum score for all criteria except posture and arm recoil. For both these, 0 is the minimum score.

New Ballard Score:

questions.text: Corpus luteum in the first 6 weeks of pregnancy is maintained by ___________
questions.solution:
Beta hCG maintains the corpus luteum in the first 6 weeks of pregnancy.

Other functions of Human Chorionic Gonadotropin include:

  • Stimulation of fetal testicular testosterone secretion which is maximum approximately when hCG levels peak.
  • Inhibits maternal processes of immunorejection.
  • Stimulates maternal thyroid.
  • Promotes relaxin secretion from corpus luteum.

questions.text: The lab report of a 35 year old lady who underwent a medical checkup suggests dyslipidemia. She has a past medical history of peptic ulcer disease. Also 2 months back, she had severe pain in her great toe which was cured temporarily by taking NSAIDs. She has been taking statins for past 1 month. Which of the below drugs is absolutely contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Niacin would be absolutely contraindicated for the lady presenting with the above clinical history. 

Contraindications to niacin are:

  • Pregnancy
  • Concurrent use with statin - causes myopathy
  • History of peptic ulcer disease
  • Gout - is a relative contraindication

Other options:

Option A- Ezetimibe in combination with statin results in further reduction of low density lipoproteins (LDL) cholesterol. However this combination should not be used in pregnant women. Ezetimibe should also not be used along with bile acid sequestrants as they inhibit its absorption.

Option B- Cholestyramine is contraindicated is severe hypertriglyceridemia (Note: since the dyslipidemia in the question is not specific, this cannot be the answer).

Option C- Evolocumab is a fully human monoclonal antibody that inhibits proprotein convertase subtilisin/Kexin type 9 (PCSK9). It is contraindicated in those with hypersensitivity.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions, the characteristic appearance marked by arrows, is seen as shown in the MRI image below
questions.solution:
The above image shows ovoid lesions with their long axis perpendicular to the ventricular surface called Dawson fingers (white arrows) which are characteristically seen in multiple sclerosis.

Multiple sclerosis (MS) is considered to be autoimmune in origin and is the most common demyelinating disease.

MRI is the study of choice in imaging multiple sclerosis because of its greater sensitivity than computed tomography in demonstrating plaques, both in the brain and spinal cord.

questions.text: Which of the following is the preferred antibiotic in case of a suspected wound contamination with tetanus?
questions.solution:
Metronidazole (400 mg rectally or 500 mg IV every 6 h for 7 days) is the preferred anti-biotic to be used in a wound contaminated with tetanus. Penicillin G, doxycycline and clindamycin are the other antibiotics which can be used if metronidazole is unavailable.

Related Pearl: Post exposure prophylaxis for tetanus

Prophylaxis is given based on patient category:

A. Full immunization or a booster dose within the past 5 years.

B. Full immunization or a booster dose > 5 years ago but < 10 years.

C. Full immunization or a booster dose > 10 years ago.

D. Unknown or never taken immunization

Category Clean wound Unclean wound
A Only wound care Only wound care
B Wound care + TT single dose Wound care + TT single dose
C Wound care + TT single dose Wound care + TT single dose + Human tetanus immunoglobulin 
D Wound care + TT complete course Wound care + TT complete course + Human tetanus immunoglobulin

questions.text: What is the most common site for an extragonadal germ cell tumor?
questions.solution:
Extragonadal germ cell tumor is most commonly seen in mediastinum.

Extragonadal germinal cell tumors (EGGCTs) are rare tumors that predominantly affect young males. Seminomas account for 30-40% of these tumors, and nonseminomatous germ cell tumors (NS-GCTs) account for 60-70%. 

Common sites:

  • Mediastinum (50-70%)
  • Retroperitoneum (30-40%)
  • Pineal gland (5%)
  • Sacrococcygeal area (less than 5%)

questions.text:
Arrange from outer to inner the layers of the retina given below: A-Retinal pigment epithelium B-Inner plexiform layer C-Nerve fiber layer D-Inner nuclear layer E-external limiting membrane.
  1. Retinal pigment epithelium
  2. Inner plexiform layer
  3. Nerve fiber layer
  4. Inner nuclear layer
  5. External limiting membrane.
questions.solution:
From the given options, the correct sequence from outer to inner is:

  • retinal pigment epithelium (A), 
  • external limiting membrane (E), 
  • inner nuclear layer (D),
  • inner plexiform layer (B), 
  • nerve fiber layer (C) 

Related Pearl: Layers of Retina

Layers of Retina  (inner to outer)

  1. Internal limiting membrane
  2. Nerve fibre layer
  3. Ganglion cell layer           
  4. Inner plexiform layer
  5. Inner nuclear layer
  6. Outer plexiform layer 
  7. Outer nuclear layer
  8. External limiting membrane
  9. Rods and cones
  10. Retinal pigment epithelium

questions.text: Basophilic staining of vascular walls due to encrustation by DNA from necrotic tumor cells is seen in ___________.

choices.text: Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung

questions.solution:
Basophilic staining of vascular walls due to encrustation by DNA from necrotic tumor cells, known as the Azzopardi effect, is seen in small-cell carcinoma of the lung.

Other histologic descriptions:

  • Sheets, ribbons, clusters, rosettes, or peripheral palisading of small- to medium-sized (2-4x neutrophils) round/oval cells with minimal cytoplasm, salt-and-pepper chromatin without prominent clumps, hyperchromatic, indistinct nucleoli, nuclear molding, smudging, or frequent mitotic figures.
  • Stroma is scanty, vascular, and delicate.
  • No glands, replacement of epithelium is less common than subepithelial growth.
  • Necrosis and apoptotic debris are common.
  • The cells grow in clusters that exhibit neither glandular nor squamous organization.
  • Lesions may have larger cells with similar morphology, small mixtures of squamous cell carcinoma or adenocarcinoma 
  • Occasionally, scattered giant cells and prominent nucleoli are seen.
  • Electron microscopy shows dense core neurosecretory granules in two-thirds of cases.

Note:

Among the various types of lung cancer, small-cell carcinoma is one that is most commonly associated with ectopic hormone production.

Immunohistochemistry demonstrates high levels of anti-apoptotic protein BCL2 in 90% of the tumors.

questions.text: Which of the following ovarian tumours is most radiosensitive ?
questions.solution:
Dysgerminoma is the most radiosensitive among the ovarian tumours.

However, radiotherapy is not the treatment of choice as dysgerminoma usually occurs in pre-reproductive or reproductive age group and fertility is impaired with radiotherapy.

questions.text: A doctor was accused of issuing false sickness certificates. He should be tried in court under which IPC section?
questions.solution:

questions.text: Facial nerve gives out secretomotor fibers to all except
questions.solution:
Facial nerve gives out secretomotor fibers to lacrimal gland, submandibular gland and nasal glands (not parotid gland).

Secretomotor pathway to parotid gland:

Preganglionic fibers - originate in inferior salivary nucleus, pass through glosspharyngeal nerve, its tympanic branch, tympanic plexus and lesser petrosal nerve.

Relay ganglion:Otic ganglion.

Post ganglionic fibers: Pass through auriculotemporal nerve to reach the gland.

questions.text: The virus causing Apollo conjunctivitis is:
questions.solution:
Enterovirus 70 causes Apollo conjunctivitis.

Hemorrhagic conjunctivitis (a.k.a Apollo conjunctivitis):

  • It is due to picornaviruses, namely, coxsackie A24 and enterovirus 70.
  • It occurs in a pandemic form producing violent inflammatory conjunctivitis with lacrimation and photophobia. Subconjunctival haemorrhages and enlarged preauricular lymph nodes are common. Cornea is usually affected.

Other options:

  • Herpes simples virus causes herpetic conjunctivitis. Usually seen in children infected by contagion from carriers of the virus. Acyclovir 3% or vidarabine 3% eye ointment or trifluoro-thymidine 1% drops are often necessary.
  • Adenovirus serotypes 8 and 19 (also 3 and 7) cause epidemic keratoconjunctivitis. Adenovirus serotypes 3, 4 and 7 cause conjunctivitis associated with pharyngoconjunctival fever. Acyclovir is ineffective against adenovirus infection.
  • Newcastle virus causes Newcastle conjunctivitis. Clinically indistinguishable from conjunctivitis of pharyngoconjunctival fever. History of contact with diseased fowls is often present.

Note : Following the epidemic of this new hemorrhagic conjunctivitis in Ghana in 1969, it was nicknamed locally as "Apollo 11 disease" as it coincided with the time of Apollo 11 landing on the moon.

questions.text: Which of the following neurotransmitters acts on the muscle, behind a bolus of food, in the process of peristalsis?
questions.solution:
Substance P and acetylcholine are released from neurons behind the bolus of food, causing smooth muscle contraction, which propels the food downwards.

NO and VIP are released by neurons in the anterograde direction from the bolus which produces relaxation in front of the stimulus.

questions.text: Which of the following is a cartilaginous  joint?
questions.solution:
Synchondrosis is a primary cartilaginous joint.

Sutures, syndesmosis and gomphosis are fibrous joint.

Based on the structure, Joints are classified into three types

  • Fibrous joints
    • Sutures
    • Syndesmosis
    • Gomphosis
  • Cartilaginous joints
    • Primary cartilaginous joints or synchondrosis
    • Secondary cartilaginous joints or symphysis
  • Synovial joints
    • Ball-and-socket or spheroidal joints
    • Sellar or saddle joints
    • Condylar or bicondylar joints
    • Ellipsoid joints
    • Hinge joints
    • Pivot or trochoid joints
    • Plane joints

questions.text: A man has relapsing fever, rash and arthralgia a week after he had a rat bite. Which of the following organisms may be the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Relapsing fever, rash and arthralgia a week after a rat bite is suggestive of rat bite fever. Causative organisms for rat bite fever are spirillum minus and streptobacillus moniliformis. Both are natural parasites of rodents.

Other options:

  • Acinetobacter: Opportunistic pathogen in human skin. It can cause ventilator associated pneumonia, meningitis.
  • Legionella: Cause legionare’s disease, pontaic fever
  • Eikenella: Normally present in mouth, GIT, Upper respiratory tract.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy presented with pruritic, hypopigmented macules on his chest and abdomen, as shown in the image given below. On examination using Wood's lamp, pale yellow fluorescence was noted. Which of the following is used as the first-line drug in this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, with the image showing sharply demarcated hypopigmented macules coalescing into patches, is suggestive of tinea verisolor/pityriasis versicolor. Topical terbinafine is a first-line drug that can be used to treat this condition.

Pityriasis versicolor is characterized by asymptomatic hypopigmented or hyperpigmented macules and patches and produces fine scales. It is caused by a fungus named Malassezia, a part of the normal skin microbiota, which are lipid-dependent for survival.

The most commonly affected site is the upper trunk, but there is often spread to the upper arms, neck, and abdomen. Occasionaly it presents as pruritic lesion. The color of the scales may vary from pale ochre to medium brown, and so the term versicolor. 

The image below shows the scales seen in Tinea versicolor.

The characteristic appearance on KOH mount and microscopy has been likened to "spaghetti and meatballs" or "bananas and grapes." 

Pale yellow fluorescence is seen in Wood’s lamp examination is characteristic of tinea versicolor or pityriasis versicolor.

Besnier's sign (coup d'ongle sign, scratch sign, stroke of the nail) is an important diagnostic clue when the scales are not visible. Here, the barely perceptible scales are made to stand out by scratching the lesion with fingernails.

Patients are treated with topical azoles or 1% terbinafine cream twice daily for 2 to 3 weeks or ketoconazole or selenium shampoo twice weekly for the same duration. Itraconazole tablets are useful as second-line management. Relapses are very common.

questions.text: Which of the following is a primary symptom of schizophrenia?

choices.text: Social withdrawal with excessive irrational fantasy thinking

questions.solution:
All of the above options are primary symptoms of schizophrenia.

Eugene Bleuler mentioned the fundamental symptoms of schizophrenia and they are known as the 4 A’s of Bleuler. They include:

  • Autism – social withdrawal with excessive irrational fantasy thinking.
  • Ambivalence – inability to take a decision.
  • Association disturbances – mainly there is loosening of association therefore the person keeps jumping from one topic to another and doesn't not remain consistent.
  • Affect problems – there is affective flattening or inappropriate affect.

questions.text: A  young patient presents with complaints of cramping abdominal pain and painless bright red bleeding in stools for the past 1 week. External and digital rectal examinations are normal. What is the next best step in the evaluation of this patient?
questions.solution:
The first step in the workup of suspected lower GI bleed is to rule out the anorectal source of the bleed by digital rectal examination (DRE) and proctoscopy. Proctoscopy is a procedure used to inspect the anus, anorectal junction, and lower rectum (up to 10 cm). Biopsy of the suspicious areas can be taken if needed.

Examination of the rectum:

- Visual inspection of the perineum
- Digital examination
- Proctoscopy
- Sigmoidoscopy – rigid and/or flexible

If the anorectal cause of bleeding is ruled out, it is important to eliminate an upper GI source through nasogastric (NG) aspiration or esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD). An NG aspirate that contains bile and no blood effectively rules out upper tract bleeding in most patients.

Colonoscopy can be performed next when the anorectal or upper GI cause of bleeding is ruled out or if the extent of the hemorrhoid disease is incongruent with the patient’s symptoms, or if the patient has risk factors for colon cancer, such as a family history.

questions.text:
True about artery of adamkiewicz:
a. Enter spinal cord  from right side
b. It is the main supply to upper one third of the cord
c. It mostly arise from aorta in lower thoracic region
d. Largest feeder artery of spinal cord
questions.solution:
Statement C and D are true regarding Artery of Adamkiewicz .

Artery of Adamkiewicz 

  • Largest feeder artery of the spinal cord.
  • Largest anterior segmental medullary artery
  • Enters spinal cord on left side
  • Importance - main supply to the lower two-thirds of the cord.
  • Origin - aorta, lower thoracic region or less frequently of upper lumbar arteries (L1 and L2).

The spinal cord can't rely on its longitudinal arteries for its entire longitudinal and transverse blood supplies and the input of its segmental medullary feeder vessels is essential, especially the artery of Adamkiewicz, which may carry the major supply for the lower cord and its damage may be responsible for paraplegia following aortic bypass procedures.

questions.text: All of the following are late complications of phacoemulsification except?

choices.text: Complete dislocation of the intraocular lens

questions.solution:
Sunset syndrome (and not sundown syndrome) is a late complication of cataract surgery.

Late adverse complications of cataract surgery are:

  • Cystoid macular oedema
  • Posterior capsule opacification (after cataract or secondary cataract)
  • Anterior capsule contraction
  • Retinal detachment
  • Corneal endothelial decompensation (aphakic or pseudophakic bullous keratopathy)
  • Intraocular lens malposition: Windshield wiper syndrome- intraocular lens haptic rubs on the endothelium; Sunset syndrome- inferior subluxation; Sunrise syndrome- superior subluxation; lens optic capture by the iris;  complete dislocation of the intraocular lens

Note: Sundown (sundowner) syndrome or sundowning is a neurological phenomenon associated with increased confusion and restlessness in patients with delirium and some types of dementia (Alzheimer’s) in evening or when the sun is setting.

Related Pearl: Complications of cataract surgery

Early postoperative complications

Occurs within the first few days to 4 weeks.

  • Endophthalmitis
  • Retained lens matter
  • Corneal edema
  • Wound leak and dehiscence
  • Toxic anterior segment syndrome

Late postoperative complications

Occurs within months to years.

  • Posterior capsule opacification (most common)
  • Cystoid macular edema
  • Secondary glaucoma
  • Retinal detachment
  • Intraocular lens malpositions:
    • Windshield wiper syndrome— intraocular lens haptic rubs on the endothelium
    • Sunset syndrome—inferior subluxation
    • Sunrise syndrome—superior subluxation
    • Complete dislocation of the intraocular lens.

questions.text: Most potent estrogen is ___________
questions.solution:
Estradiol is the most potent estrogen.

Estradiol (E2)  is ten times more potent than estrone (E1), which is ten times more potent than estriol.

Major estrogens:

  • Reproductive age group: Estradiol
  • Post-menopausal period: Estrone
  • Pregnancy: Estriol

questions.text: During a psychiatric assessment, patient was asked to explain the sentence, “A bird in the hand is worth two in the bush”. To which he replied, “It’s better to have a bird in the hand than to have two birds in the bush”. This is known as ______________
questions.solution:
Type of thinking was being tested in the above patient. The patient was asked meaning of the proverb, and he could only answer in the literal sense, and not what the proverb actually meant metaphorically. Hence the patient has concrete thinking.

In the given example, if the patient had explained the proverb as, “Things we already have are more valuable than what we hope to get”, then it would be abstract thinking.

Types of thinking:

  • Concrete thinking: It is literal thinking that is focused on the physical world. People engaged in concrete thinking are focused on facts in the here and now, physical objects, and literal definitions.
  • Abstract thinking is the ability to think beyond a single aspect of a situation, showing that they can think of various meanings of a situation, simultaneously. 

Type of thinking is tested by asking the patient:

  1. The meaning of a proverb
  2. The similarities between objects like a table and a chair or between a dog and a lion.

Note: Abstract thinking maybe impaired in schizophrenia.

questions.text: Frotteurism is __________

choices.text: Obtaining sexual pleasure by wearing clothes of opposite sex
Desire to seek surgery to become member of opposite sex
Sexual gratification by rubbing his private parts against another person
Exposure of one’s genitals to an unsuspecting stranger

questions.solution:
• Frotteurism is obtaining sexual gratification by contact with another person (rubbing his private parts against female buttocks, breasts, thighs etc. in crowds etc). It is punishable under Section 292 BNS (290 IPC, with a fine of up to 200 Rs). Under the BNS, it is permissible to be fined up to Rs. 1000.
  • Eonism (also known as Transvestism) is a sexual perversion where a person's whole personality is dominated by a desire to be identified as a member of the opposite sex. Usually seen in males who obtain sexual pleasure by wearing female clothes. There is no hormonal/genital abnormality.
  • Transsexualism: It is the desire to become members of the opposite sex and seek surgery for anatomical alterations.
  • Exhibitionism:  It involves behaviours over a period of 6 months or more, involving the exposure of one’s genitals to an unsuspecting stranger. This is a punishable offence. Section 296 BNS (294 IPC with imprisonment up to 3 months or fine.)
    Under the BNS, this is punishable with imprisonment up to 3 months, or a fine of Rs. 1000, or with both.

questions.text: A 1-year-old boy presented to OPD with the lesions as shown in the image below. There is no history of itching or bleeding. Which of the following micronutrient deficiency can result in this condition?
questions.solution:
The above image shows peri-oral and per-genital dermatitis in a 1-year-old boy which is suggestive of acrodermatitis enteropathica. This results due to a deficiency in zinc.

Acrodermatitis enteropathica is an autosomal recessive disorder where zinc absorption is defective.

It is characterized by anorexia, diarrhea, failure to thrive, humoral and cell-mediated immunodeficiency (poor wound healing, recurrent infections), male hypogonadism, skin lesions (vesiculobullous dermatitis on the extremities and perirectal, peri-genital, and perioral regions, and alopecia), and neurologic abnormalities (tremor, apathy, depression, irritability, nystagmus, photophobia, night blindness, and hypogeusia).

Management includes long-term treatment with elemental zinc at 1 mg/kg/day.

Other options

Option B: Selenium deficiency causes Keshan disease (cardiomyopathy in endemic regions of China); Excess selenium intake leads to selenosis (with hair loss, brittle nails, garlic breath odor, myopathy, and neurologic symptoms).

Option C: Niacin deficiency leads to a disease called pellagra which is characterized by diarrhea, dermatitis, and dementia. The lesion in the neck is characteristic of Casal’s necklace pattern, seen in Pellagra. The Casal collar or Casal necklace is a clinical sign in which there is an erythematous pigmented skin rash in the distribution of a broad collar (dermatomes C3 and C4).

Option D: Iron deficiency is the most common micronutrient deficiency globally. It presents with iron-deficiency anemia and neurocognitive impairment. It presents clinically with pallor, fatigue, atrophic glossitis, and pica.

questions.text: In a preoperative patient  safety surgical checklist, which of the following is not required?
questions.solution: In a preoperative patient surgical checklist, doctor’s signature is not required.

questions.text: Centor criteria/score is used for the diagnosis of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Centor criteria are used to identify the likelihood of Group A Streptococcal (GAS) pharyngitis.

They include the following:

  • Absence of cough (1 point)
  • Tonsillar exudate (1 point)
  • Anterior cervical lymphadenopathy (1 point)
  • Fever (1 point)

A score of

  • 0-1 - GAS infection unlikely
  • 4 - likely

In adults, the positive predictive value of these criteria is around 40% if 3 criteria are met and about 50% if 4 criteria are met.

Mnemonic

C- Cough not present

E- Exudates

N- Nodes

T- Temperature

(OR)

Other diagnostic Methods

  • Group A beta-hemolytic streptococcal rapid antigen detection test (preferred diagnostic method in emergency settings)
  • Throat culture (criterion standard for diagnosis of GAS infection [90-99% sensitive]).

questions.text: Glycolysis and gluconeogenesis are reciprocally regulated by allosteric modification by _____________
questions.solution:
Glycolysis and gluconeogenesis are reciprocally regulated by allosteric modification by fructose 2,6 bis phosphate.

Allosteric modification by fructose 2,6 bis phosphate:

  • The tandem enzyme consists of phosphofructokinase-II (PFK II) and fructose 2,6 bis phosphatase.
    • PFK-II converts fructose 6 phosphate to fructose 2,6 bis phosphate.
    • Fructose 2,6 bis phosphatase converts fructose 2,6 bis phosphate to fructose 6 phosphate.
    • Fructose 2,6 bis phosphate allosterically activates PFK -I.
    • During fasting, there is phosphorylation of tandem enzyme by glucagon. PFK -II is inactive and fructose 2,6 bis phosphatase is active. There is a fall in fructose 2,6 bisphosphate levels. This favours gluconeogenesis.

questions.text: Identify the structures marked as 1 to 4, respectively, in the chorionic plate of the placental tissue as depicted below.
questions.solution: The structures labeled in the above image of the chorionic plate (fetal component) are (1) amnion, (2) extraembryonic mesoderm, (3) cytotrophoblast, and (4) syncytiotrophoblast.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an anxiolytic substance?
questions.solution:
Caffeine is not an anxiolytic substance.

Anxiogenic substances provoke anxiety. Examples include:

  • Carbon dioxide
  • Cholecystokinin
  • Flumazenil
  • Caffeine

Anxiolytic substances reduce anxiety. Examples include:

  • Benzodiazepines
  • Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors
  • Beta blockers
  • Neuropeptide Y
  • Buspirone

questions.text: All of the following cause vasodilation of arterioles except:
questions.solution:
Neuropeptide Y causes vasoconstriction of arterioles. All the other cause vasodilatation.

Neuropeptide Y is primarily synthesized in GABAnergic inhibitory neurons.

Vasodilation of skeletal muscle vasculature in response to activation of the sympathetic nervous system is due to the actions of epinephrine released from the adrenal medulla. Activation of β2-adrenoceptors on skeletal muscle and liver blood vessels promotes vasodilation.

Circulating neurohumoral agents and their effects on arterioles:

Vasoconstriction Vasodilation
Epinephrine (except in skeletal muscle & liver) Epinephrine in skeletal muscle & liver
Norepinephrine Calcitonin G-related peptide
Vasopressin Substance P
Angiotensin II Histamine
Endogenous digitalis like substance Atrial natriuretic peptide
Neuropeptide Y Vasoactive Intestinal polypeptide

questions.text: Most important extracellular buffer_____
questions.solution:
The most important extracellular buffer is bicarbonate. The source of bicarbonate is plasma by filteration. It is a non inducible buffer. 

Proteins: Are the most abundant intracellular buffer. 

Phosphate: minor buffer in kidney. The source is plasma by filteration. It is a noninducible buffer. 

Ammonia is a minor buffer, locally produced by tubular cells. Its production increases in metabolic acidosis. It is the only inducible buffer. 

Related Pearl: Principal buffers in the body

Extracellular Buffers Intracellular Buffers Bone Buffers
  • HCO3 (bicarbonate) -Major buffer in ECF and body
  • Plasma proteins
  • Phosphate - minor
  • NH3- minor
  • Organic phosphates [e.g., AMP, ADP, ATP, 2,3-diphosphoglycerate (DPG)]
  • Intracellular proteins
  • Hemoglobin in RBCs

It has been estimated that at least 40% of the buffering of an acute acid load takes place in the bone.

In chronic acidosis continued buffering has adverse effects on bone mineralization and can result in bone diseases such as rickets, osteomalacia, and osteopenia.

Czerney’s retractor is used for superficial skin retraction during laparotomy.

questions.text: A patient presents with salmon-pink, well-demarcated, scaling plaques which on scratching produce tiny bleeding points as shown in the image given below. Which of the following nail changes would you expect to see in this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the image showing Auspitz's sign are characteristic of psoriasis. A subungual oil drop sign or salmon patch is a specific sign seen in nail psoriasis.

Psoriasis is a chronic inflammatory condition of the skin with systemic manifestations. Plaque psoriasis is the most common type.

The nails are frequently involved, and pitting is the most common finding seen. Nail beds can also be affected, giving rise to the oil-drop sign—a highly specific sign seen in this condition. Other manifestations include subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

 The skin is involved in the form of red/ salmon pink, scaly, and well-demarcated lesions. A peripheral clearing (ring of Woronoff) may be present. It is usually seen on the scalp, trunk, and extensor surfaces of the limbs. The lesions are surrounded by silvery-white scales. The appearance of a smooth, glossy red membrane with small bleeding points on the removal of the supra-papillary epidermis by gentle scraping (Auspitz's sign) is characteristic.
 
Other options: Dorsal nail pterygium, pup tent sign, and thinning of the nail plate are the nail findings seen in lichen planus.

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

Image :  Pitting is the commonest manifestation of nail psoriasis.

Image: oil drops visible in the nail bed.

Image: pitting and salmon patches in fingernails.

Image: Leukonychia in a patient with psoriasis.

 

Features of Nail Psoriasis – Mnemonic

“Nail – POLISH”

  • P – Pitting
  • O – Oil drop sign, Onycholysis
  • L – Leuconychia
  • I – Irregular pitting pattern
  • S – Splinter Hemorrhage
  • H – Hyperkeratosis (Subungual)

Related Pearl: Nail changes in lichen planus

Nail involvement in lichen planus occurs in up to 10% of the cases but is usually a minor feature of the disease.

Dorsal Nail Pterygium is the most specific nail change in Lichen planus. The fusion of dorsal nail fold and nail bed leads to pterygium.

The most frequent nail change is the exaggeration of longitudinal lines and linear depressions due to a slight thinning of the nail plate.

Pup-tent sign - elevation of nail in shape of tent

Trachyonychia - 20 nail dystrophy

Subungual Hyperkeratosis and Onycholysis

Longitudinal Melanonychia in Lichen Planus of the nail bed

Permanent destruction of several toenails with ulceration of soles (rare variant)

Image shows  Nails in Lichen planus presented with irregular longitudinal grooves and ridges .

Image : Dorsal Nail Pterygium

Image : Pup-tent sign 

Image: Trachyonychia

questions.text: All are true about savant syndrome except ________
questions.solution:
Savant syndrome may not always be congenital. It can also be acquired following brain injury or disease later in infancy, childhood or adult life.

Savant syndrome: It is a rare condition in which persons with serious mental disabilities, including autistic disorder, have some island of genius always linked to massive memory.

  • Male predominance – 6:1
  • Seen in 10% autism cases. Can also be seen in other mental disabilities, mental retardation, CNS injury or disease.
  • Skills in 5 major categories: Music, art, calender calculation, mathematics and spatial skills.Splinter skills are most common which include obsessive preoccupation with, and memorization of, music and sports trivia, license plate numbers, maps, historical facts or obscure items.

questions.text: True about toxin involved in staphylococcal food poisoning is ____________

choices.text: It also causes staphylococcal scald skin syndrome

questions.solution:
None of the above statements are true. Staphylococcal food poisoning is due to enterotoxin.

Enterotoxin of Staphylococcus causes nausea, vomiting, and diarrhoea 2-6 hrs after consuming contaminated food.

  • It is a preformed toxin that is heat stable.
  • Site of action: This toxin stimulates the Vagus Nerve and Vomiting center of the brain and also stimulates the intestinal peristaltic activity.
  • Most Common type of Enterotoxin: Type  A.

Other options:

  • Cytolytic toxins are membrane active substances which consists of alpha, beta, gamma and delta hemolysins and a leucocidin. Enterotoxin is not a cytolytic toxin.
  • Hot cold phenomenon is shown by beta hemolysin. The hemolysis is initiated at 37˚ C but it becomes evident only after chilling.
  • SSSS is caused by exfoliative/epidermolytic toxin (exfoliatin).

questions.text: A 70 years old female is on treatment with alendronate for 7 years for osteoporosis. Now she complains of pain in the right thigh. What is the next investigation to be performed?
questions.solution:
The pain in the right thigh in a 70-year-old female, who is on treatment with alendronate for 7 years for osteoporosis is suggestive of fragility fracture due to prolonged use of bisphosphonates (especially alendronate). Long-term alendronate causes over suppression of bone turnover, resulting in bones that are brittle despite improved bone density.

An x-ray would be the best investigation to see the fractures.

Plain x-ray shows a characteristic picture consiting of a transverse or short oblique fracture line, lateral cortical thickening and medial spiking.

questions.text: Identify the true statement about the infarction shown below.
questions.solution:
Image shows classical splenic infarct portraying its white, wedge shaped, bland nature. All of the above statements are true regarding white infarct.

White infarcts occur with arterial occlusions in solid organs with end-arterial circulation like heart, spleen, and kidney, and where tissue density limits the seepage of blood from adjoining capillary beds into the necrotic area. They are not seen in lungs.

Red infarcts: Infarcts caused by venous occlusion or occurring in spongy tissues with dual blood supply and where blood can collect typically are hemorrhagic (red). They are seen in:

  1. Tissues with venous occlusions (e.g., testicular torsion)
  2. In loose, spongy tissues (e.g., lung) where blood can collect in the infracted zone
  3. In tissues with dual circulations (e.g., lung and small intestine) that allow blood to flow from an unobstructed parallel supply into a necrotic zone.
  4. In tissues previously congested by sluggish venous outflow.
  5. When flow  is reestablished to a site of previous arterial occlusion and necrosis (e.g., following angioplasty of an arterial obstruction).

questions.text: Conjugation is a method of gene transfer in bacteria which involves ____________
questions.solution:
Conjugation is a method of gene transfer in bacteria which involves the transfer of plasmids. A male or donor bacterium makes a physical contact with a female or recipient bacterium and transfers the genetic elements into it.

  • Transformation is the transfer of genetic information through the agency of free DNA.
  • Transduction is the transfer of a portion of DNA from one bacterium to another by a bacteriophage.

questions.text: A patient presents with a tender node on the finger and non tender maculae on feet. All of these are causative agents of this except?
questions.solution:
The findings of Osler nodes(Tender subcutaneous nodules usually found on the distal pads of the digits) and Janeway lesions(Nontender maculae on the palms and soles) suggest a diagnosis of Infective Endocarditis.

Mycoplasma is not a causative agent of Infective Endocarditis.

questions.solution:
Shape of Ebola virus is filamentous. Some of the filamentous virions are fused together, end to end, giving the appearance of a "bowl of spaghetti."

Other options:

questions.text: A 30 year old male who lost his job recently, came to psychiatry OPD with complaints of low mood since last 2 weeks. He feels worthless and fatigued all the time. He gave history of early morning awakening and inability to concentrate. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient has complaints of low mood, worthlessness, fatigue, early morning awakening(terminal insomnia) and the inability to concentrate for a period of 2 weeks. Hence the diagnosis is depression.

Diagnostic criteria for diagnosing depression:

  • Five (or more) of the following symptoms have been present during the same 2-week period.
  • At least one of the symptoms is either (1) depressed mood or (2) loss of interest or pleasure.
    1. Depressed mood most of the day
    2. Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in activities
    3. Significant weight loss when not dieting or weight gain, decrease or increase in appetite
    4. Insomnia or hypersomnia
    5. Psychomotor agitation or retardation
    6. Fatigue or loss of energy
    7. Feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt
    8. Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness
    9. Recurrent thoughts of death, recurrent suicidal ideation

Other options:

  • Adjustment disorder:  Characterised by emotional or behavioural symptoms that develop within 3 months of exposure to an identifiable stressor and usually do not last more than 6 months after the stressor ends.

Diagnostic criteria of an adjustment disorder:

  • Onset of symptoms within 3 months of the stressor.
  • The symptoms disappear within 6 months if the stressor is removed.
  • The symptoms of distress are clearly in excess of the normal.
  • Mostly depressive but can also have anxious symptoms.

Note: Adjustment Disorder is not diagnosed if the symptoms meet criteria for a specific mental disorder or represent an exacerbation of an existing disorder.

  • Subclinical depression is a condition in which a person has depressive symptoms but does not meet the criteria for a depressive disorder.
  • Dysthymia: Depressed mood for most of the day as indicated by either subjective account or observation by others, for at least 2 years. In children and adolescents - at least 1 year.

 

Related Pearl: Signs and symptoms of depression

Mnemonic "SIGECAPS"

Sleep disorder (increased or decreased)

Interest deficit (anhedonia): loss of interest in previously pleasurable activities

Guilt (worthlessness, hopelessness, regret)

Energy deficit

Concentration deficit

Appetite disorder (increased or decreased)

Psychomotor retardation or agitation

Suicidal tendency

questions.text: Oral digoxin is being given to a 65-year-old male patient with congestive heart failure as a maintenance dose to gradually digitalize him. A target plasma concentration of 0.70 ng/mL is decided upon. The digoxin clearance for this particular individual is calculated as 60 mL/min. Knowing that the oral bioavailability of digoxin is 70%, what is the dosing rate in this patient?
questions.solution:
The dosing rate in this patient is 60 ng/min.

The oral bioavailability of digoxin is 70% (F = 0.7) and the required target plasma concentration (Cp) is 0.70 ng/mL. CL is the clearance of digoxin which is 60 mL/min.

Hence, the appropriate dose rate for this patient can be calculated as:

Dosing rate = Target Cp x CL/F

= [0.70 ng/mL × 60 mL/min] ÷ [0.7]

= 60 ng/min

questions.text: Consider the vascular change given in the image below. The phase of hypertension responsible for this vascular change, will also cause ____________
questions.solution:
The vascular change shown is hyaline arteriosclerosis. The arteriolar wall is thickened with increased protein deposition (hyalinized), and the lumen is irregular and markedly narrowed. This is caused due to benign phase of hypertension. Benign phase of hypertension will also cause bilaterally contracted kidney with the renal surface showing diffuse, fine granularity that resembles grain leather.

Changes in malignant hypertension:

  • Hyperplastic Arteriolosclerosis: The vessels exhibit concentric, laminated (onion-skin) thickening of the walls with luminal narrowing.
  • They are accompanied by fibrinoid deposits and vessel wall necrosis (necrotizing arteriolitis), particularly in the kidney.
  • Small, pinpoint petechial hemorrhages may appear on the cortical surface from rupture of arterioles or glomerular capillaries, giving the kidney a peculiar flea-bitten appearance.

questions.text: Abdominal examination of a 28-year-old primigravida, who is in the second stage of labour, reveals retraction ring between the active upper segment and the distended lower segment. Which would best describe this ring?
questions.solution:
Bandl's ring refers to pathological retraction ring. It is formed in cases of obstructed labour.

The upper segment of the uterus contracts and retracts vigourously in an attempt to overcome the obstruction while the lower segment dilates.

With each contraction there is myometrial shortening so that the actively contracting upper segment becomes progressively thicker and shorter. The passive lower segment is progressively stretched and becomes thinner.

The junction between the two segments stands out prominently as a pathological retraction ring.

Schroeder's constriction ring is formed due to incordinate uterine action when there is localized spastic contraction of a ring of circular muscle fibres of the uterus. It is formed due to injudicious use of oxytocin and premature rupture of membranes (PROM).

Related Pearl: Constriction ring v/s retraction ring in uterus

  Constriction / Schroeder's ring  Retraction/ Bandl's ring
Nature Due to incoordinate uterine contraction Due to tonic uterine contractions and retractions
Cause Undue irritability of uterus due to injudicious use of oxytocin Obstructed labor
Location

Usually at the junction of the upper and lower segment.

Location does not alter once formed.

Always at the junction of the upper and lower segment.

Progressively moves upwards after formed.
Per abdomen Ring not felt Ring is felt
Per Vaginal Ring is felt Ring not felt

questions.text: Identify the artery marked in the image _________
questions.solution:
The artery marked in the image is superior cerebellar artery.

The superior cerebellar artery arises near the distal portion of the basilar artery, immediately before the formation of the posterior cerebral arteries. The superior cerebellar artery supplies the pons, pineal body, superior medullary velum and tela choroidea of the third ventricle.

Circle of Willis or circulus arteriosus: Large arterial anastomosis that unites the internal carotid and vertebrobasilar systems. It lies in the subarachnoid space within the basal cisterns that surround the optic chiasma and infundibulum.

The anterior cerebral arteries are derived from the internal carotid arteries and are linked by a small anterior communicating artery.

Posteriorly, the two posterior cerebral arteries are formed by the division of the basilar artery. They are joined to the ipsilateral internal carotid artery by a posterior communicating artery.

questions.text: Which of the following is derived from tyrosine?
questions.solution:
Melanin is derived from tyrosine. Rest all are derived from tryptophan.

Products derived from tyrosine:

  • Melanin
  • Catecholamines e.g epinephrine, norepinephrine, dopamine
  • Thyroxine

Products derived from tryptophan:

  • Melatonin
  • Serotonin
  • Niacin (nicotinic acid)

questions.text: All of the following are examples of flavi virus except ___________
questions.solution:
Chikunguniya is not a flavi virus. It is an alpha virus belonging to toga viridae family.

Yellow fever, dengue, and zika virus are examples of flavi viruses.

questions.text: All of the following regimens are correct regarding treating cystitis in pregnancy except _____________

choices.text: Amoxicillin 500 mg TID for three days

questions.solution:
Levofloxacin 250mg or 500mg is given once daily for three days.

3 day regimes followed for management of cystitis:

  • Amoxicillin 500mg TID.
  • Ampicillin 250mg QID.
  • Cephalosporin 250mg QID.
  • Ciprofloxacin 250mg BID.
  • Levofloxacin 250mg or 500mg OD.
  • Nitrofurantoin 100mg BID.

choices.text: It provides a small field of vision.
Fundus beyond the equator is visualized

questions.solution:
The given image shows a Hruby lens, and it provides a small field of vision.

questions.text: Which of the following side effects was responsible for the withdrawal of oral Gatifloxacin?
questions.solution:
All systemic forms of Gatifloxacin (oral/injectable) were withdrawn from the market by the FDA following an increased incidence of dysglycemic events including both hypoglycemia and hyperglycemia.

questions.text: All of the following tests are used for diagnosis of carbon monoxide poisoning except _________
questions.solution:
Pulse oximetry is not used for the diagnosis of carbon monoxide poisoning. A standard pulse oximeter cannot distinguish between oxyhemoglobin and carboxyhemoglobin.

Tests which may be used for the diagnosis of CO poisoning:

  • Spectroscopy
  • Hoppe-Seyler's test
  • Kunkel's test
  • Potassium ferricyanide test
  • Katayama's test

questions.text: Which of the following is a 5th generation cephalosporin?
questions.solution:
Ceftaroline is a fifth-generation cephalosporin, which exhibits broad-spectrum activity against Gram-positive bacteria, including MRSA and extensively-resistant strains, such as vancomycin-intermediate S. aureus (VISA), heteroresistant VISA (hVISA), and vancomycin-resistant S. aureus (VRSA).

Ceftobiprole is another 5th generation Cephalosporin.
