questions.text: All are features of schwannoma except___________
questions.solution:
Special features of schwannoma are verocay bodies , Antoni A and Antoni B areas. Spider cells are seen in rhabdomyoma.

Schwannomas are well-circumscribed, encapsulated masses that abut the associated nerve without invading it. Microscopically, they are comprised of an admixture of dense and loose areas referred to as Antoni A and Antoni B areas, respectively.

  • The dense eosinophilic Antoni A areas often contain spindle cells arranged into cellular intersecting fascicles.
  • Palisading of nuclei is common and nuclear-free zones that lie between the regions of nuclear palisading are termed Verocay bodies.
  • In the loose, hypocellular Antoni B areas the spindle cells are spread apart by a prominent myxoid extracellular matrix that may be associated with microcyst formation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about Methacholine?

choices.text: It is used for diagnosis of bronchial airway hyperreactivity
It is more resistant to hydrolysis compared to cholinesterase
It has a greater duration of action than ACh

questions.solution:
Methacholine has a predominantly muscarinic effect with only minor nicotinic actions, the former manifest most clearly in the cardiovascular system.

Methacholine is administered by inhalation for the diagnosis of bronchial airway hyperreactivity in patients who do not have clinically apparent asthma.

It is a synthetic choline ester that differs from ACh chiefly in its greater duration and selectivity of action. Its action is more prolonged because the added methyl group increases its resistance to hydrolysis by cholinesterases.

questions.text: Major fibril protein associated with amyloidosis in Familial Mediterranean fever is__________
questions.solution:
Major fibril protein AA is associated with amyloidosis in Familial Mediterranean fever. Hence this form of amyloidosis is related to the recurrent bouts of inflammation.

Familial Mediterranean fever:

  • Autosomal recessive condition characterized by development of attacks of fever associated with inflammation of serosal surfaces (pleura, peritoneum and synovial membrane).
  • Seen in individuals of Armenian, Sephardic Jewish, and Arabic origins.
  • The gene associated with FMF encodes for a protein called Pyrin. Pyrin regulates inflammatory reaction by production of cytokines.

questions.text:
A patient presents with LMN-type facial weakness, as shown in the image below. The patient also complains of impaired taste sensation and inability to tolerate loud sounds. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

LMN- lower motor neuron
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image are suggestive of Bell's palsy. Immediate decompression is not required in Bell’s palsy and does not appear to have any benefit in this condition. 

Bell's palsy is an acute, idiopathic, and unilateral facial paresis that is caused by lower motor neuron lesions of the facial nerve. It is most often associated with HSV-1 infection.

It causes

  • unilateral facial palsy,
  • hyperacusis due to loss of stapedial reflex, and
  • impaired taste sensation due to the involvement of chorda tympani fibers.

It is diagnosed by excluding other causes. Most patients recover from Bell's palsy without treatment. A course of oral steroids and anti-viral drugs are given to increase the chance of recovery. Symptomatic measures include using artificial tears and manual closure of the upper eyelid during sleep to prevent corneal drying.

questions.text: Which of the following is a risk factor for endometrial carcinoma?
questions.solution:
HRT, DM, Hypertension are among the risk factors for endometrial carcinoma.

Predisposing factors of endometrial carcinoma:

  • Hormone replacement therapy (HRT): Unsupervised and unopposed replacement increases the risk.
  • Chronic non-ovulatory cycles as seen in DUB.
  • Familial Lynch II syndrome ( anorectal, breast and endometrial cancer)
  • History of radiation exposure
  • Tamoxifen therapy
  • Obesity
  • Hypertension
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Polcystic ovarian disease
  • Granulosa cell tumour of ovary

questions.solution:
Melanoma is not associated with myc oncogene. Melanoma is associated with amplification of the CDK4 gene.

MYC Oncogene is the most commonly involved transcription factor in human tumors.

  • The MYC proto-oncogene MYC activates the expression of many genes that are involved in cell growth. MYC upregulates expression of telomerase.

questions.text: Regarding ovarian tumour associated with pregnancy, which of the following statement is false?

choices.text: It could be a malignant tumour
It is enlarged corpus luteal cyst
It could be a benign tumour

questions.solution:
Ovarian tumour associated with pregnancy is an enlarged corpus luteal cyst which usually regresses after 12th week.

It can be both a benign as well as a malignant tumour. Benign tumour is incidentally detected during routine USG scans while malignant tumour presents with abdominal pain in pregnancy.

Treatment:

  • If no regression occurs by 12th week, benign tumour should be removed by second trimester between 14th to 16th week.
  • Earlier surgery may increase risk of abortion whereas laparotomy in third trimester may increase surgical difficulty and risk of preterm labour.
  • The tumour discovered late in pregnancy should be removed in early puerperium to avoid torsion and infection.
  • The malignant ovarian tumour requires laparotomy at the earliest, irrespective of the duration of pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions has hydrogen peroxide been recently approved for?
questions.solution:
A topical solution of hydrogen peroxide has been approved for the treatment of raised seborrheic keratoses.

Hydrogen peroxide is a keratolytic agent. Its exact mechanism of action in the treatment of seborrheic keratoses is not fully understood. Supraphysiologic concentrations may cause oxidative damage and death to seborrheic keratosis cells.

Hydrogen peroxide is commonly used as a disinfectant to clean wounds. It can also be used as a mouthwash.

questions.text: Most common type of fibroid is:
questions.solution:
Interstitial fibroids (intramural) are the most common (75%) type of fibroid. All fibroids are interstitial to begin with.

Fibroids (fibromas or Fibromyomas or leiomyomas) are the most common benign tumours of the uterus. Thy are derived from the smooth muscle of the myometrium and also from blood vessels.

Fibroids are usually well-circumscribed and pseudo-capsulated tumours which on cross-section may show areas of calcification, necrosis with whorled appearance.

questions.text: French in foley’s catheter refers to:
questions.solution:
French in Foley’s catheter refers to outer diameter of the catheter.

Two units of measurement are used to describe catheter size:

  • a metric-based French size
  • a wire-based gauge size.

French scale corresponds to the external diameter in millimetres. French size divided by 3 will give the outer diameter of the catheter. 

Fr. size = 3 x d, where d is the outer diameter in mm. 

A 3 Fr. catheter will have a circumference of approximately 3 mm and a diameter of 1 mm. 

Gauge size varies inversely with the outside diameter (i.e., the higher the gauge size, the smaller the outside diameter). Each gauge size is associated with a range of outside diameters. There is no fixed relationship between gauge size and outside diameter. Thus, the only way to determine the actual outside diameter of a catheter is to consult the manufacturer.

questions.text: Which of the following  murmurs increases in intensity after the inhalation of amyl nitrite?
questions.solution:
The murmur of AS increases in intensity after exposure to inhaled amyl nitrite. Amyl nitrate decreases the systemic vascular resistance, hence resulting in the change.

On inhalation of amyl nitrate, the following changes in the murmurs are noted:

questions.text: All of the following tests are related to rotator cuff except
questions.solution:
Bryant’s sign test (anterior axillary fold at lower level) is clinical feature related to anterior disclocation of humoral head.

The rotator cuff includes the subscapularis, infraspinatus, supraspinatus, and teres minor muscles(SITS). 

Rotator cuff injury is a common cause of shoulder pain. The rotator cuff tendons, particularly the supraspinatus tendon, are uniquely susceptible to the compressive forces of subacromial impingement.

Improper athletic technique, poor posture, poor conditioning, and failure of the subacromial bursa to protect the supporting tendons results in a progressive injury from acute inflammation, to calcification, to degenerative thinning, and finally to a tendon tear.

These are special tests for the muscles of rotator cuff performed in clinical context with patient’s presentation and imaging findings.

Option a:

A positive test is inability to press the hand in toward the abdomen and keeping the wrist straight due to weakness of subcapsularis.

Option b:

 Patient is asked to flex shoulder to 90 degree with the forearm parallel to floor. Examiner then internally rotates the shoulder while keeping the arm in the forward flexed position. A positive Hawkins test is most likely indicative of damage to the tendon of the supraspinatus muscle.

Option c:

Here the examiner lifts and place the arm in 90 degree of abduction, the elbow at a right angle and the arm maximally externally rotated; when the examiner lets go the patient would normally hold that position, but if arm falls test is positive. This is seen in patients with tears of infraspinatus and posterior part of rotator cuff.

questions.text: The sensitivity of mammography is very low in young female because:

choices.text: Young females have less glandular tissue
Young females have more fatty tissue

questions.solution:
The mammographic appearance of breast depends on relative amount of fat and glandular tissue which are present.

Young woman’s breast are more dense containing a large proportion of glandular tissue which appears as soft tissue density and lowers sensitivity of mammography and less fatty tissue .

questions.text: The equilateral triangle  formed  by the the tip of the olecranon, the lateral epicondyle and radial head is
questions.solution:
When elbow viewed from lateral position, the tip of the olecranon, the lateral epicondyle and radial head forms an equilateral triangle i.e anconeus triangle, the anatomical landmark for postrolateral portal for elbow arthroscopy.

Ward's triangle refers to a radiolucent area between principle compressive, secondary compressive and primary tensile trabeculae in the neck of femur. It is a sensitive indicator of osteoporosis, particularly in men, and should be used to identify patients at increased risk for osteoporosis-related fractures.

Bryant’s triangle is a right angled formed by:

  1. Anterior Superior Iliac Spine (ASIS)
  2. Tip of Greater trochanter
  3. Junction of perpendiculars from the 2 points above

The distance between the tip of greater trochanter and the junction of 2 perpendiculars measures supra-trochanteric shortening. It can occur in 

  1. Dislocation of hip
  2. Central fracture – dislocation of hip
  3. Destruction of head or acetabulum or both
  4. Fracture of the neck of femur
  5. Coxa-vara deformity of the hip
  6. Malunited intra-trochanteric fracture

questions.text: A 3 week old patient presenting with vomiting and failure to thrive is found to have pyloric stenosis. What should be the next step of management?

choices.text: Its emergency so do pyloromyotomy immediately

questions.solution:
Correction of electrolyte disturbances is the next step of management.

Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is a medical emergency not a surgical emergency. Hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the pylorus results in constriction and obstruction of the gastric outlet, leading to nonbilious, projectile emesis, loss of hydrochloric acid with the onset of hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis, and dehydration. Immediate treatment requires correction of fluid loss and electrolytes imbalance.

  • An initial fluid bolus( 20mL/kg) of crystalloids should be infused immediately if infant is dehydrated.
  • Infants should receive 1.5 -2 times maintenance iv fluids: 150 - 180 ml/Kg/day of 0.9% saline with 0.15% Kcl in 5% glucose.
  • Definitive treatment  : Ramstedt's pyloromyotomy.

questions.text: A diagnostic test has been introduced that will detect a certain disease 2 years earlier than it is usually detected. Assuming that early detection has no effect on the natural history of the disease and no change in death certification practices occur, which of the following is most likely to happen to the disease within the 10 years after the test is introduced?

choices.text: The period of prevalence rate will decrease
The apparent 5 year survival rate will increase
The adjusted mortality rate will decrease

questions.solution:
In the given question, a diagnostic test has been introduced that will detect the disease 2 years earlier than it is usually detected. Since the disease is getting detected 2 years earlier than usual (lead time), treatment can be started 2 years earlier. Hence, the case fatality rate will apparently be lowered, thus leading to an apparent increase in survival rate.

Whenever screening is performed, an apparently higher 5-year survival rate is observed. This is a potential bias due to earlier diagnosis (and not because people live longer).

Note: Survival rate is a complement of Case fatality rate (CFR): SR=1-CFR.

Other options:

  • Incidence rate (new cases) will remain the same after 10 years.
  • Since the duration of the disease will remain the same, the period prevalence rate will remain the same after 10 years.
  • It will also have no effect on the adjusted (standardized mortality rate) mortality rate.

questions.text: The sleep disorder that occurs during REM sleep is __________
questions.solution:
Nightmares occur during REM sleep.

Nightmares are frightening or terrifying dreams that produce sympathetic stimulation and awakens the person. They occur in REM sleep and are usually associated with lengthy and complex dreams that gradually become more frightening. They commonly occur in children in the age group 3 to 6 years and are rare in adults. 

Night terrors (Option B) are characterized by abrupt arousal from sleep. They occur during stages 3 and 4 of NREM sleep.

The person who is aroused by nighmares usually remembers the dreams, whereas a person having nigh terrors cannot recall the dreams. 

Other options: 

Option A: Sleep walking occurs during NREM sleep. 

Option C: Bruxism most commonly occurs during stage 2 of NREM sleep. 

Related Pearl: Events occurring in NREM and REM sleep

Events occurring during NREM stages 3 and 4:

Events

Description

Somnambulism

Sleepwalking

Sleep terror or Night terror

Also called pavor nocturnus.

Awakens with a scream or intense anxiety. Has increased autonomic disturbances.

They do not have a memory of this when they wake up.

Runs in families and seen more frequently in childhood and boys.

Treatment with benzodiazepines is rarely required.

Nocturnal enuresis

Behavioral therapy is the mainstay.

Drugs like desmopressin and imipramine are used.

 

Events occurring in REM sleep:

Events

Description

Nightmares

Fearful sleep without autonomic disturbances that are well remembered in the morning.

TCAs may be used for treatment.

Nocturnal penile tumescence

A normal phenomenon that can be used to differentiate between psychogenic and organic impotence.

Narcolepsy

A disorder of the REM sleep characterized by disturbed sleep in the night, leading to excessive sleep in the morning.

Associated with symptoms such as cataplexy, hypnogogic and hypnopompic hallucination, and sleep paralysis.

 *Hypnogogic hallucinations are those that occur at the start of sleep and hypnopompic hallucinations are those that occur at the end of sleep.

 

Others:

Events

Description

Bruxism (teeth grinding)

Occurs in stage 2 NREM sleep.

Frontal lobe epilepsy

Occurs in stage 2 NREM sleep.

Sleep talking

Occurs in all stages of sleep and may accompany night terrors and sleepwalking.

Common in children.

No treatment is necessary.

questions.text: All of the following can be used to stain melanin except__________
questions.solution:
Hall’s stain cannot be used to stain melanin. It is used to stain bile pigments.

Stains used for melanin:

  • Masson Fontana stain:  stains melanin black. Used for staining melanin and argentaffin granules.
  • DOPA-oxidase method: It is the most specific method for staining melanin. The stain works on the principle that the DOPA substrate is acted upon by DOPA-oxidase in the melanin-producing cells which produces a brownish black deposit.
  • Schmorl’s method: Stains melanin blue-green.

questions.text: Insulin does not have a quarternary structure because _____________

choices.text: Chains are connected by disulphide bonds
Van der waals forces are not involved

questions.solution:
Insulin has 2 different polypeptide chains. However, the reason as to why insulin does not have a quaternary structure is because polypeptide chains in insulin are connected by disulphide bonds which are covalent bonds. Proteins with quaternary structure have noncovalent bond.

Primary structure of insulin consists of 2 polypeptide chains. It has a total 51 amino acids with 21 amino acids on alpha chain and 30 amino acids on beta chain. It has 2 interchain disulphide bonds between alpha and beta chains and a intrachain disulphide bond on alpha chain.

Structures of proteins:

  • Primary: linear sequence of amino acids in the polypeptide chain
  • Secondary: Folded and geometrically ordered units of short segments of poly peptides
  • Tertiary: Secondary structures when arranged into larger functional units
  • Quaternary: Different types of polypeptides being arranged in a spatial manner

questions.text: A 26 year old sexually active male was presenting with recurrent gonococcal infections.  Which of the following complement deficiency is most specific to this condition?
questions.solution:
Recurrent gonococcal infections are seen in C5 complement deficiency. This is because, neisseria gonorrhoea is a thin walled bacterium. And C5 is a terminal component of complement, required for the assembly of the membrane attack complex involved in the lysis of organisms. Hence the deficiency of these late acting components leads to recurrent Neisseria (gonococcal and meningococcal) infections.

questions.text: Extinction phenomenon is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Extinction phenomenon is seen in Hemispatial neglect.

Hemispatial Neglect:

Concept:

The right hemisphere directs attention within the entire extrapersonal space but however the left hemisphere directs attention mostly within the contralateral right hemispace.

So right hemisphere lesions give rise to severe contralesional left hemispatial neglect because the unaffected left hemisphere does not contain ipsilateral attentional mechanisms.

On the other hand, left hemisphere lesions do not give rise to much contralesional neglect because the global attentional mechanisms of the right hemisphere compensate for the loss.

Test:

A bedside test useful in assessing neglect is simultaneous bilateral stimulation.

After right hemisphere injury, patients who have no difficulty detecting unilateral stimuli on either side experience the bilaterally presented stimulus as coming only from the right.

This phenomenon is known as extinction and is a manifestation of the sensory-representational aspect of hemispatial neglect.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presented with vague abdominal pain, anorexia, weight loss for the last 6 months. He also reported spontaneously appearing and disappearing painful, linearly arranged nodules at different locations on his body. On examination, thrombophlebitis and epigastric tenderness were noted. Investigations revealed elevated serum CEA and CA 19-9. Which of the following genetic mutations is most frequently associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The presence of the above clinical symptoms with migratory thrombophlebitis (Trousseau syndrome) and elevated serum levels of CEA and CA 19-9 in an elderly man point to a diagnosis of pancreatic cancer. The most frequently associated mutation with this condition is K-RAS.

It is attributed to the production of platelet-aggregating factors and procoagulants from the tumor or its necrotic products. Both venous and arterial thrombi can occur. Venous thrombi can embolize to the lungs.

SMAD4 Tumor suppressor gene 18q

 

Following genes are associated with an inherited predisposition to pancreatic cancer:

  • BRCA2 mutation - pancreatic cancer, breast cancer, prostate cancer, and ovarian cancers
  • PRSS1 mutation - pancreatic carcinoma secondary to hereditary pancreatitis

questions.text: Megaloblastic anaemia caused by mutation in SLC19A2 gene is responsive to___________
questions.solution:
Mutation of SLC19A2 gene leads to Thiamine responsive Megaloblastic anaemia (TRMA) syndrome which responds in varying degrees to thiamine (Vit B1).

It is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by megaloblastic anaemia, diabetes mellitus and sensorineural hearing loss. It occurs due to mutation in SLC19A2 gene, encoding a thiamine transporter protein, leading to abnormal thiamine transportation and cellular vitamin deficiency.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presented with fever, malaise, and painful enlargement of the thyroid gland after a few days following viral fever. On investigation, thyroid antibodies were normal and serum T4 was slightly raised. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical condition is suggestive of subacute granulomatous thyroiditis.

It is the most common cause of a painful thyroid. It is also known as painful subacute thyroiditis, de Quervain thyroiditis, or migratory thyroiditis (this is because the pain can shift to different locations in the thyroid). 

Option A: Subacute lymphocytic thyroiditis (postpartum thyroiditis) is typically painless. It often occurs after pregnancy and is characterized by lymphocytic inflammation in the thyroid.

Option B: Riedel's thyroiditis is a rare disorder characterized by a painless, rapidly growing thyroid mass with extensive fibrosis involving the thyroid and contiguous neck structures.

Option C: Hashimoto thyroiditis is an autoimmune disease that presents as painless enlargement of the thyroid associated with some degree of hypothyroidism in middle-aged women.

questions.text: A 1 week old neonate presents with anoxic spells and single S2. Chest X ray of the child is given. Which of the following is not associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The above given findings are suggestive of Tetralogy of fallot(TOF). Pulmonary oligemia is seen in TOF and not pulmonary plethora.

The above X-ray classically shows a boot shaped heart(Coeur en sabot) seen in TOF.

Features of TOF:

  • Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  • Right ventricular outflow tract obstruction (RVOTO) - Subpulmonic stenosis
  • Overriding aorta
  • Right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH)

X-ray Features:

  • A "boot-shaped" heart with an upturned cardiac apex due to right ventricular hypertrophy and concave pulmonary arterial segment.
  • Right-sided aortic arch is seen in 25% of patients with TOF.
  • Pulmonary oligaemia due to decreased pulmonary arterial flow.

questions.text: The histological section of a nerve fibre is given. Which of the following indicates the structure marked A?
questions.solution:
Endoneurium (Henle's sheath) is a layer of delicate connective tissue around the myelin sheath of each myelinated nerve fiber.

Within the nerve, axons targeting the same anatomical location are bundled together into groups known as fascicles, each surrounded by another protective sheath known as the perineurium.

Several fascicles may be in turn bundled together with a blood supply and fatty tissue within yet another sheath, the epineurium.

questions.text: Which of the given statements is false about Acute Kidney Injury (AKI)?

choices.text: AKI can develop without injury to parenchyma of the kidney
Renal autoregulation fails once the systolic blood pressure < 80 mmHg
AKI is defined as rise of S.creatinine from baseline by at least 0.3 mg/dL in < 48 h
KIM-1 is a biomarker for detecting AKI in less than 2 hrs of cardiopulmonary bypass-associated AKI

questions.solution:
NGAL (and not KIM-1) can be detected in the plasma and urine within 2 h of cardiopulmonary bypass–associated AKI.

NGAL, KIM-1 and IL-18 are novel biomarkers for AKI. While KIM-1 is detected shortly after ischaemic or nephrotoxic injury to tubules, NGAL is detected shortly after cardiopulmonary bypass-associated AKI.

Other options:

  • AKI is defined as any of the following:
    • Increase in S. Cr by ≥0.3 mg/dl within 48 hours
    • Or, Increase in S. Cr to ≥1.5 times baseline, which is known or presumed to have occurred within the prior 7 days
    • Or, Urine volume <0.5 ml/kg/h for 6 hours.
  • A patient may have AKI without injury to the kidney parenchyma.
  • Renal autoregulation usually fails once the systolic blood pressure falls below 80 mmHg, even in healthy adults.

questions.text: A child with recurrent UTI comes to OPD for evaluation.The child passes frequent small amounts of urine with burning sensation. Voiding cystourethrography shows unilateral vesicoureteral reflux (VUR). Identify the grade as per image?
questions.solution:
Voiding cystourethrography shows vesicoureteral reflux of Grade 4, in which contrast media fill and grossly dilate the ureter and the collecting  system with blunting of calyces. Some tortuosity of ureter is also present.

VUR severity is graded is based on the appearance of the urinary tract on a contrast voiding cystourethrogram.

 

 

Grading of vesicoureteral reﬂux:

  • Grade I: VUR into a non-dilated ureter
  • Grade II: VUR into the upper collecting system without dilation
  • Grade III: VUR into dilated ureter and/or blunting of calyceal fornices
  • Grade IV: VUR into a grossly dilated tortuous ureter
  • Grade V: Massive VUR, with significant ureteral dilation and tortuosity and loss of the papillary impression.

questions.text: Consider the following subjects. Subject 1 is a 12-year-old girl who has attained puberty. Subject 2 is a 28-year-old pregnant lady. Which of the following statements is false?
questions.solution:
Among the given statements, statement C is false. Subject 1 will not have uterine hyperplasia.

Hypertrophy and hyperplasia:

  • Puberty:
    • Breast: Both hypertrophy (enlargement of the glandular epithelial cells) and hyperplasia (proliferation of the glandular epithelium) in equal proportions
    • No changes occur in the uterus
  • Pregnancy:
    • Breast: Both hypertrophy and hyperplasia in equal proportions
    • Uterus: Mainly hypertrophy (stretch‐induced myometrial hypertrophy) and also minor hyperplasia (of smooth muscle cells in the myometrium).
  • Lactation:
    • Breast: Only hypertrophy

questions.text: A peripheral smear showed small sized platelets. This is characteristic of ____________
questions.solution:
Small sized platelets on peripheral smear is a characteristic of Wiskott Aldrich syndrome.

Wiskott Aldrich syndrome: There is a mutation in the gene encoding Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (WASP), which is located on Xp11.23. The X-linked disease is characterized by thrombocytopenia, eczema, and a marked vulnerability to recurrent infection, resulting in early death.

  • Platelets are small in size.
  • There is a progressive loss of T lymphocytes in the peripheral blood and in the T-cell zones (paracortical areas) of the lymph nodes, with variable defects in cellular immunity.
  • Patients do not make antibodies to polysaccharide antigens, and the response to protein antigens is poor. They are prone to develop B-cell lymphomas.

questions.text: Fire breaks out during laser vocal cord surgery. What is not to be done?

choices.text: Treatment with bronchial lavage and steroids

questions.solution:
100% oxygen after discontinuing anesthetic gas should not be done.

  • Oxygen should be turned off, the tube should be removed and the patient should be ventilated with a face mask.
  • 100 percent oxygen may be restarted once the fire is extinguished and the patient is reintubated.

AIRWAY FIRE PROTOCOL:

  • Stop the procedure and extinguish the fire with a saline wash.
  • Stop ventilation and remove the endotracheal tube
  • Turn off the oxygen and disconnect the circuit from the machine.
  • Assess airway damage with bronchoscopy, serial chest x-ray and ABGs
  • Consider bronchial lavage and steroids
  • Ventilate with face mask and reintubate

questions.text: Maslow hierarchy is:
questions.solution:
Physiological, Safety, Belonging, Esteem, Self-actualization is the correct hierarchy of needs as described by Abraham Maslow.

Maslow described a hierarchical organization of needs present in every­ one. As the more primitive needs, such as hunger and thirst, are satisfied, more advanced psychological needs, such as affection and self-esteem, become the primary motivators. Self-actualiza­tion is the highest need. It represents the priority of human needs which determine the human behaviour.

Trivia: A peak experience, frequently occurring in self-actualizers, is an episodic, brief occurrence in which a person suddenly experiences a powerful transcendental state of consciousness-a sense of heightened understanding, an intense euphoria, an integrated nature, unity with the universe, and an altered perception of time and space. This powerful experience tends to occur most often in the psychologically healthy and can produce long-lasting beneficial effects.

Related Pearl: Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs

questions.text: Identify the procedure performed to manage a patient with chronic pancreatitis:
questions.solution:
The image shows a distal pancreatectomy with Roux-en-Y pancreaticojejunostomy indicative of the Duval procedure.

It is a drainage procedure for chronic pancreatitis. It was developed on the basis of a presumption that a single stricture of the duct of Wirsung near the ampulla was responsible for the obstructive pathology and terminal drainage would treat the condition.

This procedure has high rates of failure due to restenosis and segmental obstruction of the pancreas due to progressive scarring.

Related Pearl: Surgical procedures for chronic pancreatitis

Duval procedure: Distal pancreatectomy with Roux-en-Y pancreaticojejunostomy

Puestow procedure: Resection of tail followed by longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy

Partington and Rochelle modification of Puestow procedure: Elimination of resection of the pancreatic tail

A longitudinal pancreatotomy shows segmental stenosis of the pancreatic duct and the presence of intraductal calculi in a patient with chronic calcific pancreatitis. Following mobilization of a Roux limb of the jejunum, a longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy is performed to permit extensive drainage of the pancreatic duct system.

Related Pearl: Resection and Hybrid Surgical Procedures for Chronic Pancreatitis

Beger’s procedure: Duodenum-preserving pancreatic head resection (DPPHR)

  • The completed resection after transection of the pancreatic neck and subtotal removal of the pancreatic head, with preservation of the distal common bile duct and duodenum (Marked A).
  • Completion of the reconstruction of the anastomosis to the distal pancreas and to the proximal pancreatic rim by the same Roux limb of the jejunum.

Frey’s procedure:

  • The local resection of the pancreatic head with longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy (LR-LPJ) provides complete decompression of the entire pancreatic ductal system. Reconstruction is performed with a side-to-side Roux-en-Y pancreaticojejunostomy.

Warren’s modification of Beger’s procedure:

Berne modification (Beger + Frey) involves excavation of the central portion of the head without formal division of the neck.

(image below)

Hamburg modification of Frey’s procedure

Note:

Surgical treatments for chronic pancreatitis

Resection

  • Pancreaticoduodenectomy (Kausch–Whipple procedure)
  • Pylorus-preserving pancreaticoduodenectomy (Traverso–Longmire)
  • Beger procedure
  • Near-total or total pancreatectomy

Decompression/Drainage

  • Duval procedure
  • Puestow–Gillesby procedure
  • Partington–Rochelle procedure (Puestow)
  • Izbicki procedure

Hybrid (resection+decompression)

  • Frey procedure
  • Hamburg modification
  • Berne modification

questions.text: A tall boy with ocular and skeletal abnormalities was found to have fibrillin 1 mutation. This disease has ___________ inheritance.
questions.solution:
Fibrillin 1 mutation is seen in marfan’s syndrome, which shows autosomal dominant inheritance.

Fibrillin occurs in two homologous forms fibrillin-1 and fibrillin-2, encoded by two separate genes, FBN1 and FBN2, mapped on chromosomes 15q21.1 and 5q23.31 respectively.

Mutations of FBN1 cause Marfan syndrome; mutations of the related FBN2 gene are less common, and they give rise to congenital contractural arachnodactyly.

questions.text: Erythema gyratum repens is most commonly associated with which of the following malignancies?

choices.text: Glucagon secreting pancreatic islet cell adenoma

questions.solution:
Erythema gyratum repens is most commonly associated with Lung malignancy.

Erythema gyratum repens was considered to be a paraneoplastic dermatosis. The most frequent underlying malignancy was carcinoma of the lung (47%) followed by oesophagus, breast, stomach, kidney cervix and haematological neoplasia. Treatment of the cancer usually resulted in clearance of infection.

However, erythema gyratum repens has now been described even in the absence of an underlying malignancy. It has been associated with pityriasis rubra pilaris, psoriasis, ichthyosis, mycobacterial infections and connective tissue diseases.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs causes carcinoma bladder?
questions.solution:
Cyclophosphamide (an alkylating agent) causes bladder cancer

The risk of bladder cancer with cyclophosphamide is directly proportional to the duration and intensity of cyclophosphamide treatment. Phosphoramide mustard is the primary mutagenic metabolite that causes bladder cancer in patients exposed to cyclophosphamide.

Painless, gross hematuria is the most common symptom that is indicative of a bladder carcinoma until proven otherwise. 

Depending upon the depth of invasion, bladder carcinoma can be divided into 

  1. Flat, non-invasive carcinoma in situ (CIS)
  2. Non-muscle invasive bladder cancer (70% of cases) - does not invade detrusor muscle but can invade lamina propria. 
  3. Muscle-invasive bladder cancer - invades the detrusor muscle.

Diagnosis is by cystourethroscopy (directly visualizing the growth) and biopsy. Management is as follows: 

  1. Non-muscle invasive bladder cancer:
    1. Transurethral resection of bladder tumor (TURBT) followed by intravesical chemotherapy with mitomycin C or epirubicin
    2. Immunotherapy with regular intravesical instillations of Bacille Calmette Guerin (BCG) in high-risk tumors.
  2. Muscle invasive bladder cancer: Radical cystectomy along with urinary diversion procedure and lymph node dissection +/- neoadjuvant chemotherapy

Other options:

Option B: Cisplatin is an anticancer drug used to treat testicular cancer. It is associated with an increased risk for acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

Option C: Taxane is an anticancer drug and is the main component in the treatment regimens of metastatic cancers. Taxane's adverse effects are neutropenia and fluid retention (pulmonary edema).

Option D: Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) and is used in the treatment of estrogen-dependent breast cancer. Due to its partial agonistic activity, it is known to increase endometrial cancer in post-menopausal women.

  • Activating mutations in RAS and PI-3 kinase

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient was brought to casualty in an unconscious state after a head injury. What is the name of the sign seen in this image?
questions.solution:
The sign seen in the image is the battle sign i.e. a skull base fracture associated with bruising over the mastoid process.

Skull base fractures are associated with:

  • CSF otorrhea or rhinorrhea
  • Hemotympanum
  • Tympanic membrane rupture
  • Battle sign: Bruising or ecchymosis behind the ear
  • 7th and 8th cranial nerve palsies

Other options:

Option A-Duret hemorrhages are delayed secondary brainstem hemorrhages. They occur in craniocerebral trauma victims with rapidly evolving descending transtentorial herniation. They are typically located in the ventral and paramedian aspects of the upper brainstem.

Option B- Kernohan phenomenon is an imaging finding resulting from extensive midline shift due to mass effect, resulting in an indentation in the contralateral cerebral crus by the tentorium cerebelli. 

Option D- Racoon eyes refer to bilateral periorbital bruising, seen in anterior cranial fossa fractures. (image given below)

Related Pearl: Signs of base of skull fracture

Signs of Base of Skull Fracture

  • Bilateral periorbital haematoma (raccoon eyes)
  • Battle’s sign (bruising over mastoid)
  • CSF rhinorrhoea or otorrhoea
  • Haemotympanum or bleeding from ear

questions.text: A 65 years alcoholic suffering from diabetes has a flexion deformity at right little finger over metacarpophalangeal(MCP)  joint of around 15 degree. The ideal management for him:
questions.solution:
As per the case scenario the patient is alcoholic and diabetes both risk factor of duputryen’s contracture and flexion deformity at MCP points towards the diagnosis of duputryen’s contracture.

Since the patient is elderly and flexion deformity at right little finger is 15 degree only its better left alone ie. Wait and watch.

Primary indication for surgery is fixed contracture of >30 degree  at MCP joint or >15 degree at proximal interphalangeal joint. Surgery doesn’t cure the disease it just partially corrects the deformity.

Amputation is often advisable for severe, recurrent disease in little finger.

questions.text: A G2P1 obese woman was diagnosed with arrest of descent during labour. Identify the following manoeuvre performed for this patient.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of shoulder dystocia and the manoeuvre shown above is the McRoberts manoeuvre. This is the most effective intervention and should be the first manoeuvre to be performed in shoulder dystocia. 

McRoberts manoeuvre:

  • Flexion and abduction of the maternal hips (positioning the maternal thighs on her abdomen).
  • The pelvic rotation which occurs due to the straightening of the sacrum tends to free the impacted anterior shoulder of the baby. 
  • Suprapubic pressure may be used simultaneously.
  • The lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh is the most common nerve to get injured during this manoeuvre.

If the first line of management fails, proceed with internal rotational manoeuvres such as Rubin's and Wood corkscrew in McRoberts position.

Rubin's manoeuvre:

  • Internal rotational manoeuver used to deliver the baby in case of shoulder dystocia.
  • It involves dislodging the easily accessible shoulder towards the anterior aspect of the chest from under the pubic symphysis by 30-45° while staying in the McRoberts' position. 
  • Pressure is applied on the scapular aspect (posteriorly) of the shoulder.

Wood corkscrew manoeuvre:

  • Internal rotational manoeuver used to deliver the baby in case of shoulder dystocia.
  • It involves dislodging the posterior shoulder by 180° in a corkscrew fashion to lie beneath the pubic symphysis while staying in McRobert's position.
  • Pressure is applied on the clavicular aspect (anteriorly) of the shoulder.

questions.text: The inferior gemellus muscle is supplied by
questions.solution:
The medial circumflex femoral artery supplies inferior gemellus muscle.

The gemelli are two narrow and triangular muscles, in the gluteal region. They are separated by the obturator internus tendon.

Arterial supply:

  • Gemellus superior - by the internal pudendal artery, the inferior gluteal artery; and sometimes by the superior gluteal artery.
  • Gemellus inferior - by the medial circumflex femoral artery.

questions.text: All of the following antibiotics can be given for the treatment of an infected human bite, except?
questions.solution:
Cephalexin, is ineffective against Eikenella corrodens, an important pathogen in infected human bites.

The current recommendations call for treatment with Ampicillin/Sulbactam or Amoxicillin/clavulanate.

Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole or a quinolone such as levofloxacin or moxifloxacin are acceptable alternatives in patients with a penicillin allergy.

questions.text: Which of the following tests would you use to differentiate between nevus anemicus and vitiligo in a patient?
questions.solution:
Diascopy is a test that helps to differentiate between nevus anemicus and vitiligo.

Nevus anemicus is secondary to a localized area of vasoconstriction, and diascopy of the adjacent skin reveals a color identical to that of the ‘depigmented’ area, since other pigments are unaltered. In vitiligo, the lesion appears paler, since there is a loss of melanin.

Diascopy is a clinical maneuver performed to assess superficial erythema in dermatological conditions. In this procedure, a glass slide or a stiff, clear, colorless piece of plastic is pressed onto the skin to compress blood out of small vessels, in order to allow evaluation of other colors. Vessels can be seen to blanch and fill, by varying the amount of pressure on the skin, which is different for different conditions.

The purpose of this procedure is to empty blood from the superficial vessels to determine if skin redness is due to blood present within the vessels or extravasated onto the skin.

Diascopy is of particular value in the following conditions:

  • Granulomatous conditions: A translucent brownish color is seen on diascopy, known as ‘apple jelly’ nodules. They are seen in all 3 of sarcoidosis, granuloma annulare, and lupus vulgaris.
  • Differentiation between nevus anemicus and nevus depigmentosus: On diascopy, nevus anemicus (congenital white patch of vasoconstriction) becomes indistinguishable with the merging of the lesion into the surrounding skin. However, the border of nevus depigmentosus remains unaltered after diascopy.
  • Spider nevus: Application of medium pressure to a spider nevus can compress radiating arterioles and allow visualization of pulsatile flow in the feeding vessel.
  • Differentiation between erythema (vasodilation) and purpura (extravasated blood): Erythema blanches on compression of vessels, while purpura and petechiae do not blanch on compression.

Wood's lamp examination can also be used to distinguish between vitiligo and nevus anemicus.

In vitiligo, the depigmented areas appear milky white, due to a loss of melanin, while in nevus anemicus, the pallor completely disappears, since it is secondary to localized vasoconstriction.

questions.text: Refsum disease is due to:

choices.text: Absence of alpha oxidation in peroxisomes
Absence of beta oxidation in peroxisomes
Absence of alpha oxidation in lysosomes
Absence of beta oxidation in lysosomes

questions.solution:
Refsum disease is due to the absence of alpha oxidation in peroxisomes.

Refsum's disease is a rare autosomal recessive disorder. The defective enzyme is phytanoyl CoA hydroxylase, which causes alpha oxidation of fatty acids and leads to elevated levels of phytanic acid in the blood.

Clinical features are dysmorphic facies and severe neurological symptoms such as polyneuropathy, retinitis pigmentosa, nerve deafness, ichthyosis, and cerebellar ataxia.

Restricted dietary intake of phytanic acid reduces the symptoms. Management includes avoiding sources of phytanic acid such as dairy products, meat, nuts, and green leafy vegetables.

Related Pearl: Types, Location and Properties of Fatty acid oxidation

Types of Oxidation

Location

Properties

Associated Disease

Beta oxidation

Mitochondria

A catabolic process by which two-carbons are cleaved from the fatty acid molecule and released as acetyl CoA starting from the carboxyl end.

The chain is broken between the α(2) and β(3) carbon.

1 round of beta-oxidation yield 1FADH2, 1NADH, and 1 Acetyl CoA.

  

Alpha oxidation

Peroxisome

The presence of the 3-methyl group of phytanic acid prevents degradation by beta-oxidation.

The chain is broken between the terminal carboxyl group and α(2) carbon removing that carbon as CO2. The remaining chain is activated with CoA and then undergoes β-Oxidation.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

Classic Refsum's Disease

Defective enzyme- Phytanoyl Coa hydroxylase.

Clinical features include:

Ichthyosis, Retinitis pigmentosa, Decreased vision, Peripheral neuropathy, Ataxia

 

Omega oxidation

Endoplasmic Reticulum

An alternative pathway to beta-oxidation occurs in microsomes.

Involves the oxidation of the ω carbon (terminal methyl group) resulting in dicarboxylic acid.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

  

Peroxisomal Beta oxidation

Peroxisome

Very-long-chain fatty acids undergo preliminary β-oxidation in peroxisomes up to octanoyl CoA. The shortened fatty acids undergo further β-oxidation in the mitochondria.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

Zellweger (cerebrohepatorenal) syndrome

A rare inherited absence of peroxisomes in all tissues.

They accumulate C26—C38 polyenoic acids in brain tissue and also exhibit a generalized loss of peroxisomal functions. The disease causes severe neurologic symptoms, and most patients die in the first year of life.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female had complaints of weakness and easy fatiguability. The hemogram showed Hb- 5.8 g/dL, TLC- 1200, platelet- 60,000 , MCV- 102 fl, MCH- 40 pg/cell. The peripheral smear is as given below. Which of the following may be a cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The haemogram shows decreased cell counts across all three lineages, raised MCV and MCH, macroovalocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils. These findings are suggestive of megaloblastic anemia, which is caused by vitamin B12 deficiency.

Megaloblastic anemia results from impairment of DNA synthesis that leads to ineffective hematopoiesis. Since vitamin B12 and folic acid are required as coenzymes in the synthesis of DNA, their deficiency results in defective nuclear maturation

Peripheral smear findings of megaloblastic anemia are as follows :

  • Macro-ovalocytes, which are highly characteristic
  • Most macrocytes lack the central pallor of normal red cells and even appear hyperchromic, but the MCHC is not elevated.
  • The reticulocyte count is low.
  • Nucleated red cell progenitors occasionally appear in the circulating blood when anemia is severe.
  • Neutrophils are also larger than normal (macro polymorphonuclear) and show nuclear hypersegmentation, having five or more nuclear lobules.

Bone marrow study would reveal :

  • Markedly hypercellular marrow, as a result of increased hematopoietic precursors.
  • The nuclei of the normoblasts retain the finely distributed chromatin. While nuclear maturation is delayed, cytoplasmic maturation and hemoglobin accumulation proceed at a normal pace, leading to nuclear-to-cytoplasmic asynchrony.
  • Granulocytic precursors also display dysmaturation in the form of giant metamyelocytes and band forms.
  • Megakaryocytes, too, can be abnormally large and have bizarre, multilobate nuclei.
  • The derangement in DNA synthesis causes most precursors to undergo apoptosis in the marrow (ineffective hematopoiesis) and leads to pancytopenia.

Other options :

Option A - Iron deficiency results in decreased MCV and MCH (microcytic, hypochromic blood picture).

Option C - Although aplastic anemia is characterized by pancytopenia, hypersegmented neutrophils are not a finding.

Option D - Intravascular hemolysis does not account for the decreased WBC and platelet count, nor does it cause hypersegmented neutrophils.

Related Pearl: Causes of Megaloblastic Anemia

Vitamin B12 Deficiency causes:

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Vegetarianism
  • Impaired Absorption
    • Intrinsic factor deficiency
    • Pernicious anemia
    • Gastrectomy
    • Malabsorption states
    • Diffuse intestinal disease (e.g., lymphoma, systemic sclerosis)
    • Ileal resection
    • Ileitis
  • Competitive parasitic uptake
    • Fish tapeworm infestation
    • Bacterial overgrowth in blind loops and diverticula of bowel

Folic Acid Deficiency causes:

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Alcoholism
    • Infancy
  • Impaired Absorption
    • Malabsorption states
    • Intrinsic intestinal disease
    • Anticonvulsants
    • Oral contraceptives
  • Increased Loss
    • Hemodialysis
  • Increased Requirement
    • Pregnancy, infancy
    • Disseminated cancer
    • Markedly increased hematopoiesis
  • Impaired Utilization
    • Folic acid antagonists
    • Unresponsive to vitamin B12 or folic acid therapy
    • Metabolic inhibitors of DNA synthesis and/or folate metabolism

questions.text: Which of the following is a feature of slow-twitching muscle fibers ?

choices.text: It has high myosin ATPase activity
Contains higher amount of glycolytic capacity

questions.solution:
Slow twitching muscle fibers have a large amount of myoglobin.

They have small fibers with low ATPase activity and moderate glycolytic capacity.

Type of muscle fibers:

All the muscles of our body contain a mixture of two types of muscle fibers: slow and fast

Slow fibers (type I):

  • They respond slowly and have a prolonged contraction.
  • These fibers are mainly present in muscles involved in maintaining the posture (Ex. soleus).
  • The prolonged contraction of these fibers is facilitated by the presence of abundant mitochondria and myoglobin.
  • The myoglobin stores oxygen and helps in rapid transport of oxygen to the mitochondria.
  • The presence of myoglobin imparts a red colour to these fibers. Hence they are also called red muscles.

Fast fibers (type II):

  • They respond rapidly and act for a short duration, but have greater strength of contraction.
  • They are present in muscles requiring rapid movement (Ex. tibialis anterior, ocular muscles).
  • These fibers have fewer mitochondria.
  • Type IIa fibers are red in colour due to the presence of some amount of myoglobin and are thus resistant to fatigue.
  • Type IIb fibers are white in colour as they lack myoglobin. Hence they are easily fatiguable.

questions.text: Lipoprotein with least protein content is____________
questions.solution:
Lipoprotein with least protein content is chylomicron.

Chylomicron: Since they have least protein content, they remain at the origin(at cathode) during electrophoresis. HDL with highest protein content moves fastest.

Chylomicron has maximum triacylglycerol. It carries dietary triacylglycerol from intestine to peripheral tissues. And carries dietary cholesterol to the liver.

questions.text: While inspecting a crime scene of a murder case, whiskey glasses were found on the table. The latent prints from the glass can be visualized by all, except ___________.
questions.solution:
Pearson method is not used for the visualization of latent fingerprints. Pearson method is used for the estimation of stature from a skeleton. All other options given can be used for the visualization of latent prints.

Latent prints are those that are left behind through interaction of hands, palms, and feet with the environment. Occasionally, these prints are left cleanly so as to be clearly visible to the unaided eye. It is more often the case that the prints are only partially visible or not visible at all without the use of specialized fingerprint-processing methods and equipment.

Methods to enhance fingerprints:

  • Lighting - White light, photoluminescence, ultraviolet spectrum lighting
  • Physical - Dusting a surface with a fine powder of contrasting color
  • Chemical - Ninhydrin, Cyanoacrylate fuming, silver nitrate

Powders used:

  • White : Lead carbonate
  • Black  : Charcoal
  • Grey : Aluminium dust OR chalk powder + mercury

questions.text: All of the following are contents of mesorectal fascia except
questions.solution:
Inferior rectal vein is not enclosed in mesorectal fascia.

Rectum has no mesentery, its surrounding fat is enclosed within a fascial envelope known as the mesorectum. It constitutes a distinct compartment enclosed by the mesorectal fascia. 

Contents of mesorectal fascia:

  • Superior rectal artery and its branches, lymphatic vessels and nodes along it.
  • Superior rectal vein and its tributaries
  • Branches from inferior mesenteric plexus
  • Loose adipose connective tissue

Mesorectum is enclosed in mesorectal fascia also called as presacral wing of hypogastric sheath derived from visceral peritoneum.

The clinical importance is that mesorectum and outermost perirectal fascia act as barrier to the spread of the cancer and constitute the surgical “circumferential margin”.

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of AIDS presents to the OPD with fever, chills, malaise, weight loss, and cutaneous lesions as shown in the image. Warthin starry staining reveals large clusters of bacteria. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture & image suggest the diagnosis as bacillary angiomatosis. It is the second-most-common cause of angiomatous skin lesions in persons infected with HIV.

Bacillary angiomatosis is a vascular, proliferative form of Bartonella infection that occurs primarily in immunocompromised persons. It can be caused by either Bartonella henselae or Bartonella quintana.

Cutaneous lesions due to bacillary angiomatosis may take one of the following forms:

  • Solitary or multiple red, purple, flesh-colored, or colorless papules (hemangioma-like lesions) varying in size from 1 mm to several centimeters.
  • Nodules, often covered with a fine, tightly adherent scale
  • Large polypoid exophytic masses

Visceral involvement associated with bacillary angiomatosis may cause fever, chills, malaise, night sweats, anorexia, and weight loss.

Diagnosis: Most often based on clinical features coupled with biopsies of lesions. Detection of Bartonella DNA in tissue specimens by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) assay or of Bartonella antigens by immunohistochemical methods is diagnostic. Warthin starry staining reveals large clusters of bacteria. 

Failure to distinguish Kaposi sarcoma from bacillary angiomatosis is problematic because bacillary angiomatosis, unlike Kaposi sarcoma, responds dramatically to antibiotic therapy. Furthermore, bacillary angiomatosis may be life-threatening if untreated. Treatment: Erythromycin or doxycycline for 3 months.

questions.text: The most consistent sign seen in fresh fractures is
questions.solution:
Tenderness over the fracture site is the single most consistent sign present in every fracture.

In an incomplete and impacted or undisplaced fracture, local tenderness is the only sign.

Crepitus, abnormal mobility, deformity cannot be elicited in undisplaced fractures, stress fractures, impacted fractures etc.

Most consistent symptom of fracture is pain.

Pathognomic sign of traumatic fracture is crepitus.

 

Note: in some books the answer is given as crepitus but its wrong as its can be elicited in the displaced fractures only.

questions.text: Adjuvant used in DPT vaccine is :
questions.solution:
Aluminium phosphate or aluminium hydroxide is used as adjuvant in DPT vaccine. It increases immunogenicity of the vaccine.

Thiomersal is used as preservative in DPT vaccine.

questions.text: The most effective bariatric surgery for morbid obesity among  the following options is:
questions.solution:
The most effective bariatric surgery for morbid obesity among the following options is biliopancreatic diversion.

Following table represents Malabsorption,percent excess weight loss and diabetic remission after various bariartic surgery:

  Protein/calorie  malabsorption 3year %EWL 3year%diabetes remission
Gastric band No 40-50% 20%
Gastric bypass No 50-60% 50%
Sleeve gastrectomy No 50-60% 50%
Bilio pancreatic diversion/Duodenal switch Yes 70-80% 80%

%EWL =Excess weight lost above a notional upper normal BMI of 25.

Laproscopic adjustable gastric banding is the safest and reversible bariatric surgery.

Bariatric surgery:

Indications:

  • Patients with BMI greater than equal to 40kg/m2 regardless of comorbidity.
  • Patients with BMI greater or equal to 35 kg/m2 with comorbidity.

     Restrictive  Bariatric surgeries

    • Laparoscopic adjustable gastric banding
    • Laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy

     Restrictive and malabsorptive bypass surgeries

    • Roux-en-Y gastric bypass - M/C bypass procedure(Largely restrictive/Mildly malabsorptive)
    • Biliopancreatic diversion(Largely malabsorptive /Mildly restrictive)
    • Biliopancreatic diversion with duodenal switch (Largely malabsorptive /Mildly restrictive)

 

 

Metabolic surgery refers to the marked effects of some operations on diabetes and the metabolic syndrome (including high blood pressure, dyslipidaemia and polycystic ovary syndrome), which may have an impact more important than weight loss itself.

The improvement in type 2 diabetes may be additional to the weight loss

Surgery is very cost effective since medications can be reduced or stopped once the glycaemic control improves post operatively.

questions.text: A patient of PID with acute salpingitis and peritonitis, is said to have PID stage _________
questions.solution:
Stage II of Pelvic Inflammatory Disease involves acute salpingitis with peritonitis.

Pelvic Inflammatory disease involves inflammation of the upper genital tract including the fallopian tubes as well as the ovaries. The spectrum ranges from mild to moderate to severe.

Depending on the severity of tubal damage, it is classified into 5 stages by Gainsville:

  • Stage 1: Acute salpingitis without peritonitis.
  • Stage 2: Acute salpingitis with peritonitis.
  • Stage 3: Acute salpingitis with superimposed tubal occlusion or tubo-ovarian complex.
  • Stage 4: Ruptured tubo-ovarian abscess.
  • Stage 5: Tubercular salpingitis.

Related Pearl: Organisms Responsible for Pelvic Inflammatory Disease

Sexually transmitted: Gonococcus, Chlamydia, Mycoplasma, Trichomonas 
Aerobes: Staphylococci , Streptococci ,E. coli
Anaerobes: Bacteroides fragilis, Peptococcus, Clostridium, Actinomyces (IUD)
Others: Tubercular salpingitis
 

Related Pearl: Treatment of choice in chronic PID

Patient characteristics

Choice of surgery

Young woman

Conservative surgery or Salpingectomy or Salpingo-oophorectomy

When extensive damage precludes conservative management

and

When the patient is multiparous and of an older age group

Abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy

Mild case of PID adequately treated

and

Minimal damage but the infection may lead to infertility

Tuboplasty

questions.text: An anesthesia resident was giving spinal anesthesia when the patient developed sudden aphonia and loss of consciousness. What could have happened?
questions.solution:
Development of sudden aphonia and loss of consciousness while giving spinal anesthesia is suggestive of vasovagal attack.

Often occurs in young, nervous and anxious patients during injection in a sitting position.

Other option:

In total spinal anesthesia loss of consciousness is immediately after injection with a dramatic course with non recordable bp, respiratory arrest, severe hypotension.

Related Pearl: High Yield Points in spinal anesthesia

  • The normal extent of the spinal cord is the lower border of L1 in adults and the upper border of L3 in infants.
  • First spinal anesthesia was given by Augustin Bier.
  • It is injected into the space between L3-L4 in adults and L4-L5 in children.
  • The deposition of the drug is in the subarachnoid space.
  • The subarachnoid space ends at S2 in adults and S3 in children.
  • Traumatic needle- Quincke
  • Atraumatic needle- Sprotte
  • Structures pierced- Ligamentum flavum, interspinous ligament, supraspinous ligament. (Posterior longitudinal ligament is NOT punctured)
  • The first fibres to be blocked- Autonomic preganglionic.
  • The last fibres to be blocked- Motor.
  • The last fibres to recover- Preganglionic autonomic.
  • Levels of anesthetic effect - Autonomic level is 2 segments above the sensory, which is 2 segments above the motor.
  • The most common complication is hypotension.
  • Brewer Luckhardt reflex- Reflex hypotension due to parasympathetic stress at a different site. 
  • Paramedian spinal anesthesia prevents penetration of the supraspinous and interspinous ligaments.
  • Anesthetics in a paravertebral block are least likely to diffuse into subarachnoid space.
  • The lowest incidence of post-spinal headache is when a thin needle is used.
  • A high level of spinal injection causes hypotension and bradycardia.
  • The vasopressor of choice in hypotension produced during the subarachnoid block is phenylephrine.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the first-trimester ultrasound?

choices.text: A gestational sac can first be seen 4 weeks after LMP
Accuracy of USG dating decreases after the 1st trimester
Yolk sac is the first sign of pregnancy on USG
A normal gestational sac implants in the midline of the endometrial cavity

questions.solution:
The accuracy of determining gestational age using ultrasound is the highest in the first trimester and decreases afterwards.

Option A: Gestational sac is reliably seen at 5 weeks of gestation on transvaginal sonography(TVS).

Option C: The first sign of pregnancy seen on sonography is the gestational sac. Visualisation of the yolk sac within the gestational sac confirms an intrauterine location for pregnancy. 

Option D: A normal gestational sac implants eccentrically in the endometrium, whereas a pseudosac is seen in the midline of the endometrial cavity.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true about the levator ani?

1) It arises from the condensation of the obturator fascia
2) It consists of 2 muscle components
3) Puborectalis and pubococcygeus create the anorectal angle
4) Its contraction leads to defecation and urination
5) It is innervated by S3 and S4 sacral segments
questions.solution:
The true statements about levator ani are options 1, 3 and 5. 

The levator ani muscle is a complex unit, which consists of 3 muscle components namely:

  • Pubococcygeus - the fibres of this muscle is further divided into - 
    • Pubovaginalis - elevates the urethra and hence contributes to urinary continence
    • Puboperinealis - draws the perineal body towards the pubic symphysis
    • Puboanalis - elevates the anus and keeps the urogenital hiatus narrowed
  • Puborectalis
  • Iliococcygeus

Levator ani arises from condensations of the obturator fascia. It is inserted into the coccyx and the anococcygeal raphe or ligament. The branches of the anterior rami of sacral nerves S3 and S4 innervate this muscle. 

It is one of the most important muscles in the pelvic floor and maintains a constant state of contraction. They provide a stable floor and support the weight of the abdominopelvic contents against intra-abdominal forces. The vaginal, urethral and rectal lumen is obstructed by the contraction of the levator ani and relaxation of the muscle is needed for defecation and urination. Puborectalis and pubococcygeus, help maintain the rectal tone as well as create the anorectal angle.

questions.text: Identify the X-ray radiographic view of skull as shown in the image below
questions.solution:
• Waters' view (also known as the Occipitomental view) is a radiographic view, where an X-ray beam is angled at 45° to the orbitomeatal line.
  • The rays are passed from behind the head and are perpendicular to the radiographic plate.
  • It is commonly used to get a better view of the maxillary sinuses.

Structures observed:

  • Maxillary sinuses
  • Frontal sinuses (oblique view)
  • Ethmoidal cells
  • Sphenoid sinus (through open mouth)
  • Odontoid process (if it is just below the mentum, it confirms adequate extension of the head

 

Other views:

 

  • Schuller's view is a lateral radiographic view of skull principally used for viewing mastoid cells.
  • The central beam of X-rays passes from one side of the head and is at angle of 25° caudal to radiographic plate.
  • This angulation prevents overlap of images of two mastoid bones.
  • Caldwell's view (or Occipitofrontal view) is a radiographic view of skull, where X-ray plate is angled at 20° to orbitomeatal line.
  • The rays pass from behind the head and are perpendicular to radiographic plate.
  • It is commonly used to get better view of frontal sinuses.

Towne view:

  • It is taken with the patient in the supine position and lying on his back with the chin often depressed into the neck.
  • The X-ray camera is angled at 30 degrees towards the feet so that the rays enter the head at the level of the hair-line.
  • The result is clear image of the posterior portion of the skull including the foramen magnum.

Related Pearl: Radiographic views of paranasal sinuses and mastoid

Related Pearl: Radiographic views of temporal bone

questions.text: Which species of chlamydia classically infect parrots and transmit the disease to humans via inhalation?
questions.solution:
Chlamydia psittaci classically infect parrots (and also other birds) and produce a subclinical infection in them. Chlamydia psittaci are shed in their droppings or nasal discharge. Humans are infected via inhalation. It is mostly seen in poultry workers, vets, pigeon farmers, etc.

Chlamydia psittaci have inclusion bodies called Levinthal Cole Lillie (LCL) bodies which are diffuse and irregular, not stained by iodine and not inhibited by sulphadiazine or cycloserine.

questions.text: A 35 yrs old pregnant female complaining of hearing loss, which aggravated during pregnancy, was sent for tympanometry. Which of the following type of graph will be seen?
questions.solution:
Most probably the patient is suffering from otosclerosis, which is more common in females and aggravated during pregnancy. Type As tympanogram is seen in otosclerosis.

Types of tympanogram:

questions.text: Identify the ionizing radiation -
questions.solution:
The image is of beta rays as it can penetrate paper but stopped by few millimeters of aluminium.

Beta particle is a high energy, high speed electron or positron which can penetrate paper and can be stopped by a few millimetres of aluminium. The range of beta rays depends on their initial energy and electron density of the material.

Typical ranges in tissue are a few millimetres, in air the range may go to several meters. Beta particles cause damage to tissue in a similar manner to alpha rays but less severely.

Related Pearl: Ionising and penetrating ability of radiation

  • Penetration power: Gamma rays > X-rays > Beta particle > Alpha particle (helium ion)
  • Ionising or tissue damaging ability: Alpha particle (helium ion) > Beta particle > X-ray > Gamma ray
  • Alpha waves have the highest molecular mass

questions.text: Which of the following agents is not used for induced hypotension during surgery?
questions.solution:
Mephentermine is an alpha adrenergic agonist and not used as an agent for induced hypotension during surgery.

It is used to treat hypotension and maintain blood pressure that is adequate for CNS perfusion. This may be advantageous in patients with hypotension due to failure of the sympathetic nervous system (e.g., after spinal anesthesia or injury). However, in patients with other forms of shock, such as cardiogenic shock, reflex vasoconstriction generally is intense, and α receptor agonists may further compromise blood flow to organs such as the kidneys and gut and adversely increase the work of the heart.

Drugs used for controlled(induced hypotension):-

vasodilators:  nitroprusside, nitroglycerine, hydralazine

beta blockers: esmolol, fenoldopam, adenosine and alprostadil are new hypotensive drugs.

Related Pearl: Hypotensive Anesthesia

Defined as:

  • Reduction of the systolic blood pressure to 80-90 mmHg, or 
  • Reduction of mean arterial pressure (MAP) to 50-65 mmHg, or
  • Reduction of MAP to 30% of baseline.

Controlled hypotension has been used to reduce bleeding and the need for blood transfusions, and provide a satisfactory bloodless surgical field.

It has been indicated in Oro-maxillofacial surgery (mandibular osteotomy, facial repair), endoscopic sinus or middle ear microsurgery, spinal surgery and other neurosurgery (an aneurysm), major orthopedic surgery (hip or knee replacement, spinal), prostatectomy, cardiovascular surgery and liver transplant surgery.

Agents used successfully include inhalation anesthetics, sodium nitroprusside, nitroglycerin, trimethaphan camsilate, clonidine, phentolamine, beta blockers, remifentanil, and agents used in spinal anesthesia for orthopedic surgeries

Newer hypotensive drugs, such as fenoldopam, adenosine, and alprostadil, are currently being evaluated.

questions.text: Which of the following vessel is not ligated in case of epistaxis control?
questions.solution:
The internal carotid artery is not ligated as it is the main vessel supplying the central nervous system.

When all the methods of epistaxis control fail, surgical ligation of vessels or embolization is the last resort of control of epistaxis.

Hierarchy of ligation: Sphenopalatine artery > Internal maxillary artery > External carotid artery > anterior/posterior ethmoidal artery.

questions.text: Deficiency of Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyl transferase (HGPRTase) can lead to _____________
questions.solution:
Deficiency of HGPRTase can lead to both, lesch nyhan syndrome and Kelley seegmiller syndrome.

Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is a rare, X-linked, recessive disorder associated with a virtually complete deficiency of Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyl transferase (HGPRT). This deficiency results in an inability to salvage hypoxanthine or guanine, from which excessive amounts of uric acid, the end product of purine degradation, are produced.

Kelley-Seegmiller syndrome: There is partial HGPRT deficiency. It manifests as a gout-urolithiasis syndrome.

questions.text: All of the following are type IV hypersensitivity reactions except:
questions.solution:
Polyarteritis nodosa is a type III hypersensitivity reaction, not type IV.

Type IV hypersensitivity reactions (delayed hypersensitivity reactions): These reactions are induced by sensitized T cells which on contact with the specific antigen, release cytokines that produce biological effects on leucocytes, macrophages, and tissue cells.

Examples of type IV hypersensitivity reactions include sarcoidosis, leprosy, type I lepra reaction, tuberculosis, psoriasis, inflammatory bowel disease, multiple sclerosis, and type 1 diabetes mellitus, contact dermatitis.

Type III hypersensitivity reactions: These reactions are induced by immune complexes which deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating the complement system. The inflammatory reaction causes tissue injury.

Other examples of type III hypersensitivity reactions include systemic lupus erythematosus, serum sickness, arthus reaction, post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, rheumatoid arthritis, and type II lepra reaction.

Related Pearl: Examples of Type IV Hypersensitivity

Type IV Hypersensitivity Reactions

  • Lepromin test
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Chronic graft rejection
  • Contact dermatitis
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Primary biliary cirrhosis
  • Type I lepra reaction
  • Crohn’s disease
  • Psoriasis

questions.text: The post mortem change shown in the given image is _____________
questions.solution:
The image shows postmortem marbling.

Postmortem marbling: It starts in 24 hours and becomes prominent in 36-48 hours. It is greenish brown or purplish red discoloration of superficial veins due to formation of sulphmethemoglobin which diffuses into tissues.

Bruise:

  • Due to ruptured vessels either superficial or deep
  • Situated anywhere at the site of blunt trauma
  • Margins irregular
  • Swelling and abrasion present

Postmortem lividity:

  • Due to engorged vessels showing through skin
  • On dependent parts
  • Margins clearly defined
  • No swelling or abrasion

Zasko’s phenomenon/tendon reaction is related to muscular changes following death. It is elicited in quadriceps femoris muscle. Striking the lower third of the muscle about 10 cms above the patella with a reflex hammer causes upward movement of patella due to contraction of the muscle. It can be seen 1 to 2 hours after death.

questions.text: All of the following are true about the instrument shown in the image given below except-

choices.text: It is used for the localization of a foreign body.
It is used for the measurement of the angle of the posterior chamber.
It is used for the demonstration of the extent of peripheral anterior synechiae.
It provides a mirror image of the opposite angle.

questions.solution:
The given instrument is an indirect gonioscope, which is used to visualize the angle of the anterior chamber, i.e., for gonioscopy, and not the angle of the posterior chamber.

Types:

  • Indirect gonioprism- provides mirror image of the opposite angle.
  • Direct goniolens- provides a direct view of the angle

Application:

  • To view the angle of the anterior chamber
  • Localization of the foreign body, abnormal blood vessels, or tumors in the angle
  • Demonstration of the extent of peripheral anterior synechiae
  • Direct goniolens can be used during goniotomy

questions.text: The sign shown in the image given below is seen in ______________
questions.solution:
The image depicts romana’s sign seen in Chagas disease. Inoculation of the parasite T. cruzi in conjunctiva causes unilateral, painless edema of periocular tissues in the eye called as Romana’s sign.

  • This is classically seen in acute chagas disease.
  • Acute chagas disease occurs soon after infection and may last for 1 to 4 months.

Some additional points:

  • Chagoma is a typical lesion occurring in acute chagas disease at the site of inoculation.
  • Chronic chagas disease is characterized by Mega esophagus, Mega colon and Myopathy (MMM).

Other options:

Option b:The protozoan disease giardiasis can cause ocular complications, including “salt and pepper” retinal changes. 

Option c:Ocular findings in cutaneous leishmaniasis represent a local phenomenon resulting from the initial site of infection near the eye with occasional spread to the lacrimal duct. Ptosis may be a presenting complaint . If the initial bite occurs on the conjunctival mucosa, the disease is termed mucocutaneous leishmaniasis. This state may lead to severe ulceration and possible loss of the eye.

Option d:Visceral leishmaniasis, or that which represents systemic disease, is known as kala-azar. The ocular manifestations of kala-azar are relatively uncommon and include chorioretinitis, central retinal vein thrombosis, iritis, papillitis, and keratitis . Additionally, flame-shaped retinal hemorrhages have been described. Glaucoma has been reported to develop after the successful treatment of kala-azar.

questions.solution:

Option C: Aconite poisoning: The characteristic finding of aconite toxicity is numbness and tingling.

questions.text: The presence of an intravenous cannula can cause local superficial thrombophlebitis if it is left in place for more than
questions.solution:
The presence of an intravenous cannula for longer than 24–48 hours often leads to local thrombosis.

Superficial thrombophlebitis is a superficial venous thrombosis. Common causes include external trauma (especially to varicose veins), venepunctures and infusions of hyperosmolar solutions and drugs. 

The superficial vein feels solid and is tender on palpation. The overlying skin may be attached to the vein and may be erythematous in the early stages before gradually turning brown.

questions.text: To eradicate measles, the children under 1 year of age to be vaccinated is at least ______ %
questions.solution:
To eradicate measles, at least 96% of the children under 1 year of age, need to be vaccinated.

Factors in favor of measles eradication are that only 2 doses are needed and a more heat stable measles vaccine has now been developed.

questions.text: A five year old child present with gradually progressive hoarseness of voice for 3 months and stridor for 2 weeks. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this case scenario is Recurrent Respiratory Papillomatosis (RRP), also known as juvenile papillomatosis. This condition is caused by a viral infection, specifically linked to human papillomavirus (HPV) types 6 and 11.

RRP primarily affects the anterior part of the glottis, with the anterior commissure and vocal folds being the most common sites of involvement. It is more frequently observed in children under the age of 5.

The exact mode of transmission for RRP is not fully understood, but there is a recognized association between maternal genital warts and the development of recurrent laryngeal papillomatosis in offspring. The primary treatment for RRP is surgical removal, typically performed using endoscopic techniques. The CO2 laser is the most commonly used tool for this procedure. However, recurrence is common in RRP, often requiring multiple surgical interventions over time. Effective management is crucial due to the potential impact on the airway and vocal function.

Other options:

Option A: Vocal nodule develops after voice abuse which is unlikely here.

Option B: Croup presents acutely with fever.

Option C: Hoarseness of voice can be seen in hypothyroidism but not stridor.

questions.text: All of the following caspases are involved in apoptosis, except _____.
questions.solution:
Caspase 11 is not involved in apoptosis.

Caspases are cysteine proteases that cleave the proteins at the aspartic acid residue. The activation of caspases plays a key role in the process of apoptosis. Caspases involved in apoptosis are :

  • The mitochondrial or intrinsic pathway of apoptosis involves caspase 9.
  • The death receptor or extrinsic pathway of apoptosis involves caspase 8 and caspase 10.
