questions.text: The fibrous element of the extracellular matrix in the connective tissue is formed by all except
questions.solution:
The fibrous element of the extracellular matrix in the connective tissue is formed by all except the ground substance.

Connective tissue is made up of cells and extracellular matrix.

Cells include fibroblast, macrophage, plasma cell, mast cell, fat cell, and pigment cell.

The extracellular matrix has a fibrous and a non-fibrous element.

The fibrous element has three types of fibres — collagen, elastin and reticulin.

The non-fibrous element is formed by the ground substance.

questions.text: A patient of head injury was brought to the hospital. Patient was conscious having clear nasal discharge through right nostril. Non contrast CT head was done which revealed non operable injury to fronto basal area. What is most appropriate management?

choices.text: Put a dural catheter to control CSF leak
Do an MRI to localize the leak and control  the discharge endoscopically
Wait and watch for 4-5 days to allow spontaneous healing
Approach transcranially to repair damaged frontobasal region

questions.solution:
The most appropriate management of a conscious patient of head injury with clear nasal discharge through right nostril with non operable injury to frontobasal area on NCCT head is wait and watch for 4-5 days to allow spontaneous healing.

Treatment CSF rhinorrhea:

  • Early cases of post traumatic CSF rhinorrhea are managed conservatively by placing the patient in the semi sitting position, avoiding blowing of nose, sneezing and straining.
  • Prophylactic antibiotics are also determined to prevent meningitis.
  • Persistent cases of CSF rhinorrhoea are treated surgically by nasal endoscopic or intracranial approach.
  • Nasal endoscopic approach is useful for leaks from the frontal sinus, cribriform plate, ethmoid or sphenoid sinuses.

questions.text: Which of the following species is not resistant to Polymyxins?
questions.solution:
Acinetobacter, Pseudomonas and Enterobacteriaceae are usually susceptible to Polymyxin. 

Proteus, Serratia spp., Stenotrophomonas and Burkholderia are usually resistant.

But recently, rising resistance has been noted among the susceptible species as well.

questions.text: A 5 yr old girl is brought to you by her mother, stating that the girl drinks a lot of water. Physical examination shows slight protusion of her eyes. Further work-up reveals the presence of multiple lytic bone lesions involving the calvarium and base of her skull. What is the most likely diagnosis for this girl?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture suggests that the girl has Hand Schuller Christian disease.

Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (LCH):

  • A spectrum of clinical diseases associated with the proliferation of Langerhans cells.
  • These cells contain distinctive granules, seen on electron microscopy – Rod shaped tennis racket or Birbeck granules.
  • Hand-Schuller-Christian disease (Multifocal LCH) –
    • Common in 2 - 6 years of life
    • The characteristic triad consists of:
      • Bony lytic skull lesions
      • Exopthalmos
      • Diabetes insipidus
  • Letterer-Siwe disease (Acute disseminated LCH):
    • Affects children before 3 yrs of age
    • Features
      • Seborrheic lesions,
      • Anaemia, thrombocytopenia
      • Recurrent infections
      • Clinical course is usually rapidly fatal
  • Unifocal Langerhans cell histiocytosis (eosinophillic granuloma)is a localized form of histiocytosis, a benign lesion of proliferating Langerhans' cells. It is the least severe of the histiocytosis syndromes, and is characterized by lytic lesions of one or more bones.
  • Seen in older patients, mostly affecting the skeletal system.

questions.text: The decorporation agent of choice for contamination by Uranium is:
questions.solution:
Bicarbonate is the decorporation agent of choice for internal Uranium contamination. It causes increased excretion of Uranium via the kidneys.

Decorporation refers to the treatment for internal radionuclide contamination. The agents used for decorporation mainly act by increasing excretion, decreasing gut absorption or chelation. 

Some of the common decorporation agents used are:

Decorporation agent Used for radionuclide Mechanism of action
Potassium Iodide (KI) Iodine (131I) Blocking agent
Zn-DTPA, Ca-DTPA Plutonium, Curium, Americium, Yttrium Chelating agent
Bicarbonate Uranium Increased excretion by the kidneys

Prussian blue 

 Cesium (137Cs)  Ion exchanger 
Water  Tritium (3H) Excretion of water 
 Aluminum phosphate gel, Aluminium hydroxide Strontium  Decreased gut absorption

questions.text:
Which of the following side effects are seen with the respective classes of NSAIDs?
1.	Indomethacin cause autoimmune hemolytic anemia
2.	Fenamates causes psychosis and hallucinations
questions.solution:
Autoimmune hemolytic anemia is a potentially serious but rare side effect of Fenamates.

Psychosis and hallucinations are seen with Indomethacin.

A high percentage of patients taking indomethacin experience side effects. The most frequent CNS effect is severe frontal headache. Dizziness, vertigo, light-headedness, and mental confusion may occur, depression, psychosis, hallucinations, and suicide.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of prospective screening?

choices.text: Cervical Pap smear in a 40 year old patient
Neonatal screening of a new-born baby for hypothyroidism
Screening of immigrants to a country
Urine for sugar screening in a 40 year old man

questions.solution:
Screening of immigrants to a country is an example of prospective screening.

Screening of disease is done to detect unrecognized disease or defect, in apparently healthy individuals, by means of rapidly applied tests, examinations, or other procedures.

The difference between prospective and prescriptive screening is given below:

  Prospective screening Prescriptive screening
Definition People screened for others benefit People screened solely for their own benefit
Essential purpose Disease control Case detection
Request for screening Specific request from the authority Request from physician
Example
  • Immigrants for infectious diseases like tuberculosis syphilis, yellow fever, etc;
  • HIV screening during antenatal visits, sex workers.
  • Screening of blood donors.
  • Neonatal screening for hypothyroidism.
  • Pap smear for detection of cervical cancer.
  • Testing of urine sugar for diabetes mellitus.

Note: Most common neonatal disease to be screened for is neonatal hypothyroidism.

questions.text: Autosomal Dominant Myotonia (Thomsen’s disease) is due to which channelopathy?
questions.solution:
Thomsen’s disease is a chloride channelopathy, which is an autosomal dominant condition. Becker disease is also related to the same genetic abnormality but is autosomal recessive.

Salient features of Chloride channel disorders:

  • Symptoms are noted in infancy and early childhood.
  • Muscle strenth is normal (Thomsen's disease) or sometimes weak (Becker disease).
  • Myotonia is worsened by cold and improved by activity.
  • Lab findings: Serum CK is normal or mildly elevated. Muscle biopsy shows hypertrophied fibers.
  • Treatment: Many patients will not require treatment as symptoms improve with activity. Treatment to decrease myotonia however include quinine, phenytoin, and mexiletine.

questions.text: An investigator wants to study the association between maternal intake of iron supplements and birth weights of new-born babies. He collects relevant data from 100 pregnant women and their new-borns. What statistical test of hypothesis would you advice for the investigator in this situation?
questions.solution:
According to the question, the association to be studied is between maternal intake of iron (yes/no) and birth weight of new-borns (to see the proportion of low birth weight) i.e. it is between qualitative characteristics. Thus Chi-square test is the most appropriate here.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about tramadol?

choices.text: Maximum recommended daily dose is 400 mg
Tramadol-induced respiratory depression is reversed by naloxone
For mild-to-moderate pain, morphine is more effective than tramadol
Peak action is seen within 2-3 hours and lasts for about 6 hours

questions.solution:
For the treatment of mild-to-moderate pain, tramadol is as effective as morphine or meperidine. However, for the treatment of severe or chronic pain, tramadol is less effective.

Tramadol is a synthetic codeine analog that acts as a mu-opioid receptor agonist. It also acts by inhibiting the uptake of norepinephrine and serotonin. The action peaks within 2–3 hours of oral dosing. The duration of analgesia is about 6 hours.

The maximum recommended daily dose is:

  • 400 mg for adults
  • 300 mg in patients >75 years old
  • 200 mg for patients with low creatinine clearance

Adverse effects include nausea, vomiting, dizziness, dry mouth, sedation, headache and respiratory depression. Tramadol-induced respiratory depression is reversed by naloxone. Tramadol can exacerbate seizures in patients with predisposing factors. Tramadol should be avoided in patients taking MAO inhibitors, SSRIs, or other drugs that lower the seizure threshold.

Clinical relevance: Precipitation of withdrawal necessitates that tramadol is tapered prior to discontinuation.

questions.text: Enlargement of pituitary tumour after adrenalectomy is called as
questions.solution:
Enlargement of pituitary tumour after adrenalectomy is called as Nelson's syndrome.

It is a rare clinical manifestation that occurs in 8%-47% of patients as a complication of bilateral adrenalectomy, a procedure that is used to control hypercortisolism in patients with Cushing's disease. It is associated with a clinical triad of hyperpigmentation, excessive adrenocorticotropin secretion, and a corticotroph adenoma. The primary treatment for Nelson's syndrome is transsphenoidal surgery. 

Steele Richardson syndrome, also known as progressive supranuclear palsy is a neurodegenerative disease which affects the brainstem and basal ganglia. Patients present with disturbance of balance, a disorder of downward gaze and L-DOPA-unresponsive parkinsonism and usually develop progressive dysphagia and dysarthria leading to death from the complications of immobility and aspiration.

Acute interstitial pneumonia, also calles Hamman Rich syndrome is a rare and severe form of idiopathic interstitial lung disease.This disease is characterised by the following criteria:

  • Acute onset of respiratory failure, similar to ARDS
  • Bilateral lung infiltrates on radiograph
  • Diffuse alveolar damage (DAD) on lung histopathology
  • The absence of an identifiable cause or predisposing condition

Autosomal dominant hyper-IgE syndrome (Job syndrome) is an immunodeficiency disorder due to deficiency of Th17 cells due to STAT3 mutation leading to impaired recruitment of neutrophils to sites of infection. It is charachterised by coarse facies, cold(noninflamed) staphylococcal abscesses, retained primary teeth, ↑ IgE, eczema. Bone fractures from minor trauma.

questions.text: In a 50 kg adult, how much fluid should be given in the first 8 hours for a 2nd-degree burn of 40%, sustained during a camping fire accident?
questions.solution:
As per the recent update :

Percentage of burn x weight (kg) x 2 = volume in ml.

So , substituting the values:

(Percentage of burn) 40 x 50 (weight in kg) x 2 = 4000ml

Volume in ml = 4000

In litres its 4 litres.

Half of fluid is given in first 8 hours  and other half in next 16 hours.

So first 8 hours its 2 litres.

 #RecentUpdate: The initial fluid rate used for burns resuscitation has been updated by the American Burn Association to reflect concerns about over-resuscitation when using the traditional Parkland formula. According to the 10th Edition of ATLS (2018), fluid resuscitation should begin at 2 ml of lactated Ringer’s x patient’s body weight in kg x % TBSA for second and third-degree burns. 

Note:% TBSA of 2nd and 3rd degree burns is calculated for the formula.Not for superficial/1st degree burns.

Related Pearl: Burns – Formulae for Fluid Calculation(Updated according to ATLS 10th edition 2018 guidelines)

Parkland’s formula gives the total fluid requirement for 24hours. Half of this volume is infused in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is infused in the next 16 hours.

This formula is recommended for those who have sustained large deep partial-thickness or full-thickness burns that cover more than 20% of the TBSA in adults and more than 10% in children. 

Formulas provide a starting target rate; Subsequently, the amount of fluid provided should be adjusted based on urine output.

Category of burn Age Amount of Ringer’s Lactate given for 24 hours (ml) Target urine output (ml/kg/hour)
2nd/3rd-degree burns Adults  2 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 0.5
<14 years 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1
< 1 year or <30kgs 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA + 5% dextrose on a maintenance rate 1
4th-degree burns / Electrical burns All ages 4 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1-1.5 (until urine clears)

Dextrose maintenance:

  • 100 ml/ kg in 24 hours for 10 kg
  • 50 ml/kg for next 10 kg
  • 20 ml/kg for every kg after 20 kg

Evan’s formula is used for normal saline.

For the first 24 hours:

  • Amount of NS administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • Amount of colloid administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • 5% Dextrose administered= 2000 ml

After 24 hours, the amount of NS and colloid administered is half. 2000 ml of dextrose is maintained.

Muir and Barclay’s formula for colloids:

  • 1 portion of colloid = (weight in kgs x % TBSA)/2
  • 6 portions of colloid are administered over 36 hours

questions.text: Most of the parotid tumour are managed by:
questions.solution:
Most of the parotid tumour are managed by superficial parotidectomy.

Treatment of salivary gland tumours:

  • Parotid malignancies - superficial parotidectomy with preservation of facial nerve.                                                                                                                           - total parotidectomy with nerve preservation if deep lobe is involved.
  • Other salivary glands: en-bloc excision of tumour
  • Neck dissection for lymph nodes: palpable nodes and high grade malignancies
  • Radiotherapy: indications-high grade tumour, large primary lesion, perineural invasion, bone invasion, cervical lymph node metastasis, positive surgical margins.

questions.text: Hepatic fibrosis is a feature of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Hepatic fibrosis is a feature of childhood (autosomal recessive) polycystic kidney disease.

Related Pearl: Cystic Diseases of the Kidney

Features  Adult PKD Childhood PKD
Mode of inheritance Autosomal dominant Autosomal recessive
Mutation in genes PKD1, PKD2 PKHD1
Proteins produced Polycystin 1, polycystin 2 Fibrocystin
Chromosomes involved 16p, 4q 6p
Extrarenal manifestations 

Multiple cysts in the liver (most common), pancreas, spleen

Berry aneurysms in the circle of Willis - SAH

Colonic diverticuli

Mitral valve prolapse

 Congenital hepatic fibrosis

Other cystic diseases:

Medullary sponge kidney - 

  • Sporadic in origin
  • Characterized by medullary cysts
  • Associated with hematuria, recurrent renal stones, and normal renal function

Multicystic renal dysplasia - 

  • Characterized by irregular, enlarged, multicystic kidneys
  • Associated with ureteropelvic obstruction, ureteral agenesis, or atresia 
  • Bilateral multicystic renal dysplasia  is associated with renal failure

Simple renal cysts - 

  • Characterized by single or multiple cysts with normal-sized kidney
  • Associated with microscopic hematuria

questions.text: A smoker suspected to have polycythemia, undergoes a series of laboratory tests which reveal an elevated RBC mass, elevated serum Erythropoietin(EPO) levels and normal O2 saturation. What is the next best step in the investigation of this patient?
questions.solution:
The next ideal step would be to measure carboxyhemoglobin levels.

  • An elevated level would confirm the diagnosis of Smoker's polycythemia.
  • However if the carboxyhemoglobin levels are normal, then O2 Hemoglobin affinity is measured to either confirm O2 affinity hemoglobinopathy (increased affinity) or search for other tumors (normal affinity). 

Other options:

  • O2 Hemoglobin affinity would have been measured earlier if the patient in the given question was a non-smoker.
  • Jak-2 levels are measured only if EPO levels are low and Polycythemia Vera is suspected.
  • Evaluation for COPD, heart disease, or intracardiac shunt is necessary only if the O2 saturation is low.

The institution depicted in the image is World Health Organization (WHO). Dr.Tedros Ghebreyesus is the current Director-General of WHO.

questions.text: A 25-year-old marathon runner presents with complaints of joint pain and rashes over the face. She says the rashes appear on exposure to the sun. On physical examination, a butterfly rash is seen over her face sparing the nasolabial folds. Which of the following antibodies will you evaluate to screen this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). The best screening test in this condition is to evaluate for the presence of antinuclear antibodies (ANAs).

questions.text: Regarding H1N1 influenza in pregnancy which of the following statement is true?

choices.text: Live attenuated vaccine administration is justified in case of pandemic
Treatment with antiviral should be started only after lab. confirmation
Oseltamavir 75 mg twice daily is prescribed for 5 days

questions.solution:
In case of H1N1 influenza in pregnancy, Oseltamavir 75 mg twice daily is prescribed for 5 days.

Treatment with antiviral medications should begin as soon as possible and without waiting for results of diagnostic testing. A negative laboratory test should not stop treatment in a patient with clinical suspicion of influenza. Pregnant women who meet the current case definition for uncomplicated illness with confirmed or suspected pandemic (H1N1) 2009 virus should be treated early with the antiviral medications Oseltamivir or Zanamivir. The regimen is the same as the regimen (75mg BID) for other adults. Treatment is for 5 days.

Pregnant women should be immunized as a priority group given their increased risk of complications and death. Only inactivated influenza vaccine is suitable for pregnant women and children less than 24 months of age. Live attenuated influenza vaccine should not be used in this population.

questions.text: The best indicator for monitoring the impact of Iodine Deficiency Disorders (IDD) control programme is:

choices.text: Prevalence of goitre among school children
Urinary iodine levels among pregnant women

questions.solution:
Urinary Iodine Levels (UID) is the principal impact indicator of IDD control programme.

Other options:

Goitre Assessment: (By palpation or ultrasound) should remain a component of survey to establish the baseline severity of IDD. However, the changes in goitre prevalence lag behind changes in iodine status and therefore cannot be relied upon to reflect accurately the current iodine intake (useful in following trends).

Neonatal TSH levels: May also play a role if the country has already in place a screening programme for hypothyroidism.

questions.text: What is the causative organism for the condition given below?
questions.solution:
The condition shown in the image is condyloma acuminata. It is caused by HPV 6 and 11.

Condyloma acuminatum is a genital wart which is a moist, soft, pedunculated wart found on the external genitalia.

questions.text: Which of the following statements refers to health propaganda?
questions.solution:
Health propaganda appeals to emotions.

Health Education vs. Propaganda

 

  Health education  Health propaganda
Knowledge Actively acquired Instilled in the mind
Skills Actively acquired Instilled
Primitive desires Disciplined Aroused
Action Reflective behaviour; trained to use judgement before acting Reflexive behaviour;Aims at impulsive action 
Emotion  Does not appeal to emotion but appeals to reason Appeals to emotion
Behaviour Process is behaviour centered  Process is information centered

questions.text: All the following are true about baroreceptors, except

choices.text: Receptors at low pressure part of circulation are called cardiopulmonary receptors
Afferent fibers from baroreceptors secrete Glutamate
Center for Reflex is Medulla (Nucleus Tractus Solitarius)
Baroreceptors are more sensitive to constant pressure than pulsatile pressure

questions.solution:
Baroreceptors are more sensitive to pulsatile pressure than constant pressure.

They are located in:

  1. Carotid sinus and aortic arch
  2. Walls of the right and left atria and pulmonary circulation

These receptors in the low-pressure part (atria & pulmonary) are called the cardiopulmonary receptors.

Discharge from baroreceptors pass via CN IX & X to the medulla (NTS).

questions.text: Which of the following drug combinations is not contraindicated?
questions.solution:
Emtricitabine and tenofovir (brand name Truvada) is an FDCapproved combination for the treatment of HIV.

All the other combinations are contraindicated.

  • Combining Stavudine with Didanosine leads to increased risk and severity of peripheral neuropathy and potentially fatal pancreatitis.
  • Stavudine and Zidovudine compete for intracellular phosphorylation and should not be used concomitantly.
  • Tenofovir and Didanosine should not be used together. Tenofovir increases the plasma concentration of Didanosine when plotted against time.(Area under curve is increased)

questions.text: Congestive dysmenorrhea is seen in patients with:
questions.solution:
Congestive dysmenorrhoea is commonly seen in PID, IUCD wearers, pelvic endometriosis, fibroids and varicosity of pelvic veins. It manifests as increasing pelvic pain a few days before menses begin.

Spasmodic menstruation is the most prevalent type and manifests as cramping pains, generally most pronounced on the first and second day of menstruation.

Membranous dysmenorrhoea is a rare variety where the endometrium is shed as a cast at the time of menstruation accompanied by painful uterine cramps.

questions.text: The graph in the image is not a representation of which of the following opioids
questions.solution:
The graph is of ceiling effect of opioids i.e. with some opiods when ceiling(roof) is reached further increament in dose not result in increase in effect. Ceiling effect is particularly seen with respiratory depression i.e. higher dose do not produce further respiratory depression.

Eg. Buprenorphine, butorphanol, nalbuphine, pentazocaine

Morphine does not show ceiling effect. Respiratory depression increases proportionally with dose.

Related Pearl: Ceiling effect of opioids

Drug Correlation of Respiratory Depression With Dose
Morphine

Increases proportionally with dose (i.e. no ceiling effect)
Buprenorphine

Ceiling effect at 0.15-1.2 mg in adults
Butorphanol

Ceiling effect at 30-60 μg/kg
Nalbuphine

Ceiling effect at 30 mg in adults
Pentazocine 

Ceiling effect suggested

questions.text: A child accidentally consumed pesticide which had fluoroacetate as one of the ingredients. Which of the following enzymes in TCA cycle are likely to be inhibited in this child?
questions.solution:
Fluoro acetate inhibits the aconitase enzyme in TCA cycle. Hence it will be inhibited in this child.

In the body, fluoroacetyl-CoA will condense with oxaloacetate to form fluorocitrate. This will inhibit aconitase, leading to citrate accumulation.

Related Pearl: Steps involved in TCA cycle

Step 1

Acetyl CoA + Oxaloacetate → Citrate

     (2C  + 4C  =   6C)

Enzyme: Citrate Synthase

Irreversible, Exothermic reaction
Step 2

Citrate → Cis –aconitate  → Isocitrate 

( 6C    →          6C →             6C)

Enzyme:   Aconitase

Cofactor:   Fe2+

The Reaction occurs in 2 steps:         

1st step:  Dehydration      

2nd step:  Rehydration

Inhibited by: Fluoroacetate (Non- Competitive)
Step 3

Isocitrate →[Oxalosuccinate]→α- Keto glutarate

        (6C) →         [6C]         →         (5C)

Enzyme:  Isocitrate Dehydrogenase

Cofactor:   Mn2+ or Mg2+

Reaction:  Oxidative  Decarboxylation

Intermediate:   Oxalosuccinate [ Unstable]

Release:    1 NADH and CO2
Step 4

α- Keto glutarate → Succcinyl Co A 

       (5C             →         4C)

Enzyme: α- Ketoglutarate Dehydrogenase(Multienzyme complex)

Reaction:  Oxidative Decarboxylation

Inhibited by: Arsenite  (Non – Competitive)

Physiologically unidirectional step.

Release: 1 NADH and CO2
Step 5

Succinyl- CoA  → Succinate

      ( 4C          →         4C )

Enzyme:  Succinate Thiokinase

Cofactor: Mg2+

Release:  1 ATP / GTP

Substrate level phosphorylation
Step 6

Succinate  →   Fumarate

( 4C          →         4C )

Enzyme:  Succinate Dehydrogenase (Part of 2nd complex ETC)

Cofactor:  FAD and Fe-S protein 

The only enzyme of TCA cycle attached to the inner mitochondrial membrane.

Inhibited by: Malonate ( competitive)

Release: FADH2
Step 7

Fumarate  →   Malate

( 4C         →     4C )

Enzyme:  Fumarate Hydratase

Reaction: Hydration
Step 8

Malate  →  Oxaloacetate  

( 4C     →        4C )

Enzyme:  Malate Dehydrogenase

Release:  1 NADH

Oxaloacetate is regenerated.

questions.text: Incorrect statement about uterus are all except:

choices.text: Length of uterine cervix> length of uterine corpus in nulliparous women
Length of uterine cervix > length of uterine corpus in multiparous women
Uterus is approximately  9 cm long in adult
Uterus is 12cm long in adult multiparous

questions.solution:
The uterus of adult women is approximately 9 cm in length.

Other options:

  • In premenarchal girls, the body of the uterus is only half as long as the cervix. In nulliparous women, the two are about equal in length. In multiparous women, the cervix is only a little more than a third of the total length of the uterus.
  • The prepubertal uterus varies in length from 2.5 to 3.5 cm compared with 9 to 10 cm in multiparous women.

questions.text: Vestibular evoked myogenic potential has been used in assessment of:
questions.solution:
Vestibular evoked myogenic potential has been used in assessment of inferior vestibular nerve function.

VEMP is a vestibule colic reflex whose afferent limb arises from acoustically insensitive cells in the saccule with signals conducted via inferior vestibular nerve.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child brought to the hospital with a history of loose stools. The mother says he is irritable and drinks water hastily when given. On examination, eyes are sunken and during the skin pinch test, the skin retracted within two seconds but not immediately. What is the treatment for the child?

choices.text: Administer the first dose of IV antibiotic and immediately refer to a higher center
Give oral fluids and ask the mother to continue the same and visit again the next day
Give zinc supplementation and oral rehydration solution only and ask mother to come back if some danger signs develop
Consider severe dehydration, start intravenous (IV) fluids, IV antibiotics, and refer to a higher center

questions.solution:
The child in this scenario has some degree of dehydration, since the child is restless and irritable, drinks water readily, has sunken eyes, and the skin goes back slowly on the skin pinch test (<2 seconds) with sunken eyes.

Treatment includes oral rehydration therapy and zinc supplementation  according to WHO Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Diseases (IMNCI) Protocol, Plan B.

WHO IMNCI PLANS:

Related Pearl: Symptoms associated with different levels of dehydration

Symptoms No or minimal dehydration Mild to moderate dehydration Severe dehydration
Loss of body weight <3% 3–9% >9%
Mental status Well; alert Fatigued or irritable Lethargic or unconscious
Thirst Drinks normally Thirsty; eager to drink Drinks poorly
Heart rate Normal Normal to increased Tachycardia
Quality of pulse Normal Normal to decreased Weak, thready or impalpable
Skin turgor test Instant recoil Recoil in <2 sec Recoil in >2 sec
Capillary refill Normal Prolonged Prolonged

Related Pearl: Treatment of dehydration based on severity

Plan A: For no dehydration or minimal dehydration. ORS is administered after each loose stool.

Age Amount 
<2 years 50–100 mL
2-10 years 100–200 mL
>10 years As much fluid as they want

Plan B: For moderate dehydration.

The amount of oral rehydration solution (ORS) to be given is 75 mL/kg body weight (wt × 75).

Plan C: Severe dehydration

Age First, give 30 mL/kg in Followed by 70 mL/kg in Total 100 mL/kg in
Infants (under 12 months) 1 hr 5 hrs  6 hrs
Older 30 min 2½ hrs  3 hrs

Note: Ringer lactate (ideal) or normal saline is used as intravenous fluids.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about gastrointestinal stromal tumour?

choices.text: Originates from interstitial cells of cajal
Most common mesenchymal tumour of GIT
ALK gene mutatition is seen in most of the cases

questions.solution:
ALK gene mutation is not seen in most of cases of GIST.

Gastrointestinal stromal tumors(GIST) are the most common sarcomatous tumors of the GI tract. They are derived from the interstitial cells of Cajal, intestinal pacemaker cell.

They are usually found in the stomach(40 - 60%), small intestine(30%) and colon(15%).

Overexpression of c-kit protooncogene is seen in 95% of these tumors and CD34+ in 60 - 70% of tumors.

The malignant potential of these tumors are assessed based on tumor size and mitotic activity.

The mainstay of treatment id complete surgical resection. Depending on tumor size, resection can include wide local excision, enucleation, sleeve gastrectomy, or total gastrectomy, with or without en bloc resection of adjacent organs.

questions.text: Which disease is transmitted by the insect depicted below?
questions.solution:
The image given is that of a sandfly, which is the vector for Kala Azar.

It is controlled by synthetic pyrethroids (Permethrin), as it is becoming increasingly resistant to DDT, Malathion and Propoxur.

Related Pearl: Sandfly

  • They are also referred to as Phlebotomus.
  • They transmit diseases such as kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis), Oriental sore, sandfly fever, and Oroya fever.
  • They are generally smaller than mosquitoes and are hairy insects.
  • They like to dwell in cracks and crevices in walls during the daytime. They are active during the night (nocturnal pests).
  • They do not fly for more than 50 yards.
  • They can be controlled by insecticides and also by proper sanitation.

questions.text: Duplicity theory is related to
questions.solution:
Duplicity theory relates to the two kinds of inputs from the eye to the CNS - Input from the rods and Input from the cones, each working maximally under different conditions of illumination.

The rods are extremely sensitive to light and are the receptors for night vision (scotopic vision).  The scotopic visual apparatus is incapable of resolving the details and boundaries of objects or determining their color.

The cones have a much higher threshold, but have a much greater acuity and is the system responsible for vision in bright light (photopic vision) and for color vision.

questions.text: A 23-year-old primigravida at 32 weeks of gestation presents to the labour room with lower abdominal pain. Her vitals are BP - 90/60 mmHg and PR - 120 bpm. Fetal distress was noted and she was taken up for a caesarean section. The uterus appears as shown below.  Which of the following is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: It is seen in revealed abruptio placenta
It is an indication for hysterectomy
It is a case of uteroplacental apoplexy

questions.solution:
The given image shows a couvelaire uterus or uteroplacental apoplexy which is seen in severe forms of concealed abruptio placenta. 

There is massive extravasation of blood into the uterine musculature up to the serosa. Thus, the uterus has a port wine colour, which can be patchy or diffuse. They can also extend to the broad ligament, ovaries and peritoneal cavity.

It is usually observed during caesarean section. It is not an indication of hysterectomy.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the pentad of Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP)?
questions.solution:
Liver failure is not a part of the pentad of TTP.

TTP is characterized by the pentad: Renal failure, microangiopathic haemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, neurologic symptoms and fever.

It causes accumulation of ultra-large multimers of von Willebrand factor as result of the absence or markedly decreased activity (< 5-10%) of the metalloprotease ADAMTS 13 which normally cleaves VWF.

It is three times higher among women.

Classic form of TTP is idiopathic TTP, which is usually the result of a deficiency in ADAMTS13.

Upshaw-Schülman syndrome is a hereditary condition characterized by congenital deficiency of ADAMTS13.

questions.text: You notice the following skin finding in a child presenting to the dermatology OPD. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
The given image depicts phrynoderma which can be managed by Vitamin A supplementation.

Phrynoderma (toad skin) is common in children in the 5 - 15 year age group. Earlier thought to be purely due to Vitamin A deficiency, now has been associated with other nutritional deficiencies including B complex, ribofla­vin, vitamin C, vitamin E, essential fatty acids, and malnutrition

It is a non-specific finding that can be associated with: 

• Liver cirrhosis.
• Malabsorption syndromes.
• Anorexia nervosa.
• Alcohol abuse.
• Nutritional deficiency following bariatric surgery.

It manifests as groups of papules, each one around 3–4 mm in diameter, with a central keratotic plug. The papules have a follicular distribution and give the skin a rough texture. The elbows and knees are the most commonly affected areas but the buttocks and extensor surfaces of the limbs may also be affected.

All patients with phrynoderma should have their Vitamin A levels measured. Treatment involves the correction of poor diet and administration of multivitamin preparations containing Vitamin A. 

 

Related Pearl: Vitamin-A supplementation & treatment of Vitamin-A deficiency

Vitamin A supplementation
Target group
6 to 11 months age
12 to 59 month of age (1yr to 5yr)
Dose
100,000 IU (oral)
200,000 IU (oral)
Frequency
Once
Every 4–6 months

 

Note: A total dose of 17 lakh IU given as per the following schedule:

  • 100,000 IU is given with measles vaccine at 9 months
  • 200,000 IU is given with DPT booster at 15–18 months
  • 200,000 IU is given every 6 months (till 5years of age)

 

Treatment of vitamin A deficiency
Age < 6 months 6-12 months > 1 year
Dose 50,000 IU 100,000 IU 200,000 IU

 

Note: Route of administration is oral, in the form of retinyl palmitate.

questions.text: Given is the image of the waveforms of brainstem evoked response audiometry. The wave V in the following image represents activity in which of the following
questions.solution:
The wave A OR Vth wave in BERA represents activity in lateral lemniscus.

Auditory brainstem response:

  • Used to elicit brainstem responses to auditory stimulation by clicks or tone bursts.
  • Non invasive technique to find the integrity of central auditory pathways through the eighth nerve, pons and midbrain.
  • The first, third and fifth waves are most stable and usedin measurements.
      TYPE     SITE OF ORIJIN
    Wave I Distal part of CNVIII
    Wave II Proximal part of CN VIII near the brainstem.
    Wave III  Cochlear nucleus
    Wave IV Superior olivary complex
    Wave V Lateral lemniscus
Wave VI and VII Inferior colliculus

Related Pearl: BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry) or ABR (Auditory Brainstem Response)

It is an objective test that records electrical activity occurring in the auditory pathway.

Normally, 7 waves are produced in the first 10ms. 

  • Wave I – distal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave II –proximal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave III – cochlear nucleus
  • Wave IV – superior olivary complex
  • Wave V – lateral lemniscus
  • Wave VI & VII – inferior colliculus

Findings:

  • Conductive or cochlear pathology- delayed wave-I but inter-peak latency of I-V is normal
  • Retrocochlear pathology- wave-I present, rest of the waves absent
  • Acoustic neuroma or vestibular schwannoma- increased inter-peak latency of wave I-V and increased inter-aural latency of wave V > 0.2ms.

Uses:

  • To objectively find hearing threshold- wave-V appears 10dB above the hearing level obtained through PTA
  • Best audiometric test for:
    • Confirming hearing loss in infants
    • Diagnosing acoustic neuroma
    • Differentiating cochlear and retro-cochlear hearing loss
    • Diagnosing non-organic hearing loss.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about sarcoidosis is false?

choices.text: The granulomas of sarcoidosis can resolve with or without therapy
HLA-DRB1*1101 is associated with an increased risk for developing sarcoidosis
Persistent form of the disease is associated with high levels of IL-6
Severely immunocompromised patients of HIV rarely develop the disease

questions.solution:
IL-8, not IL-6, is often secreted at high levels in the persistent form of Sarcoidosis.

The granulomatous response of sarcoidosis can resolve with or without therapy. However, in at least 20% of patients with sarcoidosis, a chronic form of the disease develops.

HLA-DRB1*1101 is associated with an increased risk for developing sarcoidosis

Untreated patients with HIV infection, who lack helper T cells rarely develop sarcoidosis. In contrast, sarcoidosis becomes unmasked as HIV-infected individuals receive antiretroviral therapy as the immunity is gradually restored.

questions.text: All of the following are true about retropharyngeal abscess except

choices.text: Confined to one side of the midline
Presents as unilateral para-median bulge of the posterior pharyngeal wall
Dysphagia and difficulty in breathing is present

questions.solution:
Retropharyngeal abscess is anterior to prevertebral fascia.

Retropharyngeal abscess:

  • Acute retropharyngeal abscess is commonly seen in children below 3 years.
  • It is the result of suppuration of retropharyngeal lymph nodes secondary to infection in the adenoids, nasopharynx, posterior nasal sinuses or nasal cavity.
  • In adults, it may result from penetrating injury of posterior pharyngeal wall or cervical oesophagus.
  • Dysphagia and difficulty in breathing are prominent symptoms as the abscess obstructs the air and food passages.
  • Stridor and croupy cough may be present.
  • Torticollis develops- the neck becomes stiff and the head is kept extended.
  • Bulge in posterior pharyngeal wall on Xray. Usually seen on one side of the midline.

Chronic retropharyngeal abscess is tubercular in nature and is the result of

  • Caries of cervical spine
  • Tuberculous infection of retropharyngeal lymph nodes secondary to tuberculosis of deep cervical nodes.

questions.text: Which of the following features differentiate hydranencephaly from hydrocephalus?

choices.text: Hydranencephaly is static while hydrocephalus continues to increase in size
Hydranencephaly does not cause increase in head size
Cerebral cortex is deficient in hydranencephaly

questions.solution:
Cerebral cortex is deficient/hypoplastic in hydranencephaly. In hydranencephaly, cerebral hemispheres are absent or represented by membranous sacs. Remnants of frontal, temporal, or occipital cortex are dispersed over the membrane. Mid-brain and brainstem are relatively intact.

Infants with hydranencephaly can have a normal or enlarged head circumference at birth which can grow at an excessive rate postnatally.

questions.text: Socialized medicine is___________

choices.text: Integration of social medicine with health care
Charitable care through donations by NGOs, regulated by government
Free medical care regulated by professional groups at government expense
Integration of social science with medicine

questions.solution:
Socialized medicine is free medical care at government expense, regulated by professional groups.

Socialized medicine: Provision of medical services and professional education by the state but the programme is operated and regulated by professional groups rather than by the government.

  • It prevents competition between practitioners and clients
  • Provision of medical services supported by the state government
  • Ensures social equity that is universally operated by professional health services
  • Russia is the first country to completely socialize medicine

State medicine: Provision of free medical services to the people at government expense.

Social medicine: Study of the social, economic, environmental, cultural, psychological and genetic factors, which have a bearing on health.

questions.text: Which of the following forms the internal component of a cochlear implant?
questions.solution:
Receiver stimulator is implanted during surgery (under the skin) and electrode array(implanted in the scala tympani of the cochlea) are the part of the internal component of the cochlear implant.

Microphone, speech processor and transmitter are the part of the external component of the cochlear implant which remain outside the body.

Cochlear implants replace the non-functional transducer system of hair cells of the cochlea, convert the sound signal to electrical impulses which directly stimulate the fibers of cranial nerve VIII.

Used in the cochlear type of sensorineural hearing loss.

Related Pearl: Cochlear implant

A cochlear implant replaces the organ of Corti i.e. when hair cells of the organ of Corti are severely damaged these implants bypass it and directly stimulate the auditory nerve.

Indication: Bilateral severe sensorineural hearing loss i.e. > 70 dB.

Components:

Preoperative investigation: Complete audiological evaluation and HRCT and MRI (to detect the structure of cochlea, cochlear nerve and CNS abnormalities).

Surgical approach: Two surgical techniques to approach the cochlea for implantation are the facial recess approach (via facial recess) and the pericanal technique (via EAC).

Postoperatively: Activation of the device after 3-4 weeks and evaluation is by HRCT (MRI is contraindicated).

Contraindications:

  • Absence of cochlea (Michel aplasia)
  • Deafness due to absent cochlear nerve, lesions of cochlear nerve or lesions of the central auditory pathway

questions.text: Classified according to the vascular anatomy of the muscle, what type of muscle is Gracilis?
questions.solution:
Gracilis is a type II muscle, with a single dominant vascular pedicle and several minor pedicles.

The gross vascular anatomy of muscles has been classified into five types according to the number and relative dominance of vascular pedicles that enter the muscle. This classification has important surgical relevance in determining which muscles will survive, and therefore be useful for pedicled or free tissue transfer procedures in plastic and reconstructive surgery.

Type Blood Supply by Examples
Type I A single vascular pedicle supplying the muscle belly Tensor fasciae latae, Gastrocnemius
Type II A single dominant vascular pedicle and several minor pedicles Gracilis
Type III Two separate dominant pedicles, from different source arteries. Rectus abdominis, Gluteus maximus
Type IV Multiple small pedicles that, are not capable of supporting the muscle individually Sartorius and Tibialis anterior
Type V One dominant vascular pedicle and multiple secondary segmental pedicles Latissimus Dorsi

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of Cushingoid features?
questions.solution:
Iatrogenic hypercortisolism is the most common cause of Cushingoid features.

Ectopic tumour ACTH production, cortisol-producing adrenal adenomas, adrenal carcinoma, and adrenal hyperplasia are the other causes associated.

Related Pearl: Causes of Cushing's Syndrome

Exogenous causes (iatrogenic)

  • Prolonged administration of glucocorticoids (most common cause of Cushing's)

Endogenous causes

  • ACTH independent (primary hypercortisolism)
    • Adrenocortical adenoma 
    • Adrenocortical carcinoma 
    • Bilateral adrenal hyperplasia
  • ACTH dependent (secondary hypercortisolism)
    • Cushing’s disease: ACTH secreting pituitary adenoma (most common cause of endogenous Cushing's)
    • Paraneoplastic causes: Ectopic ACTH secreting tumors
      • Small-cell lung carcinoma
      • Bronchial or pancreatic carcinoid tumors
      • Medullary thyroid carcinoma
      • Pheochromocytoma

Rare causes

  • Macronodular adrenal hyperplasia
  • Primary pigmented nodular adrenal disease
  • McCune – Albright syndrome
